IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Center for Tumor-Immune Systems Biology at MSKCC NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapies are designed to harness the human immune system to attack cancer cells and eliminate tumors. Breakthroughs in cancer immunotherapy such as checkpoint blockade agents have revolutionized cancer care, but only a fraction of patients with specific tumor types respond to these new treatments. Our proposed Research Center will deploy tools from systems biology to improve our fundamental understanding of tumor-immune interactions in contexts where current immunotherapies fail and to develop novel strategies for enhancing responses in contexts where they have only partial success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV and TB constitute major threats to human health. Progress in understanding and managing HIV has been revolutionary and rapidly translated into practice. For epidemic control, we still require an effective HIV vaccine, biomedical interventions to solve adherence issues in treatment and prevention, and a cure. Similarly, an effective TB vaccine must still be found.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in learning and memory are pathological hallmarks of a range of cognitive disorders. Using a high- throughput learning paradigm in genetic outbred mice, we found gene expression differences in the subicular complex and will determine how genetic variation influences neuronal cell-type properties and functions that affect goal-directed learning. This will reveal how learning ability and deficits can manifest across individuals with diverse genetic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digestive and liver diseases have a significant effect on public health and health care utilization costs. This application requests support for a conference that nurtures junior investigators, with an emphasis on including underrepresented populations, interested in digestive and liver disease research. Our goals are to provide additional mentoring support during a critical time in their career and to familiarize them with the scientific and technological expertise available at Midwest Digestive Disease Research Core Centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: ________________________________________________________________________________________ PROJECT NARRATIVE The Adult Wellbeing CheckUp (AWC) platform (funded by the parent award) will facilitate wellbeing assessments, referrals, and recommendations of American adults over 65 years of age to age well. By personalizing to the context of an individual’s life and utilizing evidence-based behavior change principles, the platform will encourage older adults to take actions to improve their individual and overall wellbeing domains. The AWC commercialization plan relies on the reporting of the AWC to be delivered such that its initial customers will pay for ongoing annual subscriptions to the service. In this supplement, we intend to expand the AWC prototype with additional reporting features and a consumer-friendly, searchable data repository. These features, which were not previously proposed, will allow senior centers (and additional customer segments) to more deeply understand the engagement as well as health of their members. By adding these features, we can also better support and enable the AWC commercialization plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We present a graded approach – beginning with imaging and ending with therapy – to management of advanced, aggressive prostate cancer (PC) by leveraging what we have learned over the past two decades about the prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA). We propose machine learning methodology to enhance clinical interpretation of PSMA PET scans for patient management, and development of sensitive, new detection methods using photoacoustic imaging ultimately to avoid unnecessary surgery. We also propose ways to improve immunotherapy for the lethal neuroendocrine subtype of PC and to re-program it to render it more susceptible to emerging PC therapies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this conference is to convene nurse researchers who work in clinical practice settings to discuss the challenges and opportunities presented by their work. The long-term goal of the conference is to accelerate the scale, scope, speed, and rigor of research led by nurses in the clinical practice setting so that their work can have a greater impact on the quality, safety, accessibility, affordability, and equity of healthcare in the United States. The outcome of the conference will be a five-year strategic framework outlining the mission, vision, goals, strategic priorities, and cross-cutting strategies for clinically based nurse researchers to achieve this goal.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Setting a Strategic Framework to Maximize the Impact of Clinically Based Nurse Researchers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will explore the role of the hippocampal memory system in the incubation of craving for rewarding items by combining neuroimaging methods and natural language processing techniques. The F99 phase will identify the neural regions involved in instrumental markers of craving and relate them to linguistic profiles of subjective expressions of craving. The K00 phase will expand this program of research into clinically-relevant populations (e.g., nicotine users) to examine these same associations in a substance use population to enhance our understanding of substance-related alterations in reward memories related to drug craving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients undergoing hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) experience a period of bone marrow failure, which often requires significant transfusion support to replace low numbers of red blood cells, platelets and/or granulocytes. Together, the 3 independently meritorious projects proposed here, facilitated by the two cores, will yield a unified, focused, productive program that meaningfully elucidates the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the effect and effectiveness of blood transfusion in the peri-transplant setting with the ultimate goal of developing more efficient and effective Transfusion Medicine related strategies for the benefit of the blood transfusion recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because it seeks to develop personalized anti-tumor vaccines, focusing here on the childhood malignancy neuroblastoma. The research is highly relevant to the NIH mission and the urgent unmet need of developing rational evidence-based therapeutic and relapse preventative strategies to reduce the health burden of cancer. This integrated multiple principal investigator project is designed to catalyze improved cure rates with decreased morbidity for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma, and many advances will be applicable to the field of cancer in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancers cannot initiate or progress if their subcellular components are unable to overcome the stresses that accompany uncontrolled proliferation and growth. This Center seeks a predictive understanding of subcellular adaptations that must take place to accommodate and subvert the stresses that naturally occur in response to cancer-causing genetic alterations. Successful models of such adaptations will lead to secondary inferences about where cancer cells become vulnerable as a result of their internal adaptations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE The Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on “Alcohol-Induced End Organ Diseases” will create a state-of-the- art forum for discussion of alcohol research, including studies of acute and chronic alcohol exposure across the entire spectrum of lifespan on the significant and widespread detrimental organ system effects of alcohol. The conference will provide a unique forum to bring together a diverse range of young and established alcohol researchers, and experts in complementary fields, to discuss groundbreaking advances in how alcohol consumption results in tissue injury. The meeting format employed by the GRC facilitates open discussions, builds bridges in between investigators in different disciplines, as well as between preclinical and clinical investigators and fosters the development of the next generation of alcohol researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the neural and behavioral mechanisms of social visual attention using dynamic and context-rich stimuli. The F99 phase will investigate how and where humans make eye movements toward relevant information during dynamic emotion perception and with the use of computer vision models. The K00 phase extends this research by investigating the neural mechanisms of social visual attention using dynamic and context-rich stimuli as well as naturalistic imaging approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed under this F99/K00 fellowship will assess the role of KCC2-mediated synaptic plasticity in the VTA during naturalistic reward learning and resulting network-level modifications in this process. This will establish KCC2 modulation as a novel form of synaptic plasticity during reward learning and will demonstrate the potential of KCC2 as a target for intervention to treat neuropsychiatric disorders that are characterized by aberrant reward learning such as obsessive compulsive disorder and schizophrenia, among many others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cells can sense and move along shallow gradients of chemoattractants, a process that is essential for normal physiology in the embryo and adult as well as for the pathology of numerous diseases. These studies focus on the molecular mechanisms of motility and directed migration in normal and cancer cells. A thorough understanding of these processes will make it possible to interfere with them specifically in target cells and eventually lead to new therapeutic strategies for cancer and a host of other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substantial evidence supports the use of medications to mitigate the harms associated with OUD, but 80% of people with OUD receive no treatment and only a third of those who do access treatment receive evidence- based medications. The present study proposes to develop and test a telehealth intervention for OUD treatment delivery specifically designed for marginalized patients who are likely to struggle with in-person treatment models, which has the potential to impact public health by increasing access to medications for OUD. The mentorship, training, and research activities in this application will prepare the candidate for an independent scientific career conducting intervention research to improve access to substance use disorder treatment and harm reduction services via innovative, low-barrier delivery models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Musculoskeletal (MSK) conditions are the leading contributor to disability worldwide, between one and three, and one and five people live with a musculoskeletal pain condition. Regular assessment of the state of MSK connective tissue is needed to better identify the pathophysiological origin of the inflammatory and fibrotic response. This research will advance the adaptation of low field magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as a novel, noninvasive, and affordable point of care diagnostic imaging method capable of assessing the state of MSK connective tissue and effective of regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adenomas are early lesions of colorectal cancer, but only a subset of adenomas progress and become cancer. In light of the well characterized clinical natural history of adenomas, we plan to study them as early lesions and to determine the mechanisms involved in the formation and progression of early precancerous lesions. We hypothesize that adenoma progression requires a suite of hallmark behaviors and that these behaviors are induced by adenoma autonomous factors (e.g. cancer driver gene mutations) and adenoma nonautonomous factors from the “primed colon” or adenoma microenvironment. Our proposed studies will integrate basic and translational cancer research projects to iteratively examine the direct causal relationships and interactions of adenomas, the colon “primed” microenvironment, and host-systemic factors as “co-organizers” of adenoma initiation and/or progression.

PHR: NARRATIVE This application seeks funding to support the new career-development pre-meeting, Ignite-Forum, family- and diversity-awards and participation of junior investigators at the 2024 FASEB science research conference on “Transcription, Chromatin, & Epigenetics in Aging”, held in Melbourne, Florida on September 22th – 26th, 2024. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian brain is energetically demanding with a unique lipid profile, and fatty acid dysregulation in the brain is associated with neurologic disorders including depression and autism spectrum disorders. Specific aspects of fatty acid metabolism such as bioenergetics and lipid homeostasis that may render the brain vulnerable to disease when perturbed are unknown, and studying brain bioenergetic capacity for beta-oxidation and transcriptional responses to lipid availability is fundamental to understanding how brain metabolism impacts nervous system structure, function, cognition, and predisposition to neuropathology. Understanding the metabolic contexts that predispose the brain to duress and impairment may direct future neurological interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Microcins have the rare ability to bind Gram-negative bacterial surface proteins and transport themselves across the outer membrane to inhibit essential targets hidden underneath. We lack an understanding of how microcins encode these remarkable abilities in their short protein sequences. We will uncover microcin domains important for each stage of their action and how variations in their surface receptor binding controls their spectrum of activity, which will support the future development of innovative antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) infection leads to substantial patient suffering and treatment cost because it is difficult to fully eradicate using antibiotics. In this work, we propose to design and optimize short proteins (peptides) that block the ability of C. difficile to damage tissue and deliver these peptides to the site of disease using probiotic yeast. This approach advances beyond current treatment methods due to its low cost, high specificity, and applicability to other gut infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Retroviruses integrate their DNA into the host DNA genome by the viral-encoded integrase, thus permanently changing the virus-infected cell. Assembly mechanisms of integrase multimers on the viral DNA ends producing intasomes that catalyze concerted integration are essentially unknown. We will use single-particle cryo-electron microscopy with biochemical and virological studies to determine the structure and assembly mechanisms of retrovirus intasomes using Rous sarcoma virus as a model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  This supplemental project seeks to advance our understanding of how Treg cells modulate effector, exhausted and memory T cell responses during BTE immunotherapy. This new knowledge gain will fuel newer combination regimens aimed at augmenting the therapeutic efficacy of BTEs by promoting anti-tumor effector and memory T cell responses in immunologically cold tumors characterized by paucity of T cells, while simultaneously mitigating bystander toxicity. These studies are of high significance to treatment of several pediatric and adult cold tumors such as neuroblastomas, gliomas, sarcomas and melanomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our overall goal is to understand how various patient-specific features of colorectal cancer (CRC) and its tumor-immune microenvironment (TIME) govern differential responses to different types of immunotherapies using novel in vitro ‘avatars’ of the tumor-immune circuit (‘TIvitars’) that we developed as the first aim of our parent grant. To accomplish this, we will establish and perform immunotherapy screens using human CRC tissues from 20 patients comparing responses of each tumor to a broad range of immunomodulators that can (a) compare efficacy among numerous therapies for each patient’s tumor in a response- predictive way, and (b) correlate these responses with the molecular and cellular characteristics of each tumor (obtained from standard -omics analysis of the samples) as well as with the patient’s microbiome (obtained from sequencing stool samples). The resulting data will form a completely unique dataset whereby standard -omics data from cancer patients will be coupled with differential immunotherapy responses for each.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A. Significance The significance is the same as in the original application. C. Approach C1. Specific Aim #1. To determine the optimal dose of NA-112 providing neuroprotection in two mouse models of epilepsy. C1.1. Rationale.  We have selected two mouse models to evaluate the role of calpain-2 activation as the triggering mechanism in the development of epilepsy. No model perfectly reproduces all the features of the human disease; however, models provide critical information regarding the underlying mechanisms that could be targeted in the human disease. Repeated injections of low doses of KA or pilocarpine in C57Bl/6 mice will be used as models of epilepsy because they both lead to the appearance of SRS, are amenable to animal implantation with EEG-recording equipment and have a high degree of animal survival (11-12). We have shown that NA-112 is neuroprotective in the repeated low doses of KA mouse model and that intranasal NA-112 administration in mice results in brain calpain inhibition. This aim will determine the optimal dose of intranasal NA-112 providing neuroprotection in both models of epilepsy. C1.2. Preliminary Results C1.2.1. Effects of NA-112 in the repeated low doses of KA epilepsy model.  We recently completed a series of experiments to determine the role of calpain-2 in the development of pathological manifestations of SE in mice. Our findings have been published in Neurobiology of Disease (9), and only a summary of the results is reported below. - KA model of epilepsy: All mice received three, consecutive, ip injections of kainic acid (5 mg/kg) every 20 min (10, 24) and were video-recorded for seizure analysis. - Mice: We used WT (C57BL/6J), calpain-2 conditional knockout (C2CKO, CamKII-Cre+/- CAPN2loxP/loxP) with deletion of calpain-2 in all excitatory neurons of the forebrain, and control (CAPN2loxP/loxP) mice. In addition, other groups of C57Bl/6J (WT) mice received daily ip injections of NA-112 (0.3 mg/kg/day) or vehicle (60 mg/kg/day of β-cyclodextrin) for 7 days starting 2 h after seizure initiation. - All mice exhibited SE and we did not observe any mortality with this protocol up to 7 days after KA-induced SE. There were no significant differences between any group for latency to first seizures, duration of first seizures and cumulative duration of stage 3-5 seizures. This is important, as it indicates that calpain-2 deletion or inhibition does not influence the initiation or duration of seizures, but rather the processes leading to neurodegeneration and neuroinflammation. - Seven days after seizure onset, numerous degenerating neurons were observed in hippocampus of WT animals, especially in the hilus of the dentate gyrus, identified as mossy cells; C2CKO mice were almost completely devoid of degeneration in all hippocampal subfields. Similar neuroprotective results were found when WT mice were treated daily with ip injections of NA-112. - Calpain-2 activation was detected in mossy cells up to 7 days after KA injection, and this activation was absent in C2CKO mice or in mice treated with NA-112. There was a clear correlation between calpain-2 activation in mossy cells with mossy cell death in WT mice. - KA-induced seizures resulted in strong astroglial and microglial activation in WT mice 7 days after KA-induced SE. Daily ip injections of NA-112 eliminated both astroglial and microglial activation. Similar results were found in the C2CKO mice. The prolonged duration of calpain-2 activation suggests that the window for intervention with a selective calpain-2 inhibitor following SE will be quite broad, although this will need to be further assessed in the Phase II of this STTR. - Cognitive performance was assessed by determining context-and tone-dependent memory in fear conditioning (FC) 7 days after seizure activity. Hippocampal-dependent contextual and tone memory was significantly impaired in WT and CAPN2 loxP (control) mice but not in C2CKO mice after seizures. Likewise, there was no significant impairment in mice treated daily with ip injections of NA-112. These results strongly support the premise that a selective calpain-2 inhibitor could be beneficial to prevent many of the neuropathological consequences of SE. - Blood P13BP levels are elevated after KA-induced seizures. We analyzed plasma levels of P13BP 24 h after KA-induced seizures (Fig. 1). P13BP blood levels were greatly  elevated 24 h after KA-induced seizures in WT but not in C2CKO mice. Similar  results were found in WT mice treated with NA-112 administered ip 3 h after SE  (not shown). Figure 1: Plasma levels of P13BP 24 h after KA-induced seizures. Blood was collected 24 h after KA-induced seizures and aliquots of plasma processed for western blot analysis of PTPN13 (WES system). The fragment migrating at 150 kDa is referred to as P13BP and quantified. Results are means ± S.E.M. of 6 animals. *** p < 0.001; **** p < 0.0001. One way ANOVA followed by Bonferroni test.  C1.2.2. Intranasal delivery of NA-112 inhibits brain calpain-2 activation.  We tested the effects of intranasal administration of various does of NA-112 on calpain-2 activity in anasal NA-112 prevents KA-induced hippocampal calpain  hippocampus 24 h after the administration (Fig. 2). Calpain-2 activation was completely prevented at the lowest  activation in mice  dose tested (0.1 mg/kg). Higher doses further decreased calpain-  * 2 activation to levels lower than those seen in control conditions  suggesting that NA-112 inhibits basal levels of calpain-2 activity.  Figure 2: Intranasal NA-112 prevents KA-induced hippocampal  calpain-2 activation in mice. Repeated low doses of KA (5 mg/kg) were  administered to adult mice. NA-112 was administered intranasally 2 h  after the end of seizure activity. Animals were sacrificed 24 h later and  ‡ the hippocampus was dissected and processed for immunoblotting with  ‡ a spectrin antibody. The ratios of SBDP/spectrin were analyzed. Results  ‡ are means ± SEM of 4 experiments. Statistical analysis was performed vs control with ANOVA with post-hoc comparisons. * p< 0.001 vs cont. ‡ p < 0.01 1 vs KA vs KA. Repeated low doses of KA (5  red to adult mice. NA-112 was administered  the end of seizure activity. Animals were  nd plasma was collected an processed for  TPN13 antibody. The levels of the 130 kD  esults are means ± SEM of 4 experiments.  as performed with ANOVA with post-hoc  1 vs cont. ‡ p < 0.01 vs KA.  ‡  ‡  ‡ *p< 0.001 vs control ‡ p < 0.001 vs KA C1.3. Design and Experimental Approach. These are identical to those presented in the original application. Rigor in experimental design and statistical analysis.  All studies will be done in a blinded fashion, with the examiners analyzing the data blind to the experimental groups. Animal ID will be revealed after initial data analysis for group means and statistical analyses. All experiments will be performed with male and female mice. As mentioned above, there might be some differences for some of the outcome measures; in this case, data will be analyzed separately. When no obvious differences in outcome measures are observed, the data will be combined. The number of experiments we are proposing is based on our own as well as on previously published studies indicating it should be sufficient to detect significant differences between experimental groups. Statistical differences will be calculated with Student’s t-test when comparing 2 conditions. When comparing more than 2 conditions, ANOVA followed by Bonferroni tests will be used to determine statistical significance. Justification for the supplemental funding. This supplemental funding is requested to cover the additional cost to purchase the equipment needed to perform the proposed experiments, which is a combined video-EEG recording equipment from Biopac. As can be seen in the below email from Biopac, the original quote of $87,898 was missing some essential parts. These parts are essential for the completion of the experiments, and the fact they were not included in the initial quote was completely unexpected. At present, there is no fund in the current budget to cover this additional expense and we are already working with the minimum budget we need to complete the proposed experiments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adenomas are early lesions of colorectal cancer, but only a subset of adenomas progress and become cancer. In light of the well characterized clinical natural history of adenomas, we plan to study them as early lesions and to determine the mechanisms involved in the formation and progression of early precancerous lesions. We hypothesize that adenoma progression requires a suite of hallmark behaviors and that these behaviors are induced by adenoma autonomous factors (e.g. cancer driver gene mutations) and adenoma nonautonomous factors from the “primed colon” or adenoma microenvironment. Our proposed studies will integrate basic and translational cancer research projects to iteratively examine the direct causal relationships and interactions of adenomas, the colon “primed” microenvironment, and host-systemic factors as “co-organizers” of adenoma initiation and/or progression.

PHR: Project Narrative Uncorrupted gene expression is critical to cell function and human health. Our cells encode a multitude of RNA quality control machineries that detect and degrade defective RNAs that have the potential to interrupt gene expression, some of which have been linked to neurodegenerative disorders. The objective of this proposal is to uncover the mechanisms whereby these pathways detect and degrade defective RNAs in human cells, and the consequences of defects in these pathways to cell function and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Poly ADP ribose polymerase inhibitor (PARPi) have changed treatment paradigms, with greatest clinical benefits in BRCA mutant homologous recombination (HR) deficient ovarian cancer. A critical clinical problem is chemotherapy drugs, including PARPi, are far less effective in BRCA wild-type HR proficient ovarian cancer (e.g. CCNE1 amplification/gain). This proposal will apply an innovative translational research approach to determine the potential benefits of PARPi-epigenetic drug combinations for the treatment of poor prognostic ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High grade gliomas are aggressive brain tumors that occur in children and, with limited therapeutic options, are highly lethal. We have discovered a novel function for a protein commonly mutated in pediatric high grade gliomas, which leads to distinct changes in metabolism of the neural progenitor and tumor cells. Our proposed study seeks to understand how this protein regulates lipid metabolism specifically, and whether this distinct change can be targeted to improve therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survival rates for many childhood and adolescent cancers have improved at a remarkable pace over the past five decades. The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS; U24 CA055727; PI: Armstrong) cohort has been the source of some of the most significant publications to date addressing the long-term mortality, morbidity and quality of life of survivors of childhood cancer. Understanding the risk for late effects of childhood cancer and its therapy provides the basis for health screening recommendations and interventions that can mitigate long-term health problems in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The novel research proposed here aims to understand, identify, and characterize the exercise-linked neural changes that may result in improved inhibitory control in schizophrenia spectrum disorders (SSDs). This research is crucial for justifying a longer-term exercise intervention to establish whether such benefits can be established over the longer term and paving the way for more focused research on potential therapeutic targets. Training of the applicant will potentially lead to next generation neuroimaging and computational psychiatry techniques that will dissect underlying neurophysiological and structural neuronal processes of brain function, behavior, and psychopathology among SSDs, with an emphasis on individual differences due to deafness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The Achilles Tendinopathy Center of Research Translation (AT-CORT) at the University of Pennsylvania will foster fundamental discoveries to guide clinical translation, as well as develop and employ novel translational resources, models and technologies, to address the highly significant research and clinical challenge of Achilles tendinopathy. The Overall goal of the AT-CORT is to develop new insight and technologies that uncover the mechanobiologic basis of Achilles tendinopathy across length scales, from the nucleus, to the cell, to the tissue microenvironment to patients. Together, our highly interdisciplinary team, innovative tools, and interactive Research Projects and Cores will dramatically advance knowledge, develop innovative tools and insight, and provide new directions for translation of new therapies to treat Achilles tendinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurovascular unit dysfunction is seen in many neurological disorders, including post-pneumonia delirium and migraine. In this project, I will determine how bacterial pneumonia infection, specifically, if pneumonia-induced microglia activation first causes neurovascular unit dysfunction in vivo in experimental models, and differences in neurovascular unit state in pneumonia vs. non-pneumonia post-mortem human brain. For my postdoctoral project, I will utilize the methods I master during my PhD training to investigate the mechanisms of neurovascular dysfunction at the capillary level in migraine mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The recent surge in misuse of prescription opioids as painkillers, such as oxycodone, and the easy accessibility to illegal opioids, such as heroin and fentanyl, have contributed to the current epidemic of opioid overdoses. Better treatments for opioid use disorder (OUD) are urgently needed to produce long-term recovery and avoid relapse of drug use in vulnerable individuals. However, our knowledge of how opioids affect different brain systems during disease progression is limited. This supplement is to support a project for a postdoctoral fellow to explore the role of glucocorticoid receptors in response to opioid use at a single cell level during different stages of disease progression in a rodent model of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Over the past decade, indications for the use of metformin have steadily expanded to now include not only overt diabetes outside of pregnancy, but prediabetes, obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, gestational diabetes (GDM), and type 2 diabetes during pregnancy. With its expanded use, however, questions of unintended long-term harm to offspring exposed to metformin during gestation have arisen. The current proposal will generate a Rhesus macaque model and robust data necessary and sufficient to understand if, what, whether and how early life exposure to metformin (with and without maternal & post-weaning Western style diet feeding) renders offspring persistently susceptible to obesity and insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop an understanding of the detailed mechanisms by which clock proteins from diverse species generate circadian rhythms, used to align physiology and behavior with the day/night cycle for adaptive benefit. Bringing fundamental, molecular insight to the clock will facilitate the development of therapeutics that enhance the systemic synchronization of physiology and behavior to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endolysosomal trafficking is a major cellular process that keeps aging neurons healthy by controlling whether cellular contents are properly recycled or degraded. Defective endolysosomal trafficking is a converging mechanism in neurodegenerative diseases including Huntington's disease, a fatal disorder caused by an autosomal-dominant mutation in the Huntingtin gene. The goal of this proposed study is to elucidate the precise mechanism and function of Huntingtin in endolysosomal trafficking in a physiologic organism to identify new molecular targets for treating Huntington’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The human skeleton and its major joints, such as the hip and knee, arise developmentally as result of coordinated programs governing cartilage, connective tissue, and bone formation. The proposed research focuses on the role of individual cells in these complex developmental processes in the human hind limb, through the use of state-of-the-art technologies that will define the specific genetic processes cells utilize to give rise to functionally and morphologically distinct tissues and structures. Obtaining this molecular information is both timely and crucial to bridge the gaps in our knowledge of these important skeletal structures, and as such, a new resource will be made available to the scientific and medical communities to promote innovative solutions to orthopedic problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Early cannabis use is associated with later use of harder drugs like opioids in humans, and rodent studies have suggested that THC may cause changes in opioid addiction-relevant brain circuits that could underlie this association. Microglia, the brains’ immune cells, contribute significantly to brain development by influencing neural circuit remodeling and rewiring, and they respond to developmental insults like THC as well as to adulthood opioid drugs. Here we study the causal roles of microglia in long-lasting pro-opioid effects, help uncover novel microglial biology with relevance to addiction, and attain training in RNA sequencing and bioinformatics, writing, and career development positioning me well for a career in addiction neuroimmunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the impact of social determinants of health (SDoH) on the syndemic of hepatitis C virus (HCV), human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), and substance use disorders is crucial for improving HCV and HIV screening and the timely connection of affected individuals to care. Using natural language processing, we propose developing a polysocial risk score based on SDoH and integrating it into a targeted prediction tool to assist clinicians identify at-risk individuals more effectively. This innovative tool will enhance our comprehension of the syndemic and contribute to achieving HCV and HIV elimination goals in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a pressing public health concern that defies simple prediction: 90% of AD cases are sporadic, reflecting the significant contributions of environment and lifestyle to AD risk. In this context, development is a critical time for foundational structural and functional brain maturation that can bias a person toward or away from AD risk later in life. This project will investigate the relationship between environment and relational memory to better understand the consequences of modifiable environmental risk factors for AD in early life (F99 phase) and across the lifespan (K00 phase).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Human neurological diseases associated with monoaminergic (e.g., serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine) dysfunction affect millions of individuals worldwide; however, treatments for these neurodevelopmental, neurodegenerative and/or psychiatric disorders remain inadequate. Here, employing a truly unique combination of biochemical, molecular, and behavioral approaches, we are examining novel, neurotransmission independent roles for serotonin in brain in the direct regulation of neuronal gene expression. The experiments in this proposal will leverage cutting-edge technologies to understand how alterations in histone serotonylation (i.e., the covalent addition of serotonin to histone proteins) directly modulate neurodevelopmental and early life neural plasticity in a cell type specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The urgency to understand and treat disorders of cognition such as Alzheimer’s disease and Frontotemporal dementia continues to grow, yet we still don’t know the critical molecular events that underlie these diseases. During my dissertation work, I have developed an approach that has allowed me to identify the protein-binding partners of TDP43, a protein whose abnormal accumulation is found in many cognitive neurodegenerative diseases. In this proposal, I aim to use my discoveries to determine the mechanistic role TDP43 plays in synapses and why its function goes awry in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Different regions of the skin vary in their characteristics such as thickness, pigmentation, innervation, and presence, size and density of hair follicles and sweat glands, that are reflected in differential responses to injury and to diseases such as androgenetic alopecia and psoriasis that predominate in specific skin regions. We propose to identify novel mechanisms that establish and maintain skin heterogeneity. Improved understanding of these mechanisms has potential to reveal new therapeutic targets for diseases that affect specific skin regions and have a major negative impact on quality of life; data obtained in this project will also inform strategies for generating specific skin types, including hair follicle- and sweat gland-bearing skin, for reparative skin grafting.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquito-borne diseases are a global concern that impact public health, tourism, and natural disaster recovery efforts. With no preventative vaccines or effective therapeutic option available for most mosquito-borne diseases, vector control efforts are the only combative option; however, these efforts are often limited by financial constraint and insecticide resistance concern. This proposed project aims to integrate cutting-edge mosquito collection traps, and novel remote sensing and machine learning workflows to guide local vector operations and direct abatement efforts in a cost-efficient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease is a currently incurable brain disease. Brain entropy is an important trait of brain function and may provide critical information for unveiling neuromechanisms of complex disorders like AD. Using large existing data, this project will examine brain entropy change in AD and to assess brain entropy as a potential biomarker for AD. Given our aging population and the increasing prevalence of AD, performing this project is likely to have significant public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This project introduces and investigates the scientific premise that age-related reductions in walking performance and economy have been mistakenly attributed solely to muscles spanning the ankle, and instead originate interdependently with unfavorable changes in the active, passive, and structural regulation of foot stiffness and power. Accordingly, the translational purpose of this proposal is to test the efficacy of shoe stiffness modifications to augment foot structure and function in aging and thereby improve gait performance and reduce metabolic energy cost during walking in older adults. Ultimately, this project addresses the need for new and modifiable targets to enhance mobility and independence – paving the way for feasible and cost-effective assistive devices for millions in our aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Skeletal muscle wasting during cancer cachexia has been long deemed to be a mere reflection of overall body degradation. Challenging this assumption, we generated a mouse model that phenocopied cancer cachexia from within the skeletal muscle by impairing ribosome biogenesis, the synthesis of new ribosomes, specifically in skeletal muscle. This proposal seeks to determine the etiology of cancer cachexia by interrogating this intrinsic mechanism in skeletal muscle that leads to muscle wasting and cachectic phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative This is a multidisciplinary, highly collaborative consortium that combines next--generation sequencing with state- -of-the-art behavioral screening in a unique, genetically diverse, nonhuman animal model. The goals of this consortium are to identify gene variants that are associated with compulsive-like cocaine intake and behavioral endophenotypes using genome--wide association studies (GWAS) in behaviorally characterized heterogeneous stock rats, and to strengthen the infrastructure of a newly created data/tissue repository (Cocaine Biobank) accessible to all researchers to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms related to cocaine use disorder. Results from these studies have the potential to have a sustained and powerful impact on the field of addiction because they will identify novel druggable targets, provide a comprehensive analysis of cocaine addiction-like behaviors in males and females, and increase the impact of a unique data/tissue repository that will facilitate follow--up and replication studies.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE The equipment from this project will enhance the NDSU VDL’s next-generation sequencing (NGS) capacity to support One Health and antimicrobial stewardship by implementing an easy to use, low-throughput digital microfluidics NGS library preparation system (MIRO CANVAS) that can be deployed outside the laboratory with a ‘portable’ sequencer and minimal equipment for pathogen detection, discovery, and identification. Due to the time and costs associated with NGS, it is not uncommon to save and batch samples for sequencing to justify the time and consumable costs; however, this is not ideal when timing is important for treatment of a sick animal or in the case of emerging pathogens or outbreaks. The walk-away use, low-throughput capacity, and portability make the MIRO CANVAS a very useful tool that will allow the NDSU VDL to quickly prepare and sequence pathogens of One Health importance such as Salmonella in addition to other pathogens and zoonoses that may also enhance antimicrobial stewardship through detection and monitoring of antimicrobial resistance genes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Building next-generation sequencing (NGS) capacity for One Health and antimicrobial stewardship projects An on-going case study of multidrug-resistant Salmonella in zoo mammals

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: FDA CVM Vet-LIRN PROGRAM PROPOSAL  FOR FOA PAR-23-202 “FDA Vet-LIRN Network Capacity-Building Project and Equipment Grants” NARRATIVE This Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN) capacity building project strengthens the capacity, collaboration, and integration of food-safety laboratories and networks, thereby facilitating an effective and coordinated response to future human and animal food safety issues. The Vet-LIRN at the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Animal Diseases Diagnostic Laboratory at the Ohio Department of Agriculture (Ohio ADDL) will collaborate to perform whole genome sequencing (WGS) of foodborne pathogen isolates. This project will support the identification and adoption of emerging technologies and the harmonization of analytical methods used by equipment platforms for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) studies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: FDA Vet-LIRN Cooperative Agreement with Ohio ADDL to support projects and work associated with One Health, animal food issues, antimicrobial resistance, and surge capacity testing.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE The FDA Scientific Conference Grant Program will allow Critical Path Institute (C-Path) to host the “C-Path Global Impact Conference,” an interdisciplinary conference that will capitalize on strong existing collaborations between C-Path and its diverse group of stakeholders, including regulatory agencies (FDA, EMA, PDMA), pharmaceutical industry, academic researchers, non-profit organizations, and patient groups. Topics will focus on the current and future impact of C-Path’s core competencies in data management/science, model informed drug development and analytics, clinical outcome assessments, and biomarkers and how they are applied towards the fields of pediatrics, neurology, and rare and orphan disease. Specific sessions (e.g., regenerative medicine, patient focused drug development (PFDD), and model informed drug development (MIDD) will explain how C-Path can facilitate collaborations in drug development – sharing ideas, expertise, resources, and data – to create drug development tools that can help ameliorate some of the challenges with advancing medical products for underserved populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: C-Path Global Impact Conference

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will quantify the extent to which certain characteristics of educational tools can increase veterinarians' intention to follow antimicrobial stewardship guidelines and their confidence in their own efficacy to do so. We will explore whether a short educational video on antimicrobial stewardship or a summary of evidence-based guidance with accompanying citations can impact veterinarians' opinions on prescribing antibiotics for canine acute diarrhea and define characteristics of antimicrobial use resources that veterinarians identify as effective in changing their intention to reduce antimicrobial prescribing for canine acute diarrhea. We will use the Theory of Planned Behavior to quantify the knowledge, attitude, subjective norm (perceived social pressure regarding guidelines), and perceived behavioral control (perceived ability to follow the guideline) related to prescribing metronidazole for dogs with a common medical condition (i.e., acute diarrhea).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of Antimicrobial Stewardship Resources on Companion Animal Veterinarians' Intention and Capability to Prescribe Fewer Antimicrobial Drugs

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Project Narrative The purpose of this proposal is to get support to purchase a ultra-fast automated nucleic acid extractor and a superfast real-time thermocycler to increase sample analyses for the FDA-Vet-LIRN in the event of an animal food related illnesses. This will provide enhanced capacity for FDA Vet-LIRN surveillance assignments and routine case investigation of food- borne illness in animals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Acquisition of two superfast equipment for molecular testing in UI VDL

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed Thiamine HPLC-FLD quantification method will fill a diagnostic gap in the laboratories of the FDA Vet-LIRN network by standardizing a method for accurate quantification of thiamine, thiamine pyrophosphate(diphosphate), and thiamine monophosphate in animal feeds, tissues, and blood. This standardized method will facilitate implementation at laboratories with HPLC-FLD testing abilities, improving the availability of monitoring pet feeds to provide early warnings for mis-formulations and create surge capacity in emergent cases that might require significant feed recalls. The extension of this method into tissues and blood will allow confirmation of thiamine deficiency in suspect cases, facilitating treatment of any affected animals and providing evidence for any necessary related feed recalls.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Validation of quantative method for thiamine detection in animal feed, tissue and plasma

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Testing for antimicrobial resistance in sick animals is needed to support the mission of FDA to protect public health. In 2017, FDA Vet-LIRN launched a surveillance initiative including whole genome sequencing as a key component for mitigating the lack of standardization in antibiotic susceptibility testing in their network. Sequencing methods are now standardized across six laboratories in the network, including at Cornell, and we are requesting support for these activities for the next five years.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Genomic surveillance for antimicrobial resistance in animals

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative EJH & Associates, LLC (dba Datastream Connexion) will continue to deploy a customized Laboratory services and Knowledge Management Portal utilizing the LABSuite, a GovCloud-based Software as a Service platform to optimize and improve the sharing of animal health and veterinary diagnostics information, laboratory capabilities, and research projects within the Vet-LIRN network. The methods utilized by the LABSuite tools will improve the capabilities and capacity of laboratories to investigate potential animal foodborne illness outbreaks or contamination events. This project will leverage the existing LABSuite platform, in particular the laboratory directory (Lab-DIR) and Proficiency Testing Results Capture system (PT Module) utilized by the Food Emergency Response Network (FERN) and the APHIS Laboratory Network portal, formerly called the National Animal Laboratory Network (NAHLN) portal.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Vet-LIRN Portal Continuation and Improvements

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE If successful, this project will allow for the rapid detection of multiple botulinum toxin serotypes in feed and animal samples, leading to an early diagnosis of botulism. Botulinum toxins are the most powerful bacterial toxins and are also among the most toxic substances yet identified; they pose a serious threat to animals and humans. Botulism in food animals can expose humans to the toxins via consumption of contaminated products such as milk.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Validation of Endopep-MS for qualitative detection of BoNT/A, /C, /CD, /D, and /DC in animal specimens and feed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resident-to-resident aggression (RRA) is a prevalent issue in long-term care with severe health consequences to residents, many of whom suffer from Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and are minority racial/ethnic backgrounds. We propose to comprehensively examine the role of race and ethnicity in RRA using already existing prospective prevalence data, in addition to collecting nursing home stakeholder input to improve understanding of the role of race/ethnicity in RRA to inform a novel staff education RRA intervention development. This proposal thus has the potential to reduce race/ethnicity-related RRA, strengthen workforce training by improving provider competency for resolving race and ethnicity-related aggression among residents, and benefit residents with ADRD from diverse racial/ethnic backgrounds who are at higher risk of RRA involvement due cognitive impairment related behavioral symptoms. The Project Narrative remains unchanged by this supplement.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop a method using High Performance Liquid Chromatography and Mass Spectroscopy (LC-MS) to detect the important cyanotoxin, microcystin-LS and related congeners, in fish tissue, animal tissue, and other food, feed, and diagnostic samples to assure food safety and improve veterinary diagnostic investigation of cyanobacterial poisoning cases. The LC-MS method will be used to assess an ELISA test-kit based screening method that was developed by Dr. Todd Miller at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, to quantitate microcystins in fish tissues. Once validated, these analytical methods will be made available to toxicology laboratories in the Vet-LIRN network as a tool for screening foods and feeds and for veterinary diagnostic investigations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development of analytical methods for detecting microcystins in fish tissue

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Everyday life relies on the flawless execution of motor skills that are acquired during development, yet much is left to be understood about how the motor system develops control of skilled behavior. This research proposal seeks to determine how the brain acquires highly precise patterns of activity to achieve high levels of robust motor function. Results from this proposal will engender new insights into the brain’s implementation of precise motor control, thereby representing a major step forward in our understanding of the nature of motor learning.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The objective of NASDA’s 2024 Annual Meeting is to provide information on current and emerging feed and food safety issues impacting agriculture and to build consensus among the states on regulatory approaches to these issues. The plenary speakers will give state regulators an opportunity to hear a national perspective on feed and food safety, enhancing attendees’ exposure beyond the current events they are dealing with in their respective states. NASDA members and staff work with FDA programs and leadership to ensure that consumers have a safe feed and food supply; 45 NASDA member agencies have cooperative agreements to implement the Produce Safety Rule; 47 state departments of agriculture have feed control authority, and over half of them are performing preventive controls inspections under the Food Safety and Modernization Act (FSMA); approximately 20 state departments of agriculture have manufactured food authority and cooperate with FDA in the administration of these laws. NASDA has collaborated with FDA on major outbreak announcements. Many NASDA member agencies also cooperate with FDA on food safety for milk and seafood. NASDA staff frequently posts FDA press releases in the weekly NASDA News e- newsletter and many NASDA members’ agencies link to FDA’s recall lists. NASDA staff also serve on the Executive Committee of the Produce Safety Alliance.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: 2024 NASDA Annual Meeting

PHR: Narrative The U.S. is in the midst of a psychostimulant epidemic. Drug-craving is a diagnostic criterion of Psychostimulant Use Disorder for which there exists no clinically effective intervention. This project examines augmented calcium/calmodulin-dependent kinase II (CaMKII) signaling within the prefrontal cortex as a core neuropathology driving drug-craving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ionotropic synapses are the specialized cell junctions that allow for chemical signals to be transmitted throughout the central nervous system; aberrations to synapse formation and development are defining features of numerous neuropsychiatric and neurodevelopmental conditions. This proposal aims to uncover the specific molecular mechanism by which the synaptic adhesion G-protein coupled receptor (aGPCR) Brain- specific angiogenesis inhibitor 2 (BAI2) facilitates synaptogenesis and synapse maturation across postnatal and adult development. Identifying and characterizing this molecular mechanism furthers our knowledge of synaptic development and may inform future pharmaceutical developments of aGPCR-mediated drugs.

PHR: Relevance to Public Health Due to its significant involvement in biological processes, chemotaxis contributes to disease progression in cancer and arthritis, while its impairment leads to anomalous tissue development or regeneration. IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARMS Project Narrative EJH & Associates, LLC (Datastream Connexion) propose to deploy and customize a Laboratory services and Knowledge Management Portal utilizing the LABSuite, a GovCloud-based Software as a Service platform to optimize and improve the sharing of animal health, veterinary diagnostics, human health and retail food information, laboratory capabilities, along with research projects within the NARMS network. The methods utilized by the LABSuite tools will improve the capabilities and capacity of laboratories to investigate potential animal foodborne illness outbreaks or contamination events. This project in its first phase will leverage the existing LABSuite platform, in particular the laboratory directory (Lab-DIR) and Proficiency Testing Results Capture system (PT Module) utilized by the Food Emergency Response Network (FERN), the APHIS Laboratory Network portal, formerly called the National Animal Laboratory Network (NAHLN) portal, and Vet-LIRN.

PROJECT_TITLE: NARMS Laboratory Portal

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative APOE4 is the major genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), however we do not fully understand how APOE4-driven endolysosomal trafficking defects influence disease risk in human AD brain cells. The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms of APOE4 lipid-endolysosomal trafficking defect in human astrocytes and identify targets that can reverse the phenotype. Human iPSC-based model application and the knowledge gained from this proposal will be essential to the development of novel AD therapeutic modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative: The erythropoietic and prothrombotic effects of Erythropoietin in anemic patients implicates the Megakaryocytic- Erythroid progenitor as a direct target, and a useful model to explore mechanisms that uncouple the production of erythroid and platelet-producing megakaryocytic cells. This application describes a small, discrete, well-defined project to identify candidate proteins and target genes that propagate phenotypic and functional changes downstream of Erythropoietin signaling in human hematopoietic progenitors destined to give rise to erythrocytes and platelets. Results from the proposed studies will improve our understanding of the mechanisms of action of Erythropoietin in human bone marrow leading to advancements in treatments for anemia, and will support the lab during transition to independence by generating preliminary data for a future R01 application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuropathic pain is a debilitating form of chronic pain afflicting millions of patients worldwide but is poorly responsive to current analgesic therapies. Recent preclinical behavioral data implicates the lateral parabrachial nucleus of the brainstem in the maintenance of both the behavioral reflexive and affective components of neuropathic pain. This study uses in vivo and awake moving fiber photometry and in situ fluorescent hybridization, intraparabrachial pharmacology and chemogenetics, and anatomical tracing combined with efferent terminal chemogenetic inhibition to ultimately determine if excitatory lateral parabrachial neurons (those that contain the type 1 receptor for neuropeptide Y) contribute to the behavioral manifestations of neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This project is aimed at understanding the structure and function of a large number of helical protein and nucleoprotein filaments, ranging from actin in human muscle to helical viruses that infect organisms living in nearly boiling acid. Some of the studies are likely to have a direct and immediate impact on human health, such as those involving the bacteria responsible for meningitis and food poisoning, while others will have longer range impact including new tools for biotechnology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE iGL-VRC01 B cells from KI mice will be activated in vitro and adoptively transferred into WT animals to generate higher than normal frequencies of antigen speciﬁc memory B cells with different important memory phenotypes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is often accompanied by cognitive deficits and is also the major risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). This multi-component research program studies a rodent model of naturally occurring variation in cognitive aging, with the goal of understanding the neurobiological basis of impairment and preservation of brain function that could contribute to vulnerability and resilience, respectively, in AD. Building on existing therapeutic progress, work within this program will continue to contribute to the development of effective therapeutic interventions for cognitive decline in aging with potential for slowing late-onset AD progression in its earliest phases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Arrhythmogenic cardiovascular disease and sudden cardiac death disproportionately affect VA patients with acquired cardiovascular disease, such as heart failure. Nationally, there are more than 350,000 VA patients who carry the diagnosis of heart failure. In the St. Louis VA system alone, over 3,000 patients have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and an equal, if not greater, number of patients have heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. Following hospitalization, VA heart failure patients have a 22% chance of being re-admitted for worsening heart failure and 9% chance of dying within 30 days. It is increasingly recognized that the paucity of electrophysiological studies on the human heart has been a persistent barrier to advances in heart failure diagnosis and treatment. Here, we propose a powerful experimental strategy to identify the electrophysiological signature and the molecular determinants of human heart failure-related arrhythmogenic cardiovascular disease, information that will reveal new targets to treat heart failure and new strategies to prevent sudden death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative My studies will provide a more detailed understanding of a signaling pathway regulating atrial fibrosis in atrial fibrillation development. In the long term, I aim to apply my findings as a candidate for a novel gene therapy approach to reduce atrial fibrosis in atrial fibrillation. Since atrial fibrillation is an increasingly prevalent disease with excessive atrial fibrosis being a common driver, my studies could enable a more targeted and definitive treatment for atrial fibrillation that would improve the quantity and quality of life for millions of patients in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Gastric parietal cell dysfunction underlies a wide range of human diseases associated with a high socioeconomic burden including chronic gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and cancer. Given the essential role for parietal cells in maintaining a healthy stomach, it is surprising that a comprehensive understanding how the program regulating and maintaining normal parietal cell development and function, and thereby parietal cell health and overall gastric epithelial cell health, is incomplete. This study will investigate the role of the transcription factor GATA4 in fundamental aspects of parietal cell function with the goal of applying findings to gastric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a progressive, chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation and pain of the joints that afflicts up to as much as 1% of the U.S. population1, 2. This project aims to develop a novel L. lactis synthetic biology medicine programmed to express and deliver colonization factor antigen I (CFA/I) to induce T regulatory cells for the treatment of RA. Successful commercialization would ultimately provide a profound front-line medical advancement in the treatment of RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this grant cycle, we test whether right and left hemisphere temporal regions have different roles in processing the sounds of speech, examining neuroimaging and TMS data from typical controls and behavioral data from individuals with left and right temporal lobe lesions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  As a physician-scientist with demonstrated commitment to understanding the mechanistic underpinnings of right heart failure, I will collaborate with Dr. Felipe Kazmirczak to establish and characterize a novel porcine model of severe tricuspid regurgitation. In Aim 1, we will define how a newly-developed porcine model of severe tricuspid regurgitation alters right heart structure and function using cardiac MRI. In Aim 2, we will perform a multi-omic analysis to define how severe tricuspid regurgitation alters right atrial and right ventricular biology, and then compare these effects to right ventricular pressure overload using specimens collected from our parent R01.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Bone fractures in type 2 diabetes cannot be accurately predicted by current bone density-based clinical tools as T2D patients exhibit normal to high bone mineral density. This project will establish Carboxymethyl-lysine (CML) as a new biomarker of T2D fracture and determine how the oxidation and glycation processes, associated with diabetes under obese and non-obese conditions, impact accumulation of CML and other Advanced Glycation Endproducts (AGEs) and enhance bone fragility. The results will provide new strategies to diagnose, treat and mitigate T2D and fragility fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The highest risk groups for problems stemming from opioid use disorder are (1) public system-involved emerging adults (ages 16-25) and (2) individuals who are justice-involved (including emerging adults). Peer recovery support services and recovery residences are proliferating nationally and may have tremendous benefit for these two high-risk groups, but research on them is limited and lacks scientific rigor. This Initiative is a partnership between advanced researchers, persons in recovery, providers, and payors, with the aim of advancing research on the efficacy/effectiveness of recovery support services for this critical public health issue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As adults with type 2 diabetes age, they are increasingly vulnerable to treatment-related hypoglycemia and its related complications (including hospitalization and death). We propose to evaluate, in a randomized clinical trial, a strategy of expanded advance care planning (ACP) to support older adults in value-aligned re- assessment of T2D treatment regimens with their primary care team. If the aims of this project are achieved and incidence of clinically-significant hypoglycemia is reduced, this expanded ACP care strategy could be scaled and applied in a wide variety of healthcare settings and chronic conditions in which evolving risks, benefits, and consequences of treatment require re-assessment with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This three-arm individual randomized controlled effectiveness trial aims to reduce childhood obesity disparities in children ages 5-8 (n=510) from low income and diverse households by increasing family meal quality (i.e., diet quality, interpersonal atmosphere) and quantity (i.e., family meal frequency). Innovative methodology (e.g., ecological momentary assessment (EMI), video feedback) will be used in partnership with primary care clinics and Community Health Workers to test three arms: (1) EMI; (2) EMI+Home Visiting (HV); and (3) EMI+HV+ Video Feedback. Findings will result in a new model for childhood obesity treatment in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall project goal is to address the critical need for self-care strategies to improve the physical and psychological health of older family care partners caring for patients with heart failure. This proposed study is relevant to public health because older family care partners often experience high caregiving burden that results in physical function decline, psychological distress, sleep disturbance, and poor health status. Implementation of this project's tailored physical activity coaching program, which uses integrated digital health technologies, will have the potential to support self-management and enhance the health and well-being of aging family care partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 08 Project Narrative The coordinated firing of millions of neurons in the human brain gives rise to the diverse set of experiences, emotions, thoughts, and sensations that make up the human condition. Despite the central importance of neuronal physiology to human health and disease, our understanding of this complex field remains incomplete due to a lack of tools that can reliably report on membrane potential. This proposed research will develop and apply new optical tools to study neuronal membrane potential in cells and in circuits.

PHR: Project Narrative The Forum convenes approximately 2-3 times a year for Forum member meetings. During the course of Forum discussions the need for more in-depth and detailed discussions on specific topics is likely to emerge. In order to appropriately address these topics, the Forum may sponsor a workshop on topics developed by the Forum membership. In selecting workshop topics, the Forum considers the timeliness of the issues, the amount of information already available on the topic, and whether or not the Forum can offer additional information or breadth of perspectives that would be useful to the discussion on the topic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative During cell division, each daughter cell must inherit exactly one copy of each chromosome as errors can lead to cancer and birth defects. Two large cellular machines are responsible for segregating chromosomes: the spindle and kinetochore. Here we probe how these machines’ building blocks together give rise to their function, aiming to uncover the mechanical design principles driving chromosome segregation and to ultimately better target dividing cells for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Radiation metabolomics is a well-established field in biomarker discovery and in assessing changes associated with metabolic perturbations, whether in tissues or biofluids. We have developed a rich database of radiation biomarkers in urine, blood, and saliva and we now plan to develop multiplex assays that are highly quantitative and can serve as the first step towards a deployable assay using commercially based instruments. Additionally, we will further develop membrane-based technologies that will aim to eliminate the pre-processing steps, thereby jump-starting the sample processing step and enrichment for specific classes of metabolites and stabilizing the biosignature during transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our work focuses on how signaling networks generate complex cellular behaviors such as cell movement and immune cell activation. The ability to control cell migration would be a valuable tool for combating atherosclerosis, inflammation, metastasis, and other pathological processes that occur upon the disruption of cellular guidance mechanisms. Our work on the mechanism of immune cell activation will directly impact our understanding of autoimmune disease, vaccine development, and immunotherapy-based cancer treatments.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Current standard of care imaging (contrast-enhanced MRI) is limited to detect many neurological and neurodegenerative diseases and spectroscopic MRI has a great potential to supplement routine clinical MRI for clinical conditions including brain neoplasms, neonatal and pediatric disorders (hypoxia-ischemia, inherited metabolic diseases, and traumatic brain injury), demyelinating diseases, and infectious brain lesions. This project will improve whole brain coverage and reliability of Spectroscopic MRI, which will be quantitatively assessed in collaboration sites. Successful completion of this study will produce new generation tools needed for broader applications of spectroscopic MRI in patient management with various neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative (Parent Cyber GEMS study, R01DK124427) Given the known serious consequences of uncontrolled blood sugars during hospitalization, this research proposes an alternative seamlessly integrates continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) in the hospital to test a dynamic and digitized, team-based approach to glucose management in an underserved and understudied, yet high-risk population. The Digital Dashboard is progressive, as it facilitates real-time, remote monitoring of a large volume of patients simultaneously; automatically identifies and prioritizes patients for intervention; and will detect any and all potentially dangerous hypoglycemic episodes in a hospital environment. Finally, our focus on clinical metrics (glucose control, infection) that are in-line with patient priorities and US hospital quality initiatives will increase relevance to healthcare systems and enhance incentive to adopt Cyber GEMS.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Veterans smoke cigarettes at higher rates than the general population, yet most Veterans in VHA care report low motivation to quit. Motivational interviewing (MI) is most commonly used for unmotivated smokers, but data suggests health education (HE) may also help unmotivated smokers. Client language can provide insights into therapeutic techniques associated with behavior change. To elucidate this issue, mixed methods will be used to code and analyze 102 MI and 102 HE sessions from a large community RCT to examine the relationship between key aspects of client language, including statements reflecting plans to change (“change talk”) and evidence of client learning (“learning talk”), and 3- and 6-month treatment outcomes. We will also code and analyze 15 MI and 15 HE sessions from a VHA RCT that included a sample of unmotivated Veteran smokers with mental illness to assess for proportion of CT, LT, and other aspects of client language. Results will be used to combine MI and HE techniques to develop a brief intervention for unmotivated Veteran smokers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The goal of this study is to develop innovative econometric methods for measuring the value of greater provider options from the perspective of Veterans. The proposed study is timely and policy relevant in light of the Commission on Care’s top long-term recommendation for transforming VHA through the establishment of community care networks for Veterans to access high quality care. Findings from this study will help inform VA’s rapidly evolving role as a payer. Specifically, the development of value measures and the identification of provider attributes that most greatly increase value to Veterans will help VA assess the adequacy of community care networks and select contract providers to most effectively meet Veterans’ health care needs. The strategic selection of high quality provider options available through the Veterans Choice Program and future community care policies is of high interest to key operational partners including the Office of Community Care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Poor muscle recovery following disuse is frequent amongst older adults leading to low muscle mass, weakness and increased disability. We have proposed to test specific mechanisms of a disrupted macrophage metabolic state during recovery from disuse in aged mice and humans. These findings will produce new knowledge of macrophage metabolism that will aid in the development of therapeutic strategies to promote muscle recovery in aged individuals.
