IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Men who have sex with men (MSM), and gender minority individuals who have sex with men, living with HIV and substance use disorders (SUDs) are less likely to be virally suppressed, which can lead to HIV transmission and negative health outcomes. This hybrid type 1 study will assess the efficacy, mechanisms, as well as facilitators and barriers to implementing the MATTER intervention, a virtually delivered 5-session text- enhanced psychobehavioral intervention designed to facilitate viral suppression by addressing internalized stigma and shame as barriers to engagement in HIV care among MSM and gender minority individuals living with HIV and SUDs in two locations with different levels of HIV resources (i.e., the Boston, Massachusetts and Miami, Florida metro areas). MATTER aims to mitigate the negative behavioral consequences of internalized stigma and shame on viral suppression by a) developing behavioral self-care goal setting skills and related self-efficacy, b) increasing metacognitive awareness (i.e., non-judgmental awareness of emotions and cognitions), and c) teaching and reinforcing compassionate self-restructuring (i.e., self- compassion), in addition to providing access to phone-based resource navigation. Scalable interventions such as MATTER are essential to our efforts to end the HIV epidemic in high priority regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to understand how cells repair one type of DNA lesion, the double strand break (DSB). DSB repair is essential for a broad range of cellular processes from DNA replication to innate immunity, while dysregulated DNA repair is a hallmark of cancer and other human diseases. Research described in this proposal will increase our understanding of a fundamental biological process and may improve gene editing and chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Microsporidia are unicellular,  fungal  parasites with a wide host-range, from insects to humans;  they are emerging pathogens, classified as NIAID Category B opportunistic pathogens, and cause microsporidiosis in immunocompromised patients.  To gain entry into a target cell, microsporidia employ a remarkably unique and specialized harpoon-like invasion machine called the polar tube, which is conserved among microsporidial species. Here we will focus on understanding the mechanism by which microsporidial parasites use this unique organelle to initiate infection, which may provide broader insights into infection mechanisms used by other eukaryotic parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Currently, there are no accurate nonanimal tests to identify consumer products and chemicals that require labeling to advise users to wear protective eyewear and avoid eye contact due to the threat of serious eye damage. The purpose of this application is to further develop and commercialize a new nonanimal test — the in vitro depth of injury eye irritation test (IVD EIT) — to identify this class of ocular irritants and thereby allow for adequate labeling that will advise and inform users about product safety as well as comply with new laws preventing or limiting the use of animals that have been historically used for this type of routine safety testing. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive deficits that occur with aging are a pervasive concern to older individuals and a growing public health issue and maintaining or improving cognition in older adults could have an important effect at the population level, potentially delaying the onset of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias in millions of older adults. The goals of the proposed research are to first determine the minimal and/or optimal dose of a meditation-inspired digital intervention required for cognitive enhancement, and then to examine the impact of several potential moderators of treatment effects (i.e., cognitive decline, AD polygenic hazard score, cardiovascular risk, and race/ethnicity). This knowledge gained from his high-impact study with transform the field of cognitive interventions, paving the way for a precision medicine model for cognitive enhancing interventions that improve quality of life for older adults and individuals with cognitive deficits at risk of developing dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Use of tobacco products is a strong predictor of nonmedical use of prescribed opiates, development of opiate dependence, and susceptibility to accidental opiate overdose. Nicotine use results in insular cortex dysfunction which is further associated with development of substance use disorders. Elucidation of the mechanisms through which nicotine, acting within the insular cortex, may enhance opiate addiction liability is critical for development of treatment strategies aimed at the large proportion of nicotine and opiate polysubstance users currently involved in opiate treatment programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Pregnant women and children are exposed to a mixture of chemicals. We will investigate the impact of prenatal and postnatal exposures to chemical mixtures on child cognition, attention/executive function, externalizing and internalizing behaviors, and brain imaging. We will use two well-characterized birth cohort studies in the U.S. and Canada to identify the impact of a single chemical, interactions between chemicals, and joint effect of multiple chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to conduct the first longitudinal convergent mixed-methods study to quantify and elucidate the impact of water insecurity (WI) on HIV related to climate-related drivers, infrastructure challenges, water accessibility, and heightened risk of water-borne diseases, to inform interventions to address WI among people living with HIV (PLWH). We will utilize innovative remote sensing technologies to estimate the effect of climate- related factors on WI and then measure the impact of WI on HIV health outcomes, including viral load suppression and adherence to antiretroviral treatment. Findings from this study will provide initial data on the drivers of and sequelae of WI and their impact on HIV treatment outcomes, to identify and prioritize intervention options to address WI among PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Telomere maintenance is essential for genome stability and the prevention of cancer and degenerative diseases. The proposed research will examine how environmental genotoxic and oxidative stress cause accelerated telomere shortening, and the pathways that preserve damaged telomeres. This project will reveal how various forms of telomeric DNA damage impact telomere function, cellular function and organism health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Autoimmune diseases cause a large social burden on both the patients afflicted with the disease and their support systems. The Accelerated Medicine Partnerships in Autoimmune and Immune-Mediated Diseases (AMP AIM) is a consortium of Governmental, University, Biotech, and Non-profit institutions that will work to assemble an unparalleled repository of samples and data from biopsy tissues using advanced technologies and analysis approaches of samples from four autoimmune diseases: System Lupus Erythematosus (or “Lupus”), Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA), Sjogren’s Syndrome (SjD), and Psoriatic Spectrum of Disease (Psoriasis, PsD). The Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation’s Tissue Research Core (OMRF TRC) proposes to provide the Network with 1) standard methods, 2) centralized sample storage/management, 3) centralized testing, 4) collection of tissue pathology data, and 5) data systems to organize all data through its existing staff and infrastructure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Frequently the more severe a person's motor impairment, the less able they are to operate the very assistive machines, like powered wheelchairs and robotic arms, which might enhance their quality of life. The purpose of the proposed study is to provide people with tetraplegia with the means, through non-invasive technologies, to control robotic arms with their available body mobility, while concurrently promoting the exercise of available body motions and the maintenance of physical health. We propose and study an approach that leverages robot machine learning and autonomy in order to facilitate human motor learning of how to operate a robotic arm using a customized interface, in order to make powered assisted manipulation more accessible to people with severe paralysis. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This longitudinal observational study examines multiple levels of Structural Racism and Discrimination (SRD) including individual (both intrapersonal and interpersonal), neighborhood, institutional, and societal/policy and their associations with mental, physical, and behavioral health outcomes across the life course. Innovative mixed-methods (e.g., ecological momentary assessment, geographic information system data, community- based participatory approaches, biomarkers) are being used at two sites (Minnesota, Georgia), across two time points 18 months apart, with families from racially/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse households (n=927). Study findings will identify targets for intervening at multiple SRD levels to promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This cohort consortium project provides the first comprehensive evaluation of exposure to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) with risk of liver cancer overall, by racial/ethnic groups, and by hepatitis B virus (HBV) and C virus infection (HCV) status. This research will generate new insights into the etiology of liver cancer and advance the field of liver cancer prevention and health disparities, thereby ultimately reducing morbidity and mortality from this deadly disease. Findings on PFAS and health effects will also provide novel information for regulatory agencies, policymakers, and practitioners to make science-based decisions and action plans to improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project we examine how interdisciplinary communication using text messaging can improve delivery of age-friendly care to nursing home (NH) residents and prevent avoidable NH-to-hospital transfer. This study will provide information needed for the development and testing of interventions using convenient, low-cost technologies, like text messaging, to ultimately reduce morbidity and mortality in residents with Alzheimer’s disease or a related dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black women in the United States have worse outcomes and higher mortality from breast and uterine cancer than any other racial/ethnic group. The UPMC Hillman Cancer Center has assembled a multidisciplinary team with expertise in cancer health disparities, epidemiology, environmental health, and basic science to conduct a preliminary evaluation of whether environmental and social determinants of health modify risk of chemical beauty products in the development of breast and uterine cancer among Black women.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Heart failure is the number reason for admission among patients in the Veteran (VA) health system without cure, consuming a significant portion of VA medical resources. This proposal is to test a hypothesis that targeting UCH-L1, a deubiquitinating enzyme, is a novel approach for the treatment of heart failure and circulating UCH-L1 serves as novel biomarker of heart failure. The outcome will pave the way for translational studies of targeting UCH-L1 to treat and manage cardiac disease and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a leading cause of mortality/morbidity, and there is no FDA-approved therapy for any stage of ALD. Unfortunately, patients with ALD rarely have their underlying alcohol use disorder (AUD) concomitantly addressed. This consortium links health care providers with expertise in AUD and ALD in a unified treatment strategy to evaluate novel combined treatments for AUD/ALD in patients with advanced ALD. The existing resources of the NIAAA-funded AlcHepNet are used for patient studies, biospecimen collection and site-specific translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because opioid use is prevalent in the United States and the human and financial costs associated with tolerance and withdrawal are at crisis levels. The relationship between altered adenylyl cyclase signaling and potassium channels present an opportunity to develop intriguing candidates target to prevent opioid-induced tolerance and withdrawal. This proposal is relevant to the part of NIDA’s mission that pertains to conducting basic research on drug use, its consequences, and the underlying neurobiological mechanisms involved in long-term use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This NIH Diversity Supplement will provide a clinical research experience with related training for the candidate with a doctorate in occupational therapy to become involved in the funded non-inferiority trial (BeST-AID) of telerehabilitation versus in-office care for low vision magnification devices. Specifically, we will evaluate how enhanced intervention approaches (habit training and motivational interviewing administered by the candidate) in both telerehabilitation and in-office settings impact BeST-AID participants’ acceptability and increased utilization of visual aids. Additionally, we aim to develop, implement and evaluate a training protocol specifically for visually impaired patients to improve their ability to independently access electronic health records and healthcare resources through Epic patient portals at ophthalmologic academic centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Persistent inflammation is a venomous biological process - it can initiate or worsen human pathologies of all organ systems. The purpose of this study is to delineate the mechanisms behind rare monogenic causes of inflammatory syndromes featured around the JAK-STAT pathway. Improved understanding of innate immune regulation in these patients will ultimately inform the design of anti-inflammatory therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HSV-2 is a sexually-transmitted infectious (STI) agent that is responsible for painful genetical blisters in approximately 15% of the population: 40-80 million people globally are estimated to suffer from recurrent symptomatic genital infections. The virus can be transmitted to neonates during birth where encephalitis can result in long-term neurologic deficits and disseminated infections are life threatening. The goal of these studies is to develop an HSV-2 non-neuroinvasive live-attenuated vaccine based on our established R2 technology. The vaccine will be tested for safety, immunogenicity, and efficacy in preparation for clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The lifetime prevalence of voice problems in teachers is considerably higher (in some reports as high as 94%) than in the average occupation and negatively impacts children's learning in the classroom. The current research provides further insight into how internal and external risk factors (including classroom vocal demands) are associated with the vocal accommodations that teachers make. Additionally, this research investigates the economic impact of current and potential policies (or lack thereof) used to address voice problems and/or improve vocal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is a deadly cancer, and there is an urgent need for rapid treatment response monitoring so that patients can be spared the significant toxicities of ineffective drugs and can instead be offered alternative regimens with a higher chance of efficacy. In this project, we will combine circulating tumor DNA and metabolic imaging to improve the timely assessment of the clinical utility of therapies in PDA, with the overarching goal of lengthening survival in PDA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the Center for Innovative NeuroTech Advancement (CINTA) is to rapidly transform emerging technologies into commercially viable, clinically focused solutions for disorders of the nervous system as a hub under the NIH Blueprint MedTech: Incubator Hubs program. CINTA will support the advancement of neurotechnology solutions by adapting and improving upon the proven model that CIMIT developed and implemented for RADx Tech to accelerate promising neurotechnologies that address critical areas of unmet needs in the diagnosis and treatment of nervous system disorders to human-grade prototypes. CINTA plans to find, fund, facilitate, and accelerate 15 projects per year through this program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is one of the major global health problems afflicting about 229 million people and causing over 400,000 deaths annually. Because of the emergence of drug resistance parasites, current therapies for malaria are rapidly losing their efficacy. The proposed research seeks to identify novel antimalarial lead compounds targeting parasite protein kinases effective against multidrug resistant malaria with therapeutic and prophylactic properties, thus contributing to the global malaria elimination campaign.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Practice-based improvements in our ability to detect or discriminate subtle sound features – a process known as perceptual learning – is important for the development of speech and language, and for maximizing the benefits of hearing aids and cochlear implants. While non-sensory factors, such as attentional state or delivery of reward, are known to shape perceptual learning, we lack a comprehensive understanding of the neural mechanisms involved. The experiments proposed here will address this issue by assessing the contribution of one non-sensory brain region, the orbitofrontal cortex, and its descending projection to the auditory cortex to perceptual learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The World Health Organization in 2014 reported that alcohol contributed to more than 200 diseases and injury- related health conditions, including Alcohol Use Disorder, liver cirrhosis and cancer. Alcohol misuse is the third leading preventable cause of death in the United States and generates a significant economic burden. Lohocla Research Corporation has developed a novel therapeutic, called Nezavist, to reduce heavy alcohol consumption, including consumption by dependent individuals, and has completed nearly all nonclinical studies required to proceed to human clinical trials. The goal of this application is to complete and submit an Investigational New Drug (IND) application to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and, upon approval, to perform the first-in-human clinical trials of safety and tolerability of Nezavist in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a leading cause of mortality/morbidity, and there is no FDA-approved therapy for any stage of ALD. Unfortunately, patients with ALD rarely have their underlying alcohol use disorder (AUD) concomitantly addressed. This consortium links health care providers with expertise in AUD and ALD in a unified treatment strategy to evaluate novel combined treatments for AUD/ALD in patients with advanced ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Abnormal white patches of tissue in the mouth, or leukoplakias, are common and may become cancerous over time. This project aims to understand what events make these patches arise, and if we can predict which ones might go on to become cancer. This will permit us better select which people need treatment, as well as possible treatment strategies for these white patches.

PHR: Project Narrative The Integrated Therapies for Alcohol use in Alcohol-associated Liver Disease (ITAALD) network, comprised of six leading partner institutions in the field, will examine novel treatments for advanced alcohol-associated liver disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There are currently no effective treatments for tauopathies, such as Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). Uptake and spreading of pathogenic tau is recognized as a key driver of AD pathology, and is primarily mediated by tau's interaction with the cellular receptor LRP1. Molecular dissection of the tau-LRP1 interaction will enable us to devise new therapies for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Over 1.7 million people suffer from limb loss in the United States and this number is estimated to increase by 185,000 per year for upper extremity loss. Sophisticated limb robotic limb prosthetics have increased dramatically the intuitive control, but evoking a naturalistic sensation from the engineered sensors in the bionic limb to the amputee users, remain a formidable challenge. We propose to develop a highly selectivity regenerative peripheral nerve interface that uses small electrodes, and molecularly guided motor and sensory subtype axonal defasciculation to improve neural interfacing of amputated nerves.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a leading contributor to mental, physical and cognitive disability, and preventable death in the US, particularly in those 40 years old and older. The Collaborative Study on the Genetics of Alcoholism (COGA) is a tightly integrated and interdisciplinary project, whose overarching goals are to understand the contributions and interactions of genetic, neurobiological, behavioral and social-environmental factors on risk and resilience over the developmental course of AUD, including remission and recurrence; the three COGA projects (Lifespan, Brain Function, and Genomics), supported by three cores (Administrative, Data Management Coordination and NIAAA/COGA Sharing Repository) aim to address the public health challenge of AUD by integrating findings across multiple domains of research. Combining our multidisciplinary expertise with our single mission, COGA can traverse the path from genes to brain to behavior across the lifespan and lay the foundation for precision medicine efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced age is the greatest risk factor for the onset and progression of Alzheimer's disease. We are using the powerful genetics of the fruit fly Drosophila to better understand the biological mechanisms of aging. The long-term goal of this research is to provide novel therapeutic targets to counteract age-related human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease.

The project’s purpose will be accomplished through supplemental work on an existing funded grant. The supplement aims to increase participation of the United States (US) Latinx community in clinical trials for neurodevelopmental disorders. The proposed project has broad public health relevance because it will improve access of US Latinx families to clinical research interventions. Data from this project will inform approaches to enhance research participation in neurodevelopmental disorder related clinical trials among the Latinx community, which is well aligned with the NICHD’s mission.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microplastics, tiny plastic particles that are a source of widespread environmental contamination, may contribute to adverse health conditions in humans, including colorectal cancer. In this project, we will measure the presence and level of microplastics in human stool and colorectal tumor tissue samples to compare the burden of microplastic contamination by colorectal cancer history and by age at colorectal cancer diagnosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Heterotopic ossification (HO) is the pathologic formation of extra-skeletal bone that forms almost exclusively at sites of mechanical stress. We purport that discoidin domain receptor 2 (DDR2) and injury site immobilization modify extra-cellular matrix alignment and thus changes cell fate through downstream mechanotransductive signaling. Determination of the underlying mechanisms responsible for HO will enable us to validate clinically relevant mobilization protocols and mechanotransductive therapies to combat this currently untreatable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will examine midlife women's relationships and support exchanges with their late adolescent and adult children, as well as with other kin and non-kin, and the implications of these relationships and exchanges for women's psychosocial well-being. The experienced bi-national team will collect and analyze survey and in-depth interview data building upon an existing longitudinal panel of women in rural Mozambique, a setting that in many respects is typical of sub-Saharan Africa. The results of this study will fill important gaps in our understanding of intergenerational and community relationship dynamics and their consequences for women's welfare in rapidly changing resource-limited patriarchal contexts and will inform policies aimed at improving health and well-being of rural women and at optimizing health and social services for that vulnerable population segment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Family health history (FHH), a critical component of genomic medicine that is essential for both identifying individuals at risk for hereditary conditions and for contextualizing results of genetic testing, continues to be broadly underutilized and underappreciated in clinical care. Barriers to adequate data collection and synthesis are numerous and cross all clinical stakeholders: patients, providers, and health systems. Significantly, they include the pervasive view that FHH is unimportant except in select cases and that it rarely contributes to clinical decision making. With this perspective, few providers have been willing to allocate precious time to collect detailed FHHs or to learn the complex algorithms required to synthesize FHH data into actionable care plans. However, in studies of systematic FHH-based risk assessments in unselected populations, 25% of patients meet risk criteria for (actionable) hereditary conditions. FHH-based risk assessment programs have emerged to address these barriers, but as designed do not meet the needs of low literacy, low resource populations. The goal of this proposal is to develop a scalable end-to-end solution for risk assessment and management that meets the needs of low resource settings. Our central hypothesis is that combining FHH- driven risk assessment, a literacy-enhanced interface using voice-to-text response capture (like ‘Siri’), family engagement (through social networking platforms for data gather and risk sharing), and a genetic testing delivery system, will create a solution that engages and increases the proportion of diverse patients who are identified as at increased risk, who undergo testing, and, when appropriate, who initiate cascade screening among relatives. In this proposal we will define and deploy this new care delivery model as the “Genomic medicine Risk Assessment Care for Everyone” (GRACE). To this end we will 1) develop and deploy the model using pre-implementation assessments at clinical sites with highly diverse patient populations to select the most appropriate integration options and pathways for both patients and providers; and 2) perform a randomized implementation-effectiveness pragmatic hybrid trial to assess implementation and effectiveness outcomes relevant to these diverse populations. Outcomes will include reach, uptake, clinical utility, accessibility, genetic testing frequency, genetic testing results, and cost-effectiveness. In addition we will convene an advisory panel of stakeholders from industry (laboratories, insurers), providers, patients, and health system to understand sustainability and address knowledge gaps that will promote access when the trial is over.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In all life forms on earth, DNA carries the hereditary genetic information. Transcription copies DNA into RNA, a key process that permits gene expression. On occasion, the nascent RNA can become entangled with the DNA, resulting in an alternative three-stranded nucleic acid structure called an R-loop. R-loops form universally under normal conditions and are thought to play physiological roles in cells, including human cells. Studies have suggested, however, that under conditions where transcription is perturbed, harmful R-loops are created, leading to DNA breaks and chromosome anomalies. What distinguishes “good” from “harmful” R-loops remains unknown. Similarly, how harmful R-loops arise as a result of perturbed transcription is unclear. Using innovative technologies developed by my group, we will characterize the formation of so-called harmful R- loops under conditions of perturbed transcription in human cells. We will also determine whether harmful R- loops, or perturbed transcription itself, are the cause of the DNA breaks. Finally, we will determine if an enzyme known to relieve the DNA break problem is acting by resolving harmful R-loops or remediating the altered transcription. This work will benefit our understanding of fundamental cellular processes acting in our genome and will provide insights into a range of human disorders linked to perturbed transcription.

PHR: Project Narrative The membrane-interacting domains of class I viral fusion proteins, such as HIV-1 Env, appear to play much greater roles in its stability, function and antigenicity than what has been appreciated previously. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As opioid use disorder (OUD) and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection prevalence continue to rise in the United States, particularly among young women, new strategies are needed to identify high-impact venues to address both epidemics together. Pregnancy is a motivating time for women to engage in care for both their own health and that of their families. This project will utilize programmatic and public health data and simulation modeling to project the clinical and cost-effectiveness of employing interventions in the perinatal care venue to reduce opioid-related mortality and HCV transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a leading cause of mortality/morbidity, and there is no FDA-approved therapy for any stage of ALD. Unfortunately, patients with ALD rarely have their underlying alcohol use disorder (AUD) concomitantly addressed. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic low back pain (cLBP) affects over 10% of adults in the US, contributing to the burden of disability and health care costs, and putting those suffering from cLBP at risk of opioid addiction or even overdose. The National Institutes of Health is funding a patient-centric research program to discover new low back pain mechanisms and develop improved diagnostic and treatment algorithms through extensive patient phenotyping and use of precision medicine approaches. Our proposal is to provide network leadership and operations support, state-of-the-art data integration and analytics infrastructure, and bioinformatics and statistical expertise to support the research goals of the BACPAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psoriasis, a prevalent chronic inflammatory skin disease, is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D); however, the molecular mechanisms that predispose patients with psoriasis to develop T2D are unknown. We have identified that keratinocyte overexpression of interferon kappa (IFNκ), a type I IFN upregulated in psoriatic skin, is associated with impaired metabolic function and promotes increased inflammatory macrophages (MΦs) in skin and adipose tissue. This proposal will seek to elucidate how overexpression of IFNκ in psoriatic keratinocytes is regulated and how increased IFNκ produced by keratinocytes drives increased inflammatory MΦs in the skin and adipose tissue that leads to impaired adipocyte-mediated glycemic control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The swallowing muscles are prone to decreased strength and function as part of the natural aging process which can lead to difficulty swallowing, malnutrition, and frailty. Exercise and nutrition are powerful stimulators of muscular change. The proposed research will investigate the effectiveness of a proactive regimen of swallowing exercises (with or without daily protein supplement drinks) to improve the composition, force, and physiology of the swallowing muscles and explore the relationship to overall health and physical function in community-dwelling older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OF FUNDED PARENT AWARD (1R01DC020229)  (NO CHANGE)  There are over 200,000 individuals with Down syndrome in the United States, and most rely on hearing to communicate. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is focused on understanding how speech perception and auditory skills mature for infants, children, and young adults with Down syndrome. The results generated from this project are expected to provide new information about the factors that support communication outcomes for individuals with Down syndrome, and support the development of interventions to maximize listening, learning, and communication in noisy listening environments, such as classrooms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Extensive expansion of unconventional oil and gas development (UOGD) has been an emerging environmental health issue due to it proliferation and potential harmful health influence on nearby residents. Critical gaps in exposure assessments have prevented previous UOGD-related epidemiological studies from achieving credible and actionable evidence regarding the specific UOGD construction stage(s) or UOGD-related pollutant(s). I plan to enhance exposure assessment with remote sensing methods and evaluate the acute effects of UOGD construction stages on the risk of cause-specific hospitalization in Medicare beneficiaries based on the improved exposure metrics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will investigate the expression, localization, and polymorphisms of the newly discovered Mas-related G protein-coupled receptor X3 (MrpgrX3) and IL-22 in the pathogenesis of itch in atopic dermatitis and prurigo nodularis in human patients. The results will be correlated with race, as these itch-associated skin diseases disproportionately affect African Americans. The results will provide new pathogenic insights and biomarkers for itch in distinct patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal examines a means of providing potent anticoagulation within extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) circuits without limiting normal coagulation in a patient’s tissues. To accomplish this, we propose combining polycarboxybetaine surface coatings with a highly selective bicyclic peptide Factor XIIa inhibitor. Together, these should improve survival during ECMO and enable long-term respiratory support outside the intensive care unit.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: HIV testing remains the critical first step in achieving the 95-95-95 goals for HIV/AIDS treatment and prevention, yet testing rates are plateauing and more cost-effective strategies are needed to test higher-risk populations. We propose to leverage the ubiquity of mobile phones and the reach of social networks, to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a novel mHealth intervention, Confidential Social Network Referrals for HIV Testing (CONSORT), for ‘nudging’ high-risk populations to test for HIV. The autonomous, open-source, SMS-based approach can be scaled at minimal cost, is readily extensible to smartphone technologies and social media contexts, and holds significant potential to improve uptake of HIV testing and broadly shift paradigms for engaging social networks to change health-related behaviors.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite global advances in technologies to prevent cervical cancer, roughly 90% of the burden of this preventable disease persists in LMICs. Along with the WHO’s call for elimination of cervical cancer within 100 years comes the need for effective innovations for expanding screening and completing follow-up triage and treatment. mHealth interventions integrated into existing HPV-based cervical cancer control programs may significantly impact patient health outcomes and provider engagement.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE School-age school children in sub-Saharan Africa are most commonly infected with malaria parasites among other age groups, but their infections are often undiagnosed because of a lack of malarial testing commodities. Because malaria screening among school-age children is important to reduce malaria transmission and to improve school performance, our research focuses on developing a mobile health (mHealth) technology to reliably identify school-age children who will need malaria tests and receive treatment. The proposed mHealth technology will support community health workers and local health facilities by maximizing the currently available resources for malaria diagnosis and management, while improving children’s health and public health response, in particular in the developing world and resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by low platelet counts; patients with thrombocytopenia are at risk of excessive, uncontrollable bleeding. The current standard of care is transfusion with donor platelet products to mitigate bleeding risks. However, donor platelets are expensive, carry significant risk of infections, have variable hemostatic efficacy, and have very short shelf life (3-5 days). Our innovative SynthoPlateTM technology can mimic platelet’s hemostatic functions while providing advantages of large-scale production and sterilizability to reduce contamination risk and ensure long shelf life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a leading cause of mortality/morbidity, and there is no FDA-approved therapy for any stage of ALD. Unfortunately, patients with ALD rarely have their underlying alcohol use disorder (AUD) concomitantly addressed. This consortium links health care providers with expertise in AUD and ALD in a unified treatment strategy to evaluate novel combined treatments for AUD/ALD in patients with advanced ALD. The existing resources of the NIAAA-funded AlcHepNet are used for patient studies, biospecimen collection and site-specific ancillary studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipoproteins are essential particles that transport fats to different cells in the brain. In individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD), lipoproteins are not taken up by cells properly and instead bind to other factors outside the cell such as amyloid, leading to amyloid plaque formation, and damage to brain tissue and function. In this proposal, we aim to enhance the activity of the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL), which can help specialized cells called microglia remove excess lipoproteins, prevent amyloid accumulation, and protect against the development of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how the molecular components, inherited lineage, and spatial milieu of single cells dictate function in health and disease remains a key outstanding challenge in genomics. The overarching goal of our Center for Integrated Cellular Analysis is to develop methods to simultaneously assess these multimodal cellular properties, develop tools to harmonize them to allow inferential assessment of cell identity based on partial phenotyping, and share these developments with the broad scientific community while encouraging community engagement through education and outreach. Success in our strategy will facilitate deep, multi-omic phenotyping of single cells for basic research and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Congenital cardiac anomalies represent the most common birth defect, affecting nearly 1% of all live births and despite significant advances in their surgical and medical management, these conditions remain a leading cause of death and disability in the newborn period. One significant source of morbidity and mortality arises from complications associated with the use of currently available prosthetic vascular grafts, cardiovascular patches, and replacement heart valves that are frequently required to perform reconstructive procedures. Tissue engineering offers a potential strategy for creating improved biomaterials for use in congenital heart surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is now accepted that cell-to-cell variability affects viral infection outcome, we currently lack mechanistic understanding as to the host factors and transcriptional programs that control it. To gain such mechanistic insights requires the development of new approaches that are able to connect the cell’s initial state with infection outcome. This project will develop and apply state-of-the-art single cell approaches to decipher the molecular mechanisms that control viral infection outcomes at the single cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: This project investigates the effects of Neuropeptide Y (NPY), a peptide made by inhibitory neurons in the brain, on the function of the hippocampus, a part of the brain important for learning, memory, and mood regulation. NPY is known to have anti-anxiety properties and to be protective against stress, although our knowledge about the mechanisms underlying its effects is incomplete. The proposed studies will enhance our understanding of the underlying synaptic and circuit mechanisms by which NPY in hippocampus alters stress- related behavior and affects how the brain responds to traumatic stress, and may lead to new therapeutic targets for complex brain disorders such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survival rates for many childhood and adolescent cancers have improved at a remarkable pace over the past five decades. The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS; U24 CA055727; PI: Armstrong) cohort has been the source of some of the most significant publications to date addressing the long-term mortality, morbidity and quality of life of survivors of childhood cancer. Understanding the risk for late effects of childhood cancer and its therapy provides the basis for health screening recommendations and interventions that can mitigate long-term health problems in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Naïve T cell numbers are dramatically decreased with age, leading to impaired immune responses in the elderly. Naïve T cells rely on signals from the lymph node tissue environment to survive, yet it is unknown whether this support is reduced with age. This project will determine how age-related changes to the structural organization of the lymph nodes contributes to reduced naïve T cell survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how skin commensal bacteria shape pathogenic MAIT cell responses is essential to elucidating the pathogenic mechanisms in lupus skin, characterized by disbyosis and notable T cell presence. This application directly addresses the NIH Stephen Katz funding opportunity as it proposes an innovative project that represents a change in research direction, while also supporting the programmatic objectives of the NIAMS Skin Biology and Diseases program. In addition to advancing the understanding of the immune cell – microbiome interactions in lupus skin, these studies will define targetable pathways to prevent lupus skin disease, thus addressing the NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce the burden of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The effective treatment of bacterial infections of skin, deep soft tissues and wounds continues to be a major unmet healthcare challenge, especially in patients whose antimicrobial responses are compromised by underlying diabetes. The proposed work seeks to establish a new class of antimicrobials, inspired by immune cells, that are synergistic through the combination of histones with agents that target the outer surface of bacteria. The successful outcome of this work would provide fundamental insight into a novel antimicrobial mechanism and produce important pre-clinical data for the development of new therapeutics that treat skin, soft tissue, and wound infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The built environment—the buildings, streets, and green spaces in which we live—may influence cardiovascular disease (CVD) by promoting or limiting physical activity and weight gain and by shaping exposures to environmental hazards (e.g., air pollution, extreme temperatures, noise); however, developing accurate, time- varying, and personalized exposure metrics is necessary to build causal relationships between the built environment and CVD and to inform policy-relevant, actionable interventions. We propose to identify the influence of the built environment on CVD-related health behaviors and CVD incidence by developing longitudinal built environment exposure measures from street-view and satellite imagery using deep learning algorithms, and to apply these exposure measures to time-activity data from a) 500 participants with global positioning systems (GPS) data from the Nurses’ Health Study 3 (NHS3) and b) over 34 years of geocoded residential addresses from three large nationwide cohorts of over 288,000 US adult women and men from the Nurses’ Health Study, Nurses’ Health Study II, and Health Professionals Follow-up Study prospective cohorts. Our work will enable us to measure time-varying exposure to the built environment with unprecedented precision in large prospective cohorts, to elucidate potential relationships between the built environment and CVD health behaviors, to better specify pathways to CVD incidence, and ultimately, to yield actionable insights to guide land use policy and urban planning strategies to design cities that optimize cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Polyketides are used more in human medicine than any other class of secondary metabolites, and comprise roughly 20% of top-selling small-molecule drugs. This project advances catalytic methods for the de novo chemical synthesis of polyketides based on hydrogen auto-transfer processes that enable direct stereo- and site-selective conversion of lower alcohols to higher alcohols. Polyketide natural products that possess anti-cancer and anti- bacterial properties are targeted.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Ensuring that colonoscopy is performed well is necessary for optimizing prevention of colorectal cancer (CRC). One of the most important ways of measuring the quality of colonoscopy is to see how often CRC occurs following an initial colonoscopy that does not show CRC, an entity known as “post-colonoscopy CRC” (PCCRC). We plan to: 1) measure how often PCCRCs occur in Veterans; 2) compare Veterans who have PCCRC with those who have an initially detected CRC for cancer stage, surgical complications, and survival; 3) identify factors associated with PCCRC, some of which may lend themselves to interventions that improve how colonoscopy is performed and how well follow-up occurs, measures that will make sure Veterans are receiving colonoscopy and follow-up of the highest quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: R21 R33 Narrative Hearing loss is a major global health problem, especially in low and middle income countries where most people lack access to hearing health care. This proposal offers innovative mobile health solutions, focusing on the fitting and support of good quality low-cost hearing aids by community health workers. If successful, this approach could be scaled up to address hearing health care for underserved populations globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The initiation of DNA replication is tightly regulated to maintain genome integrity, yet the molecular mechanisms that underlie this fundamental process are poorly understood, especially in multicellular organisms. Key proteins involved in replication initiation are poorly conserved between yeast and humans, and mutations in these proteins cause genetic diseases. This project will employ a powerful single-molecule approach that we developed to dissect the mechanism of replication initiation, delineate the exact roles of replication initiation proteins, and understand why mutations in these proteins cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung function is an important determinant of asthma, a disease with significantly increasing public health burden world-wide. This K99/R00 grant utilizes innovative analytic approach for multi-omic integration of metabolomic, methylomic and genetic drivers of sub-optimal lung function in asthmatic children; none of the studies so far have interrogated their joint role for lung function in asthmatics. The findings from this proposal will provide a better understanding of the mediated effects through multi-omic profiles for asthma pathogenesis and allow us to focus on the molecular intersection of potential biomarkers with predictive potential in dysregulated pathways and life- course interventions for individuals with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy development relies on the preclinical validation of anti-tumor immune responses in patient derived xenograft (PDX) models. The current PDX models generally lack an autologous human immune system (HIS) and are difficult to reconstitute directly with non-matching human immune cells. We propose to optimize the conditions to generate reprogrammed cells from the same cancer patient and utilize these cells to generate a panel of matched HIS-PDXs to disseminate to the scientific community through the NCI Patient Derived Model Repository (PDMR) for use in testing immune responses and advancing immunotherapy and oncology research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinitis Pigmentosa is a blindness disease in which rod photoreceptors, which are necessary for night vision, degenerate due to inherited mutations, and subsequently, cone photoreceptors, which provide humans with daylight color vision, degenerate for unknown secondary reasons. In mouse models of Retinitis Pigmentosa, which recapitulate the human disease progression, the barrier that separates the blood from the retina begins to break down once rod photoreceptors degenerate. By determining whether such blood leakage causes cone death, this proposed research aims to develop novel therapeutic approaches to promote cone survival, leading to the preservation of daylight color vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The continual trend of “lost in translation” in the search for a successful treatment for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) calls for innovative approaches before a viable drug target is established. The outcomes of this research will yield valuable insights into whether a therapeutic shield such as a human ApoE2- based protein therapy that promotes brain metabolic resilience can potentially be developed into an effective and safe disease-modifying strategy for AD, which is vital to the present fight against this devastating and currently untreatable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse social conditions contribute to poor breast cancer outcomes among Black women. This study will collect and analyze data from surveys, biospecimens, and focus groups among Black women with breast cancer to study associations between social determinants of health, biomarkers of inflammation, and health-related quality of life. Study findings will increase understanding of how social factors may contribute to racial disparities in breast cancer and help identify strategies to improve health outcomes among Black women with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has been well documented that depression is a risk factor for dementia; however, the reasons for this relationship are multifaceted as depressive symptoms may be causal and lead to cognitive decline or they could be an early symptom of a neurodegenerative process occurring later in life. To help clarify this relationship, the current study will examine the extent to which mid-life and late-life onset of depressive symptoms relate to subtle cognitive decline subtypes (i.e., low-executive), progression to cognitive impairment, and unique biological and neural profiles. Further clarifying the underlying causes that link depressive symptoms and cognitive decline would help to clarify the reasons for the depression-dementia relationship and potentially identify individualized targets for intervention based on the time of depression onset and a person’s cognitive and biomarker profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Tic disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder are commonly comorbid and are thought to have overlapping pathophysiology in the cortico-basal ganglia circuitry. Work in an animal model of pathophysiology and pilot data in subjects with tics and OCD have identified previously uncharacterized abnormalities in dopamine D2 and D3 receptors. We will use state-of-the-art positron emission tomography (PET) imaging to examine these receptors in vivo in the brains of individuals with tics, OCD, or both; this will characterize these systems in tic disorders and OCD for the first time and has the potential to elucidate targets for novel treatments, and to identify the particular patients who might benefit from them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver cancer, also known as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), is the fastest growing cause of cancer-related deaths among Americans with liver disease. Fatty liver disease related to metabolic dysfunction (e.g., diabetes, obesity), also called MAFLD or MASLD, has become the most common liver disease in the world. Our research using multilevel factors characterizing genetic ancestries and neighborhood socioeconomic disadvantage aims to address important gaps in our understanding of heterogeneity in HCC risk within Hispanic populations with cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: This study addresses the association between obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk, focusing on Black women who are underrepresented and at heightened risk. The research expands the parent grant by examining the moderating effect of OSA on the link between inflammation and cognitive performance, as well as determining if OSA mediates the relationship between neighborhood factors and cognition in Black women. Leveraging a community-based approach, the study incorporates both sleep variables and subjective neighborhood factors to comprehensively assess the multifaceted determinants of AD risk among an underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The use of drugs to enhance sex (sexualized drug use (SDU), chemsex) is a practice among some men who have sex with men (MSM) and this positions them at greater risk for HIV/STI transmission, injection drug use, and polysubstance use. This supplement candidate and parent grant PIs bring together a team of investigators with expertise in harm reduction implementation and social networks, clinicians who serve people who use drugs and LGBTQ+ patients, and community partners that understand and recognize the multiple complexities that surround substance use, specifically in the context of chemsex. Together, we propose a novel study of rural SDU/chemsex engagement among people who use drugs with the intention of evaluating secondary distribution of harm reduction and network influences among this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB), is one of the deadliest pathogens on the planet, and TB is one of the leading causes of death due to infectious disease. The cell envelope of Mtb forms a barrier around the cell, protecting the bacterium from antibiotics and our immune system. We will study protein-based systems that facilitate the transport of nutrients across the cell envelope, including the building blocks of the barrier itself, which may aid in the design of new antibiotics to treat TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene editing systems such as CRISPR are useful for developing immune cell therapies, but clinical applications frequently require processing billions of cells outside the body and current methods are not able to directly deliver DNA-editing proteins into large numbers of cells. The proposed project will develop a very fast method of stretching cell membranes to create temporary pores, facilitating the delivery of proteins which cut DNA and control DNA repair. This nonviral approach of quickly delivering biomolecules into billions of human immune cells will be valuable for efficiently producing immune cell therapies at clinical scales.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of T cells to destroy target cells (e.g., virus infected cells and tumor cells) critically depends on the CD28 costimulatory receptor, but the mechanism by which CD28 is activated in peripheral tissues is unknown since target cells do not display CD28 ligands. Guided by my preliminary data, this proposal aims to dissect a novel cell-intrinsic mechanism of CD28 cis-activation by its ligands expressed on T cells. Execution of the proposed research will define a new dimension of CD28 co-stimulation, and likely reveal innovative means for improving T cell based therapies against cancer and infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Lupus nephritis is a severe manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus associated with significant morbidity and mortality. This project will establish sugar modifications in immunoglobulins that initiate processes within the blood filtering cells of the kidney, known as podocytes, which lead to lupus nephritis. This information will generate new insights and advanced concepts to expand the mechanistic understanding and therapeutic targets for these patients and treat them more efficiently.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The rise of multidrug-resistant organisms (MDRO) in recent decades represents a significant public health concern, associated with increased rates of mortality and healthcare costs. The proposed research will adapt wastewater-based surveillance to the detection of MDRO, by elucidating specific wastewater parameters which influence the prevalence and diversity of MDRO and antibiotic resistance genes. This will lead to development of optimal wastewater based models to accurately estimate the prevalence of MDRO, and ultimately inform targeted, population-specific strategies to mitigate multidrug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With multi-drug resistance and a high recurrence rate, Clostridioides difficile (C. diff.) infection severely threatens human life and burdens health-care systems both in the United States and worldwide. As potent RNA polymerase (RNAP) inhibitors are front-line treatments for infectious diseases, this pioneering work will investigate the structure, function, and regulation of the C. diff. transcriptional machinery. The results generated will provide new knowledge needed to discover new drugs targeting C. diff. RNAP and understand their mechanisms of action, thereby improving antibiotic treatments for this emerging public health threat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) co-opts cellular metabolism for viral propagation. This research proposal describes synergistic efforts to develop CRISPR- based tools for dissecting viral mechanisms of host takeover and identifies RNA repair mechanisms that support SARS-CoV-2 replication. Collectively, the work proposed here will provide RNA editing tools with broad implications for science and medicine and generate new insights into RNA repair in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Achilles tendinopathy is a painful condition that does not fully resolve in 20-60% of patients following conservative treatment. In this study, we will determine rehabilitation loading profiles and ultrasound imaging biomarkers that explain tendon healing and functional outcomes in patients. We will also measure circulating levels of sex hormones to determine how variations in sex hormones impact tendon healing and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of neurological disability, however the pathological mechanisms initiated by primary physical injury that lead to progressive cognitive and motor impairment are not well defined. This proposal will leverage stem cell biology and genomics techniques in order to understand how mechanotransduction by oligodendrocytes contributes to myelin pathology after TBI. The results of this proposal will contribute to the development of novel therapeutics aimed at enhancing white matter integrity after TBI.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Use of opioids during pregnancy can result in a diagnosis of neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. Our fundamental goal is to understand how opioids affects the brain pathways essential to swallow, and to develop a platform in which new therapies can be tested.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Title: Brain cPLA2 as a mechanism for neuroinflammation in AD/ADRD with and without APOEε4 – Diversity Supplement In this supplement application, Cristelle Hugo will test the role of cPLA2 activation on cellular senescence in induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived astrocytes carrying the APOEε4 allele, as well as in a set of patient-derived iPSCs. To identify whether cPLA2 activation AD status and APOE genotype, Cristelle Hugo will also study cPLA2 activation in the context of cellular senescence using a set of patient-derived astrocytes. This research project adds a new angle to the parent grant, with the potential to implicate cPLA2 activation in cellular senescence, an important component of aging and aging-related diseases like AD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed studies aim to leverage a physiologically relevant non-human primate model of both HIV and malaria to identify key immune factors that drive poor maternal and fetal outcomes during infection in pregnancy. Establishing such immune mechanisms would create potential for considerable advances in the identification and pre-clinical testing of novel therapeutic strategies to restore health in women living with HIV who become infected with malaria during pregnancy. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NICHD as it will significantly contribute to the ultimate goal of reducing the substantial burden of malaria infection in vulnerable women living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This administrative supplement application is related to parent award U41 NS129514 “HORNET OpenNerve Platform” which aims to develop and disseminate an open-architecture and open-source implantable system for autonomic nerve stimulation and recording system to support clinical research for bioelectronic medicine applications. The objective here is to perform short- and long-term validation of the OpenNerve Platform functionality in large animals for closed-loop sacral nerve stimulation and for treatment of chronic constipation. Studies will include the implanted OpenNerve Platform components: (1) implantable pulse generator, (2) implantable leads for nerve stimulation; (3) implantable leads for recording muscle activity (4) implantable leads for strain sensing, and (5) implantable leads for pH and Acetylcholine sensing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This administrative supplement application is related to parent award U41 NS129514 “HORNET OpenNerve Platform” which aims to develop and disseminate an open-architecture and open-source implantable system for autonomic nerve stimulation and recording system to support clinical research for bioelectronic medicine applications. The objective here is to perform short- and long-term validation of the OpenNerve Platform functionality in large animals for closed-loop cervical vagus nerve stimulation and glossopharyngeal nerve stimulation for treatment of stroke-induced dysphagia and aspiration pneumonia. Studies will include the implanted OpenNerve Platform components: (1) implantable pulse generator, (2) implantable leads for nerve stimulation; and (3) implantable leads for recording muscle activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Peripheral arterial disease (PAD), an illness commonly found in the elderly and caused by arterial occlusion in the lower body, affects more than 200 million people worldwide and is associated with high rates of morbidity and mortality. To reduce these complications and improve the quality of life for PAD patients, our research aims to develop novel biodegradable nanoparticles to deliver therapeutic agents that specifically protect cells under ischemic stress conditions, facilitate the formation of blood vessels under hypoxia, and facilitate noninvasive multimodal imaging methods, such as fluorescent and photoacoustic imaging, to monitor the progress of this therapeutic intervention. The impact of our research is significant as these new nanoparticle platforms could be used to deliver any therapeutics locally, treat this disease effectively, and monitor the treatment noninvasively by imaging.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: While the majority of VHA enrollees have their own insurance, VA research and operation depend mostly on data within the VA to assess opioid use and evaluate policy. Meanwhile, Veterans who are dual users of the VA and community care are at higher risks of opioid use and misuse. This study will leverage several non-VA data sources along with VA data to study the opioid use and misuse in dual users vs the mono users, with the goal of improving care coordination and reduce opioid misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROPOSAL NARRATIVE We have found that neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) activated during lung inflammation can trigger the awakening of dormant cancer cells that have spread to other organs, causing them to start proliferating again. This is a new concept for how an external factor, inflammation via NETs, promotes metastatic recurrence. Through three specific aims, we will determine exactly how NETs drive dormant tumor cells to proliferate, how NETs activate macrophages to generate an inflammatory microenvironment, and how best to target NETs to prevent metastasis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Ensuring that colonoscopy is performed well is necessary for optimizing prevention of colorectal cancer (CRC). One of the most important ways of measuring the quality of colonoscopy is to see how often CRC occurs following an initial colonoscopy that does not show CRC, an entity known as “post-colonoscopy CRC” (PCCRC). We plan to: 1) measure how often PCCRCs occur in Veterans; 2) compare Veterans who have PCCRC with those who have an initially detected CRC for cancer stage, surgical complications, and survival; 3) identify factors associated with PCCRC, some of which may lend themselves to interventions that improve how colonoscopy is performed and how well follow-up occurs, measures that will make sure Veterans are receiving colonoscopy and follow-up of the highest quality.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effort to fully realize health equity across ethnicity, race, age, disability, and geography will be accelerated by the use of data that best measures and captures the health of all Americans and the contexts in which they receive their care. Minoritized populations, older populations, rural populations and persons with disabilities have been underrepresented in the real-world data used for studies of drug and device safety and efficacy and many datasets do not adequately measure domains necessary for health equity research. To address these challenges, we will evaluate the impact of race, ethnicity, geography and social deprivation on the delivery of guideline concordant care for COVID-19, using data from a diverse cohort of nearly eight million primary care patients from small independent clinics across the U.S.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Assessing the racial, ethnic, and geographic equitability of COVID-19 treatments in a primary care population

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Aging is a complex process that drives increased cancer risk in tissues throughout the body, including the blood system. To understand why aged individuals have higher risk of developing blood cancers, there is a vital need to understand the mechanisms by which aging contributes to clonal expansion and transformation. This research is relevant to public health because it will provide mechanistic insights into effective therapeutic strategies to target clonal evolution, attenuate pathophysiology promoted by clonal expansion, and intercept malignant transformation.

PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE  Age is the most important risk factor for developing Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, but the mechanisms and development of successful treatments remain elusive. IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: ASSOCIATION OF FOOD AND DRUG OFFICIALS
PHR: AFDO 2024 Alliance to Support the Activities of the Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS), Including the Grade A Milk Safety and National Shellfish Sanitation Programs  Application: Project Narrative The Association of Food and Drug Officials’ (AFDO) efforts under this cooperative agreement are intended to facilitate long-term improvements to the national food safety system by strengthening federal – state collaborations and improving state’s regulatory surveillance and protection programs for manufactured foods, Grade A milk, and shellfish sanitation programs. AFDO will support and contribute to the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Alliance (MFRPA) as they work with states to develop best practices, develop and support training initiatives, and assist state programs in achieving programmatic improvement and conformance with the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS). Through effective interagency collaboration, workforce development strategies, development of critical communication and data sharing strategies, and funding for state Grade A Milk and Shellfish program training and equipment, this project will help achieve a nationally Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) and assist the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in achieving their mandates under the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to develop a new class of b-strand/sheet mimics capable of disrupting the aggregation of amyloid proteins. These compounds will be used to selectively target the fibrilization and transmission of toxic tau filaments from cell to cell. The research plan incorporates chemical synthesis, structural characterization, and biological evaluation of novel peptide and protein mimics to probe neurodegenerative protein assemblies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/ Public Health Relevance Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) are complex, multifactorial disorders characterized by impaired host- microbiome interactions that lead to chronic and relapsing intestinal inflammation with an incompletely understood etiology. In the parent application, we demonstrated that poly-ADP-ribosylation (PARylation), a post-translational protein modification known to profoundly affect cellular functions in other systems, plays an active role in gut epithelial cell biology, host-microbiome interactions, and mucosal inflammatory responses. This administrative supplement is geared towards providing additional support for a minority graduate student (Catherine Ellis), an exceptional PhD candidate in the Kiela lab, who identified a novel pathway responsible for promoting pathological and excessive PARylation in the inflamed gut mucosa, thus contributing to the severity and progression of inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reactive astrocytes are common features of neurodegenerative diseases and normal aging, but their role is still poorly understood and can encompass both beneficial and harmful effects. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that lead to astrocyte activation and defining the heterogeneity of astrocyte activation will lead to novel astrocyte-targeted therapies. This training proposal aims to understand the causes and effects of astrocyte reactivity in the context of Alexander Disease (Aim 1) and aging and neurodegeneration (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In this multicomponent application for an Administrative Supplement for U54 AI170752, the first component will accelerate membrane protein technologies for HIV-1 Env studies, aimed at structural dissection of the mechanisms of antibody interactions to the Membrane Proximal External Region (MPER), understanding HIV- 1 coreceptor tropism and elucidating the mechanism of a gp41 directed fusion inhibitor. The second component will add a Direct Detector Camera to our existing Tundra microscope to enable routine high resolution cryo-EM data acquisition for HIV-1 Env samples. The third component will acquire a Nanotemper Monolith X for robust equilibrium measurement of challenging biomolecular interactions with minimal sample consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cytomegalovirus viremia is associated with mortality in persons with advanced HIV disease. It is unknown if cytomegalovirus viremia is driving the risk, or is rather a sensitive marker of immune dysfunction in those at risk for poor clinical outcomes. The objective of this study is to determine the dynamics of CMV viremia over time in persons with advanced HIV disease and concomitant cryptococcal meningitis, to establish how CMV viremia impacts mortality in a time-dependent fashion, and to identify if an impaired host immune response is associated with active CMV viremia.

PHR: The 2025 meeting of the SBSRN will be co-hosted by the Penn and UNC CFARs and will partner with the Inter-CFAR Substance Use Research Committee (I-SURC) and the National CFAR CAB Coalition (N3C). The meeting will bring together early-stage investigators, established investigators from CFARs and ARCs, community representatives, and NIH program officials, will be fully aligned with the OAR and EHE research priorities, and will disseminate and critique cutting edge HIV science. SBSRN 2025 will begin with a day devoted to mentoring ESIs followed by a one-day scientific symposium and will provide attendees with opportunities for networking and collaboration development.
