IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a public health crisis in the US and a growing health disparity, with African Americans at disproportionate risk for the disease compared to non-Hispanic whites. This project proposes to investigate earlier-life, individual- and community-level stress exposures—adverse life circumstances and trauma (ie, extreme poverty, residential instability, crime, police and community violence, incarceration, racial discrimination), mental disorders and their symptoms, and poor sleep (eg, abnormal duration, fragmentation)—as determinants of known midlife risk factors for poor cognitive outcomes in later life in two high-risk, predominantly African American cohorts followed longitudinally for 35 years. Results will help clarify links of stress exposures with estimated risk at midlife for later-life dementia, identify vulnerable subgroups for targeted prevention of Alzheimer’s disease, elucidate the role of social inequities in determining racial disparities in Alzheimer’s dementia, and establish a midlife cognitive baseline for future longitudinal follow-up of these valuable cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative . Over 1 million older adults with serious illness have major surgery or severe trauma each year, and palliative care delivered alongside surgical care can help relieve patient suffering, improve post- operative outcomes, and reduce healthcare utilization. Although seriously ill surgical patients benefit from palliative care, they are less likely than other patients to receive it. The proposed study will provide an innovative and layered examination of the role of palliative care in surgery in order to directly inform bedside clinical decisions and the implementation of targeted palliative care interventions to improve care for older seriously ill surgical patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Aging and brain disorders such as dementia and epilepsy lead to deficits in spatial navigation and memory,  which are vital to daily functioning and independence. Here, we will identify key neural circuits of navigation  and memory in humans, thus helping explain the cause of navigational disorders and memory deficits. This will support the development of navigational aids and guide future circuit-based interventions to alleviate  memory loss, thus improving the lives of persons with memory deficits, disorientation, and mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative If we could pinpoint the genes that contribute to resistance against infectious disease, then we would be equipped to efficiently develop personalized gene-based therapies and to precisely target medical and public health interventions to the individuals and populations most at risk. My parent award advances this vision by testing hypotheses for why it has proven so difficult to identify these resistance genes. Our results thus far indicate that the genes contributing to resistance depend critically on how many infectious agents a host encounters (i.e., dose), and this proposed equipment supplement would increase the precision, replication, and versatility of our experiments to systematically characterize how, and why, dose dictates infection outcomes and the underlying genetics of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Narrative We seek to discover the mechanisms of the dynamic contacts of neighboring cells as well as between cells and the extracellular matrix that hold animal cells together. These junctions additionally communicate signals and control the stress placed upon cells. Since the regulation and dysregulation of cell junctions are fundamental to many biological processes such as development and cancer, our proposed studies are therefore significant to our basic mechanistic understanding that could eventually result in a translational impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As people age they lose the ability to heal from injuries or diseases like osteoarthritis, partially due to a reduced ability of old stem cells to differentiate and an inhospitable tissue environment that no longer supports repair. To address this, we propose to 1) activate SIRT6, a sirtuin that can epigenetically reverse age-associated changes in stem cells and 2) inhibit apoptosis signal regulating kinase 1 (ASK1), a protein associated with cell death and inflammation, in the tissue environment. We will test the ability of this novel dual strategy to enhance stem cell differentiation and promote a more regenerative tissue environment in articular cartilage defect models of aged animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is inconsistent evidence indicating that Bilingualism might increase Cognitive Reserve and or resilience (CR/R). We propose a multidisciplinary longitudinal study to compare Bilinguals and Monolinguals with amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment from an equivalent cultural background in neuropsychological and neuroimaging data. Our findings will advance understanding of the complex interactions between neural, environmental, and sociocultural factors and the role of Bilingualism in CR/R in MCI, paving the way for new targets for interventions and providing fundamental insight into the role of language(s) in the aging brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: This supplemental project will increase the availability of culturally relevant and low-cost DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) for low-income African American (AA) women and increase the generalizability of a targeted, useful, and usable interactive health information resource. Community-engaged approaches will be used to identify culturally preferred recipes and modify them into low-cost DASH recipes with AA women living in two low-income AA communities. Modified DASH recipes will be included in the health information resource and marketed to a broader audience through existing community-based partnerships and networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Despite the long-term impact of attention deficits on academic performance, life satisfaction, and job performance, identification of attention deficits in young children remains elusive. This project will examine neural markers of attention to determine if they can better predict attention deficits as children age relative to behavioral assessments. This project is directly relevant to the priorities of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism because we will examine attention in children with prenatal alcohol exposure who are known to have increased risk for developing attention deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Why some cells die while other survive in the brains of patients with synucleinopathies remains uncertain. Herein, we propose to use a new gene editing technology to elucidate the mechanisms driving cell resilience in these neurological disorders. If successful, this strategy may have far-reaching implications for the treatment of synucleinopathies and even perhaps Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE On average, children from disadvantaged backgrounds, on average exhibit disparities in academic achievement and cognitive development, compared to their peers from higher socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds. The proposed studies will investigate the role of specific aspects of children’s early language input on the development of neural networks supporting the development of language, executive functioning, and social cognition, and how these may ultimately drive SES differences in academic achievement. Findings from this work have the potential to inform maximally impactful interventions to reduce achievement gaps and improve cognitive outcomes for children from all backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE__________________________________________________________________ Alzheimer’s disease is one of the most prevalent and impactful diseases in the United States and throughout the world. Currently no effective treatments or therapeutics that slow or stop Alzheimer’s disease are available. This project seeks to determine the mechanism by which changes in the gut microbiota and gut permeability can modify the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed work is expected to result in new information that can inform the development of new therapeutic strategies or treatments for Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our Program is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) recruits and controls host DNA damage responses to ensure the fidelity of the viral genome. Importantly, this work will define the mechanisms by which HCMV evolves antiviral resistance. Despite advances in diagnostics and therapeutics, HCMV remains a major life-threatening complication following solid organ or stem cell transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although telomere regions at the ends of human chromosomes normally shorten with age, accelerated shortening can lead to diseases like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) that may necessitate lung transplantation. This proposal tests the innovative hypothesis that accelerated telomere shortening may also cause loss of function in the transplanted lung. This novel paradigm could lead to novel diagnostics and interventions to improve survival following lung transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The project by Drs. Gage, Mertens and colleagues aims at deciphering the roles of neuronal hypo- maturity in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) using patient-specific 3D models. The team will study the spatial relationship between markers for neuronal senescence, neurodegeneration, maturation, and neuroinflammation in functional and unbiased multi-omic approaches employing AD and control derived 3D models. They will also leverage insights from the cancer field and explore chemical PKM modulators in AD patient 3D models to develop novel approaches to treat AD, and they will assess the impact of aberrant metabolic states of human neurons and astrocytes in the context of neuron-astrocyte coupling in a three-dimensional multicellular model. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: R01 Parent Project Narrative This project’s relevance to public health stems from its efforts to identify aspects of the bilingual experience that are associated with a significantly later age of symptom onset in Hispanics with language-prominent dementia. In addition, this project will address evidence-based treatment approaches for bilingual speakers with progressive language impairments caused by dementia (i.e., primary progressive aphasia). The project will enhance our knowledge of bilingualism as a contributor to cognitive reserve and brain plasticity which will inform theory and clinical practice in this historically underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Understanding how the infraslow sigma power (ISP) rhythm regulates sleep architecture and REM sleep will help identify mechanistic targets to restore sleep quality impaired by stress, chronic pain, or affective disorders, thus providing substantial translational value for human health. As the ISP rhythm is present in the human EEG, it is a potential biomarker for assessing sleep quality and may enable the early detection of sleep disturbances, which are often precursors for other disorders. In addition, our findings will unravel neural mechanisms that promote infraslow brain dynamics and may thus open new avenues to develop complementary approaches that can amplify the ISP rhythm and thereby enhance the restorative effects of high-quality sleep on brain homeostasis and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: By quantitatively characterizing how neurons in the auditory cortex learn to encode behaviorally relevant complex sounds such as vocalizations, this project will reveal fundamental principles of the organization and function of auditory cortical circuits for sensory aspects of vocal communication across species. By gaining a deeper understanding of the normal function of these circuits, our project could also provide insight into circuit dysfunction underlying communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): The results will provide a validated model that can explain individual and clinical differences across tasks  and will reveal biological changes that contribute to belief updating behavior, both normal and abnormal in  schizophrenia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: public health relevance, the circuit and computational principles underlying cognitive  flexibility are poorly understood. The prefrontal cortex (PFC) and mediodorsal (MD) thalamus play a  critical role in cognitive flexibility, disrupted PFC or MD activity or their temporal coordination may lead to  impaired flexibility in attentional control, working memory and decision making. Guided by the converging  evidence from the literature and our own preliminary data, we propose that temporal coordination between  the MD and PFC in the beta/gamma range enable optimal cognitive control, and that their perturbation  underlies some of the cognitive deficits in schizophrenia. We will develop experimental and computational  tools that further clarify this link along with a set of interventional tools that may ultimately be deployed in  human patients. Our central hypothesis is that temporal coordination of the MD and PFC neural activity  (spikes and local field potentials) provides a readout of animal's "state-of-mind" during working memory,  and that temporally patterned MD neurostimulation provides an effective strategy to enhance prefrontal  engagement in cognitive processing. Specifically, we will combine multidisciplinary techniques (genetic  mouse model, animal behaviors, multisite electrophysiology, optogenetics, closed-loop brain-machine  interface, machine learning and computational psychiatry) to understand temporal dynamics of  coordinated MD-PFC neural activity during flexible cognition tasks for both schizophrenic and wild-type  mouse models. In Aim 1, we will test the hypothesis that MD-PFC oscillatory entrainment deficits co-vary  with task-switching impairments in a high-penetrance genetic model relevant to schizophrenia. In Aim 2,  we will develop closed-loop patterned stimulation strategies to modulate MD-PFC circuits for improving  cognition. In Aim 3, we will develop spiking recurrent neural network models as a general platform for  prototyping interventions in the MD-PFC loop for cognitive dysfunction. Accomplishment of these aims is  highly significant for gaining translational insight into a wide range of neuropsychiatric disorders related to  cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As the number of older adults continues to rise, and the prevalence of individuals affected by neurodegenerative disease increases, understanding the interpersonal factors that contribute to caregivers’ health decline will become increasingly important. Identifying interpersonal mechanisms that promote or hinder caregivers’ health will point towards potentially modifiable factors that could reduce the collateral damage of neurodegenerative disease. Findings from the current research could facilitate the development of targeted and effective interventions to maintain the health of caregivers and the individuals for whom they care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Embrient Inc is pleased to submit our request for an HHS / SBIR / NIBIB grant, entitled, “Developing a Novel Incubator to Increase Cell Culture Reproducibility.” By funding this grant, you will support our efforts to design and test an incubator that employs laminar flow principles, aiming to achieve zero or near-zero chamber recovery time when the incubator door is opened. This innovation holds the promise that future cell culture experiments utilizing our incubator can maintain stable conditions akin to the human body, without the extensive fluctuations that affect the reliability of current market incubators. As a result, research outcomes will be more dependable and reproducible, advancing scientific progress.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the 7th leading cause of death in the US and approaches for reducing the  number of people affected by dementia are needed. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Here we propose a rapid, field-deployable, cost-effective, highly sensitive and specific lateral flow assay (LFA) that will fully meet a Target Product Profile (TPP) released in 2021 by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the surveillance of Lymphatic Filariasis (LF). The filarial worm Wuchereria bancrofti, the main causative pathogen of lymphatic filariasis (LF), has been the focus of the most ambitious mass drug administration (MDA) programs ever implemented by WHO. With 50 countries theoretically approaching disease elimination in the next 5 years, there is an urgent need for new and sensitive field-deployable diagnostics that will assist countries in conducting post-MDA surveillance until 2030, and beyond. The key requirements of the TPP are that the test should be able to detect early infection, have >85% clinical sensitivity and > 98.8% specificity, and be field-deployable and cost-effective. To date, the best markers of early infection are IgG4 antibodies the human host generates in response to Wb123, a protein expressed by the infective (L3) stage of W. bancrofti. The only existing IgG4/Wb123 portable Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT), marketed by Abbott, had a clinical sensitivity around ¼ that of the corresponding ELISA. In earlier work, we have developed a prototype LFA for the detection of Wb123-specific IgG4 characterized by an analytical sensitivity 16-32 greater than that of the Abbott RDT and equal to the commercial Wb123 ELISA. This test is poised to meet the > 85% clinical sensitivity criterion but might fall short of the minimal (>98.8%) or ideal (>99.8%) specificity criterion. We now propose a biplex test allowing to simultaneously detect antibodies against two antigens, of which one will be Wb123, and the other one chosen from a series of five novel antigens, termed WbAg1-5 or WbAgX. The purpose of the dual test is to achieve a superior specificity by imposing the condition that both test lines must be visible to count the test as positive. We have been awarded a grant from the Task Force for Global Health (TFGH) and USAID to develop a prototype version of such a biplex assay. We are now requesting additional funding from the NIH to: (1) optimize the biplex assays (2) establish a biorepository of 2000 clinical samples and ensure that one biplex meets the WHO TPP with greater than 95% statistical confidence and (3) progress the selected biplex to manufacturing and commercialization. By the end of this Phase 1/2 Fast-Track grant, a total of 100,000 assays will be available for testing by the TFGH, the CDC, and other stakeholders to generate the field data necessary to secure its international endorsement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates contributes to increased rates of human infertility and reproductive disorders worldwide. The proposed research will fill a public health need by developing a method to investigate the mechanisms through which endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates act to cause toxicity in the ovary. The results of this project will facilitate the development of safer alternative chemicals and contribute to the identification of new treatments to protect the ovary from environmental chemical exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the prevalence of co-occurring psychiatric and/or substance use disorders in people living with HIV, these disorders are generally investigated in isolation, with very little work performed at the intersection of these disorders, especially in human brain. To address this gap, we propose to directly investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of co-occurring major depressive disorder, opioid use disorder, and HIV using a combination of multi-omics and histological approaches in postmortem human brain. These studies will improve our understanding of disease-related mechanisms in the brain, while paving the way for improving on current and new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative – MAE-WEST SCORE Overall Women compared to men experience an excess of burden of age-related diseases of the heart, brain, and kidney for reasons that remain unclear. Growing evidence points to the potential importance of chronic inflammation and small blood vessel dysfunction as key determinants of the sex differences seen in age-related disease outcomes. Therefore, we will establish a Specialized Center of Research Excellence focused on comprehensively investigating sex differences in the molecular drivers of chronic inflammation, microvascular aging, and end-organ disease. !

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks funding for the seventh cycle of our training program in Pathophysiology and Rehabilitation of Neural Dysfunction (PRND). The specific objectives are to train prospective researchers from engineering and the basic sciences who understand the spectrum of problems confronting people with neurologic disabilities, and who possess the clinical, scientific, and quantitative skills to alleviate the burden on this growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optic nerve hypoplasia (ONH) is one of the most common congenital disorders of the optic disc and an increasingly prevalent cause of childhood blindness. Not much is known about this pervasive disease with very few animal models available. In our current proposal we describe a translational project on this disorder, one which is also likely to delineate a common pathway linking association of ONH with nutritional deprivation, infantile cholestasis, maternal diabetes, fetal alcohol syndrome, mitochondrial cytopathies, and peroxisomal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biomedical scientists use descriptions of biomedical concepts (and of the relationships among concepts) known as ontologies to standardize how researchers and clinicians talk about biomedical phenomena. BioPortal is a computer system that integrates more than 1000 biomedical ontologies, making it easy for scientists and clinicians to use the resulting knowledge to describe their data, to access information more reliably, to build other knowledge resources in standardized ways, and to bring biomedical knowledge both to the laboratory and to the point of care. The infrastructure that BioPortal uses to store its ontology content has reached the end of its expected lifespan, thus this supplement will allow us to replace the storage unit to extend the durability of the entire BioPortal resource for many more years.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults living with HIV (YLH) experience high rates of non-retention in care, and it is important to identify key factors influencing non-retention. The proposed F31 project leverages data from an ongoing cluster randomized trial to identify demographic, social, behavioral, and clinical cofactors of non- retention among YLH (10-24 years), determine trajectories of depression and adherence self-efficacy during 12- month longitudinal follow-up, as well as examine caregivers’ experiences navigating HIV adherence and retention support for YLH. Findings from this study will inform future interventions tailored to YLH and their caregivers, identify age-disaggregated cofactors of non-retention, and provide opportunities for the F31 candidate to gain new methods and content-area expertise and advance as an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Biliary atresia the principal reason for liver transplantation in children, yet is without known causes or effective medical therapies. The research in this proposal aims to fill these large knowledge gaps by performing studies in a newly-created mouse model of biliary atresia. This novel mouse model is based upon recent genetic studies indicating that mutations in the gene PKD1L1 may be a cause of biliary atresia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will have a significant impact on the fundamental understanding of bacterial physiology by determining why ribosome rescue pathways are essential for bacteria, providing the first structural and biochemical pictures of ribosomal interactions required for ribosome rescue, and providing biochemical and structural information that will allow rational optimization of the activity of ribosome rescue inhibitors. These studies will enable development of ribosome rescue inhibitors as new antibiotics. Therefore, this work will have a large and direct impact on improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Human noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) usually occurs due to accumulated damage across repeated exposures, in contrast to studies in animal models where hearing loss is typically induced by single high-level noise exposures. By combining chronic noise exposures (modeled after human occupational noise exposure) in macaques with anatomical, behavioral, and physiological studies, we will document the sequential progression of hearing difficulty and hearing loss with cochlear pathology: progressive damage is expected to be associated with progressive deficit. The studies are designed to elucidate the sequence of hearing changes and the dosage of noise associated with those changes, and to identify clinically adaptable tests and measures that can be used as early warning signs of hearing dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There is a need to discover new treatments for ischemic stroke because, for most patients, we cannot currently prevent long-term disability and its associated suffering and expense. Experimental stroke research shows that inactivation of alpha2-antiplasmin (a2AP-I) profoundly reduces brain injury, hemorrhage, disability and death, in a longer time window, than the best available medical therapy. Following a successful Phase I trial of an a2AP-I called TS23, this Phase II NIH StrokeNet trial will investigate whether a particular dose is safe and potentially effective in patients who present late after ischemic stroke, for whom there is no effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use among adolescents (ADOL) is prevalent, yet grossly undertreated. Wisdom tooth extraction is a common, acutely painful procedure for ADOL that represents an opportune time to identify ADOL substance use and engage ADOL in brief intervention due to shared risk factors between SU and pain, the potential for exposure to prescription opioids for pain management, and because substance use is associated with increased risk for post-operative complications. This study aims to adapt and evaluate a novel, scalable pre- surgical brief intervention for ADOL with substance use undergoing oral surgery (i.e. wisdom tooth extraction) that dually targets substance use and pain coping.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates contributes to increased rates of human infertility and reproductive disorders worldwide. The proposed research will fill a public health need by developing a method to investigate the mechanisms through which endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates act to cause toxicity in the ovary. The results of this project will facilitate the development of safer alternative chemicals and contribute to the identification of new treatments to protect the ovary from environmental chemical exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutics being developed for organophosphate (OP) poisoning have not been tested in juvenile animals, but infants and children are certainly likely to be poisoning victims in terrorist attacks or chemical accidents and are likely to be more vulnerable than adults. Therefore, a testing paradigm using juvenile animals is needed to provide useful information on the efficacy and safety of current therapeutics and therapeutics under development. This supplement application proposes to develop such a paradigm in juvenile rats (12 and 21 postnatal days equivalent to 3 and 7 years in humans) by investigating the levels and time frame of two OPs that are acutely toxic, and validating that the standard of care (atropine and an oxime reactivator) are effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-infectious uveitis causes 10% of blindness in the United States and disproportionately affects working- aged people, making it a significant public health issue. Targeted corticosteroid-sparing immune therapies are only variably effective because the underlying pathogenic mechanisms in ocular inflammation are not well understood. If successful, this research will address this knowledge gap and advance the NEI’s goals by: 1) developing advanced molecular diagnostic tools, 2) better defining heterogeneity within uveitis and 3) identifying the roles of specific immune mediators in individual inflammatory syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project is relevant to public health as it investigates the genomic and social determinants of health within a heterogeneous group of Latinx immigrants living within the United States. By understanding and honing in on the genotypic and environmental factors that cause differential adverse health outcomes within Cuban immigrants and Cuban-Americans, scientists, public health experts, community members, organizers, and policy makers can work collectively to change these conditions for the betterment of current and future immigrant populations and their descendants within the United States. Additionally, this work will also address how environmental factors including the social determinants of health are embodied within historically and currently marginalized groups through the use of epigenomics in conjunction with sociocultural approaches to understanding lived experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of neurodevelopmental delays (NDDs) in children has increased, therefore the identification of modifiable risk factors is of utmost importance. The inconclusive evidence on the associations between prenatal and early childhood environmental factors and NDDs and sensitive windows of exposure has been a barrier for the implementation of air pollutant regulations for pregnant women. Therefore, it is critical to accurately quantify the risks of NDDs from environmental exposures and identify vulnerable subpopulations based on socioeconomic status in a large cohort of pregnant women and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Development of an effective preventive vaccine is essential to achieve long-term immunity against HIV infection. A successful HIV vaccine will likely need to induce potent broadly neutralizing antibodies to circulating viral strains. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to increase numbers of clinical trials and observational cohort studies in Institutional Development Award (IDeA) states that currently have less than 10% of active NIH supported trials. Strategies to accomplish this goal include communicating to trial sponsors the expertise, quality, and capacity of IDeA state institutions to conduct clinical trials and to IDeA investigators available clinical trial opportunities. We will also train a cadre of skilled research coordinators across IDeA states to provide the necessary workforce capacity to conduct increased numbers of trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FROM PARENT Epilepsy surgery can result in seizure freedom in patients with drug-resistant epilepsy. Current clinical tools that guide surgical decisions are limited, in part due to an incomplete understanding of brain connectivity patterns in focal epilepsy. Using magnetic resonance imaging and intracranial recordings, we will develop new network- based tools that can be applied broadly at epilepsy centers to improve patient selection, outcome prediction, and localization of surgical targets in epilepsy surgery.

PHR: Project Narrative Endothelial cell migration and cell-cell interactions are fundamental processes mediating physiological angiogenesis and they are often dysregulated in human diseases. The proposed project will define how these processes regulated in time and space and identify components of this regulation. The proposed studies will reveal important factors regulating angiogenesis and guide future development of potential therapeutic strategies.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative Neuropathic pain is a major public health challenge and is inadequately addressed. The proposed research will identify the role of Ca2+/Calmodulin-dependent protein kinase (CaMKII) in dorsal root ganglion in chronic pain. Completion of the proposed program may lead to new therapeutic pathways for chronic pain by selectively reversing neuropathic pain-induced down-regulated CaMKII activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently developed a new non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) system, kilohertz transcranial magnetic perturbation (kTMP), that opens a new experimental space for safely modulating neural excitability in targeted areas of the human brain. This project will focus on testing the impact of AM-kTMP on a language task by targeting physiologically relevant frequencies to manipulate brain oscillations and speech perception. In addition, the supplementee will conduct customer discovery interviews to test and validate our costumers' segments and our value propositions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fertility requires many levels of interaction between males and females – at the level of gametes and their fates in the reproductive tract and at neural/behavioral levels – and their ultimate success varies dramatically with the genotype of the male and female involved. This variation affects the likelihood of a particular male siring offspring with a given female, due to interactions between male and female components that impact the handling of sperm within the female, and the regulation of genes in her brain. Our proposed studies with a tractable and sensitive model system will uncover the extent and mechanisms by which genetic variation can alter reproductive outcomes, and how these can be predicted analytically for given pairs of interacting animals.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered two new sperm incubation methods based on the regulation of intracellular calcium and metabolic pathways; these methods improve sperm functional parameters which increase the percentage eggs that can be fertilized in vitro and also improve early embryo development and pregnancy rates. From the basic science perspective, this proposal is aimed to understand at the molecular level how intracellular calcium and metabolism interact to enhance sperm function. From the applied point of view, accomplishment of these goals will provide tools for improving current Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) methods including in vitro fertilization and early embryo development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP) accounts for between 8 and 17% of all epilepsy-related deaths and, although our understanding of SUDEP is rudimentary, there is increasing evidence that respiratory arrest after a convulsive seizure is the primary cause in many cases. In support of this, we have found that seizure-induced apnea that occurs during the tonic phase and failure of postictal breathing recovery produce SUDEP in mouse models. Using novel mouse models of SUDEP, we propose to use chemogenetic, optogenetic, and electrophysiological techniques to elucidate the underlying neural circuitry that is recruited to cause seizure-induced apnea and SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Fear and anxiety underlie the most common forms of mental illness in the United States, with more than 30% of Americans experiencing an emotional disorder at some point in their life. Consequently, a major goal of NIH is to understand the neural mechanisms that underlie adaptive and maladaptive threat processing. The hippocampus and locus coeruleus both contribute to fear and anxiety, but it is not known how they interact during these states to promote the encoding of aversive memories. This represents a major gap in our understanding of the neural systems that contribute to emotional disorders. Altered catecholamine release by the locus coeruleus accompanies schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and ADHD, which are often comorbid with fear and anxiety disorders. Alzheimer’s disease also produces severe atrophy of the locus coeruleus, which reduces catecholamine release throughout the brain and is thought to exacerbate amnesia. To determine how altered catecholamine levels impact these disorders, it is essential to establish the basic mechanisms by which neuromodulatory inputs to the hippocampus regulate the formation of aversive memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will provide novel information on the role of microglia in disease mechanisms and neuronal dysfunction in C9orf72 patients clinically diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia (FTD). While microglia activation is known to occur in this patient population through postmortem autopsy studies, a much better understanding is needed regarding the extend of microglia-neuron co-regulation and the existence or absence of non-cell autonomous disease mechanisms similar to what has been described for astrocyte and motor neurons in other neurodegenerative diseases, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The proposed studies will provide novel opportunities for drug target identification and future drug discovery efforts with the hope of identifying novel therapeutics for these affected patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Much of human perception and behavior is governed by functioning brain networks. This project will develop a method for generating human cortico-striatal organoids from stem cells and demonstrate that these organoids can be used to model the development of human cortico-striatal networks. The ability to create patient-specific cortico-striatal organoids for use in a variety of laboratory analyses will provide a new approach to enable patient-specific diagnostics and treatments associated with disorders of cortico-striatal connectivity, including autism, schizophrenia, epilepsy, and mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Background parenchymal enhancement (BPE) is a promising new marker of breast cancer risk that has been studied almost exclusively using magnetic resonance imaging, an expensive screening modality that is indicated primarily for women with high risk of breast cancer. We propose here to measure BPE quantitatively using contrast-enhanced mammogram (CEM), a rapidly emerging screening modality that is more affordable and generalizable than MRI, and assess the potential of BPE measured on CEM as a marker of breast cancer risk. Our long-term goal is to use our new, objective measure of BPE on CEM to improve assessment of breast cancer risk, enabling personalization of breast cancer screening to detect breast cancer earlier and ultimately reduce breast cancer mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in medical and antiretroviral therapy, rates of cerebrovascular disease are increasing in people with HIV, and cognitive impairment and structural brain changes are still observed in treated people with HIV. These non-communicable complications of HIV threaten to put a significant strain on health systems in coming years, and will most affect low resource settings where rates of HIV are highest. The objective of this proposal is to understand the onset and pathophysiology of systemic and central nervous system vasculopathy in people with very early HIV infection, and to identify biomarkers of endothelial dysfunction that can be targeted for early interventions to improve cerebrovascular health in this population globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), the locus of the brain’s circadian clock, plays a critical role in mediating circadian rhythmicity of numerous important functions; these actions are achieved via a combination of hard-wired and diffusible signals. We recently identified a new portal system connecting the SCN and the organ vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT), which stands as a candidate route mediating diffusible signals from the SCN. Using a multidisciplinary approach in the proposed study, we will investigate the precise anatomical sources and targets of this novel portal system and determine directionality of blood flow and its regulation to generate novel information on mechanisms that mediate orchestration of circadian rhythmicity of multiple tissue targets by the SCN.

PHR: R01 ES035431_Administrative Supplement PI: Veress PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhalation of toxic chemicals often causes lung and heart abnormalities that develop and worsen over time after initial exposure in adult patients, while impacts of these exposures on children is not well characterized. In this project, we will study the long-term effects of in utero mustard gas and chlorine gas exposures on offspring born to inhalation exposed mother rats. The findings of this application will improve our understanding of heart and lung problems in a developing pediatric rat after in utero chemical exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Lay Abstract A collection of cognitive abnormalities is seen in people living with HIV, despite antiretroviral therapy. Yet, the underlying causes of such impairments are not completely understood. This proposal intends to test the novel hypothesis that HIV causes cognitive impairments by promoting the accumulation of amyloid beta through the envelope protein gp120. The main mechanisms that we will examine is the ability of gp120 to target the neurotrophin receptor p75, which has been shown to mediate amyloid beta accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Chronic inflammation underlies pathogenesis of HIV-associated neuropathology, but it remains unclear why it persists when HIV replication is suppressed by anti-retroviral treatment. Our studies suggest that HIV can induce a pro-inflammatory epigenetic memory in peripheral myeloid cells. In the proposed study, we will test whether this memory extends to brain cells and can explain neuroinflammation.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative It is imperative to train researchers in clinical, scientific and technological areas to advance the fields of Kidney, Urology and Hematology (KUH) towards bringing better understanding and management to KUH conditions and diseases. This program in North Carolina combines expertise and novel concepts in Training, Research, Innovation, and Outreach to form the NC KUH TRIO Program, bringing together six institutions across the state; 3 academic medical centers and 3 historically black universities that have strong science, technology, and engineering programs. TRIO will support pre- and post-doctoral trainees, providing them with innovative research tools and a professional development foundation to launch KUH research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project utilizes synthetic chemistry, microbiology, genetics, and proteomic methods to develop novel compounds to combat bacteria. This research will develop narrow-spectrum and antivirulence tool compounds as potential therapeutic agents that either inhibit growth or biofilm processes within pathogenic bacteria. The compounds are derived from natural product scaffolds isolated from regions rich in chemical diversity and bioactivity, which will undoubtedly shed light on the chemical underpinnings of these complex microbial communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In the proposed research we will examine the mechanisms by which memantine, one of the few drugs approved for treatment of Alzheimer's disease, protects nerve cells from damage. We will study how memantine works physiologically, use computer modeling and medicinal chemistry to design and synthesize new neuroprotective drugs, and use the new drugs to deepen understanding of neuroprotective strategies. The proposed research will examine a new approach for developing therapeutic drugs and will produce lead compounds for future development of improved medications to treat Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The principal goal of this project is to dissect and study the machinery that modulates RNA tailing and its effects on RNA stability and translation. These mechanisms will be explored during C. elegans oogenesis and early embryogenesis, taking advantage of the window of transcriptional inactivity when post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression is critical. In the process, this project will also identify essential genes for oogenesis and shed light on how their regulation is critical to their physiological function in the oocyte.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Teich, Andrew, Franklin Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the number one cause of dementia in the western world, and is a major cause of mortality and morbidity. Brain inflammation involving cells called microglia has recently been recognized as an important component of AD, although how microglia contribute to dementia is not completely clear. This proposal will lead to a better understanding of the types of microglia that are active in brain tissue from patients with early AD pathology, and link this to biomarkers in cerebral spinal fluid that may be useful for predicting clinical outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Leukodystrophies are inherited diseases that affect the white matter of the brain due to the loss or absence of myelin, the lipid membrane that insulates axons in the nervous systems. In collaboration with advocacy partners, we have successfully formed a research-based consortium, the Global Leukodystrophy Initiative Clinical Trials Network (GLIA-CTN), representing industry partners, advocacy groups and research scientists. The GLIA-CTN is developing a clinical trial readiness infrastructure across the leukodystrophies, enabling transformation of the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost half of all people diagnosed with HIV in the United States are older than 50 years and are expected to live near normal life expectancies given effective antiretroviral therapy; however, people aging with HIV are at increased risk for dementia, as well as depression and cardiovascular disease. In this project, we will develop a multimorbidity simulation model for dementia, depression, cardiovascular disease, and HIV and will use the model to project chronic disease outcomes, quality of life, and costs associated with aging. The overall goal is to investigate the long-term clinical and economic consequences of different strategies to reduce dementia and multimorbidity among people aging with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of innovative medical devices and technologies depends on a biomedical engineering workforce capable of identifying unmet clinical needs and working in teams to develop design solutions. Clinics in urban environments present unique health care issues, and this clinical immersion and team-based design program will challenge students to engage in engineering design in this context, with socioeconomic considerations in mind. The project will implement the novel INdiana Summer Clinical Residency in Innovation for Biomedical Engineers [(IN)SCRIBE] Program at Indiana University–Purdue University Indianapolis, in collaboration with the IU School of Medicine, to prepare biomedical engineering students for clinically-relevant, team-based design in an urban setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Although a strikingly similar spectrum of disease symptoms, including blindness and neurodegeneration, are associated with the misregulation of protein complexes critical for controlling gene expression and cytoskeletal organization, the mechanisms linking the regulation of these complexes are not well understood. Here, we leverage a newly identified regulatory axis between the gene regulatory complex “SAGA” and the cytoskeletal regulatory complex “WRC” to understand the molecular components involved in this regulatory pathway, the basic mechanisms of their co-regulation, and the major biological functions that depend on their interplay. These experiments will provide new insight into the underlying mechanisms contributing to blindness and neurodegeneration and inform the search for new therapeutics to treat these devastating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This five-year study aims to understand how social and structural determinants of health influence mobility patterns among adolescents and young adults living with HIV (AYA-HIV) in Tennessee, and how these patterns influence HIV care outcomes. Through a mixed-methods approach – integrating geospatial monitoring, in-depth interviews, population-level data, and clinical data – we will examine how personal and residential mobility affects HIV care outcomes. Elucidating these relationships will inform the development of targeted interventions to address disparities among mobile AYA-HIV and contribute to efforts to end the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The fellows and mentors trained by this program will contribute to short- and long-term improvements in global health. In collaboration with 21 low- and middle-income country institutions, fellows’ research will help develop clear and effective programs and policies to advance global public health, including care for HIV, other infectious diseases, noncommunicable diseases, global surgery, cancer, mental health and addiction, sexual and reproductive health, and planetary health.

Images of the retina will be obtained and analyzed using both traditional and novel methods to develop new potential measures of CADASIL that would be useful in clinical trials to select participants for study, to determine whether and when a treatment is working, and to better understand the underlying mechanisms of CADASIL.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The COVID-19 pandemic presents fundamental threats to dialysis patients. Over 16,000 of enrolled Veterans with ESKD receive VA-financed dialysis, 80% of whom receive this life-sustaining treatment through VA Community Care providers. Prior work found lower rates of survival among Veterans receiving dialysis exclusively in non-VA settings compared to VA dialysis, which may be due to fragmented and siloed care structures in community compared to the VA’s integrated healthcare system. Patients with kidney failure are particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 infection and related morbidity and mortality, are already prone to fragmented care, and especially susceptible to disrupted care. This study addresses an urgent need to examine the extent and impact of pandemic-related disruptions in care on disparities in outcomes among Veterans receiving dialysis treatment in VA and VA Community Care settings. Findings will inform how VA manages care for Veterans in disaster scenarios for this vulnerable and uniquely healthcare reliant population of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Persons living with HIV (PLWH) are 2-3 times more likely than the average population to use nicotine- containing products, and although nicotine use may improve HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND), it may also exacerbate neurobiological sequelae induced by HIV infection such as neuroinflammation despite use of anti-retroviral therapies (ART). The proposed research has the potential to uncover novel neurobiological mechanisms by which nicotine use alleviates some of the cognitive dysfunction associated with HIV infection but exacerbates neuroimmune dysregulations utilizing the EcoHIV virus in a rat model of nicotine use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative When a taste is placed on our tongues, we must recognize that a taste is on the tongue, identify that taste, decide whether it’s palatable or not, and then either swallow it or expel it. This thought process can be observed to play out in the firing of neurons in taste cortex, but evidence suggests that cortex doesn’t work alone. We will rigorously test how the amygdala (the seat of emotion in the brain) and hypothalamus (the center that controls hunger and thirst) work with cortex, and with one another, to make taste decisions happen, and how these decisions get implemented by motor circuits—adding to a systemic understanding of taste that will help us fight against a spectrum of feeding-related disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The purpose of the renewal of the Duke Autism Center of Excellence is to apply cutting-edge, translational digital health and computational methods to develop more effective tools for early autism screening and for objectively monitoring changes in children’s behavior, and to discover novel, brain-based biomarkers that can be used for stratification and to assess target engagement in clinical trials with young autistic children. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (PROJECT NARRATIVE) The proposed research will study the involvement of CCL2 in modulating monocyte recruitment to the BBB in the context of HIV infection as targets for stroke susceptibility. The central hypothesis is that that astrocyte- specific CCL2/CCR2 signaling modulates HIV-associated stroke severity and functional recovery by regulating monocyte recruitment to the BBB, inflammasome activation, and modulating innate immune responses. The findings resulting from this proposal will help to identify promising new therapeutic targets in ischemic stroke associated with HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite strong consensus that early, specialized intervention for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) can have a dramatic impact on outcomes, the public health system’s capacity to provide such services is severely challenged by the rapid rise in ASD prevalence. The goal of this research is to increase timely and equitable access to ASD-specialized early intervention during the critical first three years of life by capitalizing on the existing infrastructure of the Part C Early Intervention (EI) system, which is publicly funded and available in all U.S. States. This project will train EI providers to use an evidence-based, inexpensive, parent-mediated intervention that can improve child and family outcomes as well as mitigate the substantial economic costs associated with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latino/a/e (“Latine”) sexual and gender minority persons (SGM), specifically men and transgender women who have sex with men, face inequities in HIV prevention and treatment outcomes. Although strategies for Ending the HIV Epidemic in the United States recognize that stigma and discrimination at multiple levels shape such inequities, research on structural stigmatization and discrimination has been hampered by measurement challenges. Our project aims to develop, validate, and apply state-level measures of structural stigmatization and discrimination for Latine and SGM populations that can be applied to health equity research across multiple conditions.

PHR: Project Narrative: This study investigates the disruptions and displacement effects of natural events and their influence on HIV treatment continuity and mental health in Puerto Rico (PR) using electronic health records. It also explores the role of social networks in HIV care and mental health continuity during natural events, aiming to develop an intervention prototype with implementation and dissemination recommendations based on findings. Dr. Casanova will acquire training in longitudinal analysis, social network analysis, and intervention design for achieving these research aims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Newly formed probation services in Eastern Europe, where the HIV epidemic continues to expand, provide a unique opportunity to reduce HIV transmission by linking people with opioid use disorder to opioid agonist therapy (OAT) while promoting decarceration efforts. Dr. Azbel's two proposed research aims use the EPIS framework to understand the influence of the inner (clients, officers, criminal subculture) and outer contexts (probation leadership and OAT clinic staff), as organizational process changes are introduced via NIATx, on the implementation of a screening-engagement-treatment (SET) strategy for OAT scale-up among probation clients in Georgia and Moldova. This K01 seeks support for enhanced coursework, seminars, interdisciplinary mentorship, and research experience to bolster the candidate’s ability to emerge as an independent researcher, leveraging newly acquired training in ethnography, implementation science, and mixed methods to inform implementation strategies of evidence-based HIV prevention practices in community supervision settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-HIV broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) demonstrate potential for effective virus suppression and reservoir depletion when used early in conjunction with combined antiretroviral therapy (cART), which provides effective treatment for infants. However, their effectiveness in deep tissue reservoirs, particularly in targeting infections within the central nervous system (CNS), is limited due to insufficient concentrations caused by the blood-brain barrier. We propose a novel nanotechnology approach, called 'nanocapsules,' designed to enhance the delivery of bNAbs directly to the CNS, potentially leading to the remission of HIV from CNS reservoirs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent literature indicates that people living with HIV are more likely to be smokers, use substances at higher rates, derive less benefit from antiretroviral therapy, report significantly poorer medication adherence, and have poorer clinical outcomes for many non-AIDS related conditions (e.g., lung cancer, cardiovascular disease). However, engagement in evidence-based behavioral interventions may work to address some of these negative outcomes. The present K24 proposal would allow me to accommodate increasing requests for mentorship from trainees and junior faculty, as well as provide an additional platform for involving my mentees in substance use bio-behavioral research in the context of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol use is associated with increased respiratory symptom burden in people living with HIV (PLWH), and alcohol increases the risk of sepsis and multimorbidity of the lungs and liver in PLWH. In this proposal, the PI will determine if alcohol and HIV induce apoptosis of lung immune cells, alveolar macrophages, and promote the release of extracellular vesicles which impair alveolar epithelial barrier function, causing lung leak, and potentiate liver injury; thereby exacerbating lung injury. The findings from the study will not only identify potential treatment strategies for PLWH with AUD but also raise awareness of the impact of alcohol misuse on HIV-induced multi-organ damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We propose to create an approach for directly regulating the transfer of electrical information across neural circuits that encode emotions. After creating this new method for rewiring synapses, we will deploy it in animal models of psychiatric disorders. Thus, our high-risk research has the potential to yield a new therapeutic strategy for treating mental illnesses such as depression, anxiety, and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 45% of people living with HIV (PLWH) in the United States are over 50 years old and at heightened risk of aging-related comorbidities. The goal of this exploratory grant is to investigate whether the hyperactivation of the autophagy pathway can delay age-related phenotypes and cognitive decline in HIV-infected adult and old mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common and lethal form of the fibrotic lung diseases that is associated with loss/dysfunction of lung stem cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This research study will examine how alcohol associated gut dysbiosis may lead to harmful downstream health effects, i.e., inflammation, CVD, and excess mortality, among PWH who are hazardous drinkers. By conducting whole genome sequencing on the gut microbiota within three rich existing cohorts, the study will be able to address this important public health question in a cost-effective and innovative manner. Results will inform precision medicine approaches targeting gut dysbiosis as an intervention for CVD, inflammation, etc., in PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Floyd, Thomas NARRATIVE  There is growing awareness that survival and neurologic outcomes in patients experiencing intracranial hypertension after traumatic brain injury, severe stroke, or cerebral hemorrhage may be improved by strategies that focus on improving cerebral oxygenation and oxygen utilization. Currently available devices for monitoring cerebral oxygenation are extremely limited in their accuracy and have yet to demonstrate clinical efficacy. We are developing a minimally invasive brain device, FLOXBR, that measures blood flow and oxygenation and which may offer significant improvements over current technology in accuracy and clinical efficacy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this mixed methods randomized controlled trial is to test the integrated nurse-led intervention bundle for family home care management of end-stage heart failure and palliative care in rural Appalachia. This intervention bundle is designed to address rural disparities in access to health care, with the help of the faith- based nurses and local volunteer visiting neighbors. Focus group research is used to determine plans for sustaining the bundle implementation, maintaining rural volunteers, and coordinating administrative aspects of the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with rare and undiagnosed conditions often face significant challenges in receiving proper diagnosis and care and accessing research opportunities, resulting in poor outcomes and straining healthcare resources. Through this project, we aim to leverage implementation science frameworks to extend the reach of the Undiagnosed Diseases Network (UDN), improve access for underserved communities, develop technical solutions tailored to the needs of the undiagnosed and rare disease community, and ensure ongoing research and care continuity for participants awaiting diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: DNA replication restart is an important process to study from a human health perspective because knowing more about how DNA is properly maintained will help to identify targets to kill selectively the deleterious, malignant or disease-causing cells that may plague our bodies (cancer and pathogenic organisms). Conversely, this knowledge may also help to augment basic health and longevity of our bodies by the design of better antibiotics. This may be translated into a longer, healthier life for individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - PARENT GRANT (7/1/18 to 5/31/24) People aged 90 and older (the oldest-old) are the fastest growing segment of the population and have the highest rates of dementia. Many oldest old individuals, however, maintain superior cognitive performance (cognitive resilience) often despite the presence of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and other neuropathologic changes. With clinical, imaging, and pathological investigations, our goal is to identify lifestyle and other factors that contribute to resilience in this understudied and unique segment of the population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Signaling between cells encodes spatiotemporal information crucial both for development and homeostasis, and when dysregulated, results in developmental syndromes or diseases throughout the lifespan. Vertebral segmentation is jointly controlled by the segmentation clock and FGF/ERK signaling gradient. Understanding how the clock oscillations and signaling gradient are integrated and how cells decode this information are needed to decipher the etiology of vertebral malformations and build precisely patterned organoids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein synthesis is a major pathway targeted by antibiotics, and the rise of multi-drug resistant bacteria calls for further understanding of the translational machinery to improve current antimicrobial treatment. Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica cause over a million illnesses and tens of thousands of hospitalizations annually in the United States alone. Our work will provide insights into adaptation of such bacterial pathogens during stress conditions and facilitate development of novel antimicrobial strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed K01 career development and research activities merge intervention science with phylogenetic analysis to address the co-occurring epidemics of HIV, hepatitis C, and opioid use among people who inject drugs along the Texas-Mexico Border. Research activities are guided by the Multiphase Optimization Strategy (MOST) Preparation Phase including formative intervention development activities and a feasibility and acceptability trail using a factorial experiment design. Our trial will lay the foundation for a full-scale MOST trial in the future that tests four intervention components that aim to reduce drug use, promote HIV prevention, and increase HCV cure, with phylogenetic analysis conducted in parallel to determine sub-optimal HCV treatment outcomes and transmission networks. Proposed training and research activities will provide a platform to launch an early-stage investigator’s long-term career in intervention science and novel biomarker research.

PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section African Americans are 60% more likely to develop T2D than non-Hispanic whites, even after correction for obesity and lifestyle factors. A sequence variant rs142619613 that occurs mainly in African Americans contributes to hepatic insulin resistance, hyperglycemia and metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD). These findings aim to bridge the knowledge gap on T2D disparities among African Americans and introduce a novel therapeutic target for both disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Joint pain and stiffness associated with osteoarthritis and synovial fibrosis affects a large population of active duty military and veterans with an incidence higher than the general public, and the research goal of this proposal is to test a non-surgical intervention to alleviate joint stiffness and protect the joint’s cartilage surfaces. By targeting synovial cell contractility, or how much a cell pulls on its local environment, we introduce a therapy that can both mitigate fibrotic cell differentiation and restore lubricant expression in joints. Overall, this work has the potential to introduce a new treatment option for veterans experiencing joint pain and stiffness that can delay surgical intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The Epicenter for Emerging Infectious Disease Intelligence will establish research hubs in the Amazon and Congo Basin forest for emerging infectious disease research, building on our demonstrated commitment to capacity strengthening in these regions. Our proposed research will enhance surveillance for arboviruses and filoviruses in acute febrile illness cases, vectors, and vertebrate hosts that are perpetuating transmission in forest and urban systems. This work will advance an understanding of cross-species transmission dynamics for emerging viral threats, as well as optimize innovative and deployable surveillance and testing strategies to strengthen infectious disease surveillance and enable rapid response to outbreaks as part of the Emerging Infectious Disease Research Center network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: We propose to conduct research that will determine the impact of relevant behaviors on HIV prevention among Young Black Sexual Minority Men (YBSMM), such as heavy cannabis use. We propose to explore mechanisms, specifically neurocognitive impacts of heavy cannabis use, linking heavy cannabis use to HIV prevention outcomes (and particularly PrEP use), and whether motivations for cannabis use, amidst a changing cannabis regulatory, social acceptance and legal landscape, modify its effects on HIV prevention. Identifying neurocognitive mechanisms through which cannabis use affects HIV prevention and the importance of motivations for cannabis use in understanding clinical outcomes will provide targets for future HIV prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) The Society of Behavioral Medicine’s 45th Annual Meeting & Scientific Sessions, to be held March 13-16, 2024, in Philadelphia, PA, will bring together 1,800 of the nation’s leading behavioral scientists, clinicians, educators, and policymakers to exchange new research on improving health through behavior change, in particular by moving behavioral science upstream. Through a broad range of scientific presentations, discussions, and skill-building workshops, the meeting will facilitate the exchange of the latest population‐level, clinic‐based, and experimental research on the prevention and treatment of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality, with the goals of improving health behaviors, reducing the burden of chronic disease, improving health inequities, lowering healthcare costs, and bettering our nation’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL COMPONENT This program project grant (PPG), called the AIRHEALTH study(Air pollution disrupts Inflammasome Regulation in Heart and Lung Total Health) we will use novel and powerful biotechnologies to uncover the complex of IL-1β and other cellular pathways involved in pollution-associated pathology of the cardiopulmonary system. Understanding the contribution of inflammatory markers to these important public health diseases will lead to the development and application of new ways of preventing and treating air-pollution associated diseases of the pulmonary and cardiovascular systems. By utilizing already collected human samples from individuals of different ethnicities, ages, and genders, we will determine how these factors affect the toxicity response to air pollution, further facilitating personalized medicine.

PHR: Project Narrative This funding is critical for the preservation and continuation of support for these unique cohorts that provide invaluable participant samples to forward the strategic scientific goals of the PAVE MDC. At the time of the UM1 application, we were fortunate that these investigator-initiated cohorts were supported by individual R01 grant funding or the EPIICAL Consortium funded by ViiV Healthcare. The request is for consideration to support three existing cohorts within PAVE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative COVID-19 is increasingly recognized as a risk factor for vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia, VCID. The mechanisms by which COVID-19 promotes vascular dementia are unclear. Our proposed research using mechanistic mouse models will investigate how modifications to brain endothelial cells caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection can promote development of vascular dementia by destabilizing the blood-brain barrier. These studies will establish novel targetable mechanisms to prevent or treat vascular dementia after infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Traffic related air pollution (TRAP) is strongly associated with an increased risk for neurodegenerative disease, such as Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD); however, since TRAP is a complex mixture of particulate matter (PM) and gases, it is not known which component is primarily responsible for promoting neurodegenerative disease, or how it does so. One goal of this Diversity supplement is to investigate the relative neurotoxicity of TRAP-derived PM vs. gases, the role of microglia in mediating the neurotoxic effects of TRAP, and the influence of sex and genotype on microglial response to TRAP. A second goal is to increase the diversity of the scientific community with the training needed to conduct rigorous scientific research focused on identifying and understanding environmental risk factors associated with neurodegenerative diseases in order to develop strategies for promoting healthy brain aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Estrogen receptor gene (ESR1) mutations are found at up to 38% frequency in metastatic breast cancer, and exhibit resistance to endocrine therapy (ET), limiting durable clinical management of the disease. This project will investigate the transcriptional and clonal evolution of ESR1 mutations in metastatic and ET-resistant disease using a combination of bioinformatics and experimental validation. There are currently no approved therapies specific for ESR1 mutant breast cancer, and this proposal lays essential groundwork for mutant- specific therapeutic targeting to prolong metastasis-free survival and ET sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasingly, prevention-minded gerontologists and geroscientists look to midlife as the life stage offering a terrific opportunity to prevent or delay the multiple diseases that shrink older adults’ health span, and they call for more knowledge about aging during midlife. We propose to follow up at age 52 a cohort of 1037 infants studied since birth, the Dunedin Study, to quantify how fast or slowly each cohort member is aging in each of 8 different life domains: the pace of biological aging, functional aging, facial aging, social aging, sexual aging, inflammatory aging, microvascular aging, and cognitive aging (Aim 1). We will generate new knowledge about the early-life antecedents of each of the 8 kinds of aging (Aim 2), and about the risk each kind of aging poses for late-life disease (Aim 3), and we will export to the field DNAmethylation blood-test measures of 8 kinds of aging.

PHR: Project Narrative: Overall The overall objective of the Penn State TCORS is to provide a science base for reducing the harm from tobacco products. We are pursuing the Food and Drug Administration’s Comprehensive Plan for Tobacco and Nicotine Regulation by determining the toxicity of aerosols, smoke, and oral exposures of tobacco products that may be used as substitutions for cigarettes. This includes identifying the specific characteristics of non- cigarette products that can be regulated to reduce harm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Notch signaling pathway has been implicated in a wide range of biological and pathological processes. Using the Drosophila ovarian model, the proposed studies will lead to improved understanding of the diverse effects and regulatory mechanisms of Notch signaling during development and tissue homeostasis. The findings from the proposed studies will help designing new therapeutic strategies for diseases related to aberrant Notch signaling.
