IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative There is a public health need to develop novel, culturally adapted interventions to reduce alcohol consumption among Latinx hazardous drinkers with comorbid clinical anxiety. The proposed R01 study will draw upon National Institutes of Health (NIH) treatment development guidelines (Stage 1) to translate and innovate past work to address a major public health priority. Specifically, we propose to develop (Phase IA) and test (Phase IB) the effectiveness of a brief, integrated, single-session, computer-based, culturally adapted personalized feedback intervention (PFI) designed to enhance knowledge regarding adverse anxiety-alcohol interrelations, increase motivation and intention to reduce hazardous drinking, and reduce positive attitudes and intention regarding anxiety-related alcohol use among Latinx hazardous drinkers with anxiety within community-based health clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Having health workers assist HIV-infected persons with the recruitment and testing of their sexual contacts and biological children is an effective and efficient way of identifying persons in need of HIV treatment and prevention. However, in Malawi, a country with a generalized HIV epidemic, health workers lack the counseling and coordination skills to routinely assist their HIV-infected clients with these services. This study will determine how to help health workers in Malawi to provide these services through a set of digital capacity-building tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative In recent years it has become increasingly evident that the gut microbiome, the resident population of bacteria in the intestines, plays a key role in health and homeostasis throughout the body including the brain. Our laboratory has found that changes in the gut microbiome can alter the development of drug craving in animal models of relapse and affect how genes are expressed in the brain. These studies will identify how specific manipulations of the microbiome and its molecular byproducts affect brain and behavior, and will provide strategies for targeting the gut microbiome to reduce substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mucins are a protein found in natural saliva that provide lubrication, create a protective shield against harmful acids, and play a role in maintaining the balance of the oral microbiome. This project aims to produce artificial mucins that emulate the physicochemical properties and functions of their natural counterparts found in human saliva, which can offer relief to patients afflicted with dry mouth disease. The materials will be optimized to prevent acid erosion of tooth enamel and promote beneficial microbial colonization to promote healthy oral environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Title: Barriers and facilitators of cancer care and financial burden of cancer care in Kinshasa, the Democratic Republic of the Congo PROJECT NARRATIVE Growing cancer morbidity and mortality is a major public health problem in the Democratic Republic of Congo, yet there is lack of data on barriers to cancer care and its cost for cancer patients. This mixed- method study will identify factors associated with access to and adherence to cancer care and the economic burden of care for patients living with and without HIV. Title: Leveraging Existing Infrastructures and Expertise to Enhance Cancer Control in sub-Saharan Africa PROJECT NARRATIVE Sub-Saharan Africa faces a critical lack of reliable cancer data, despite a concerning shift in cancer profiles mirroring trends observed in high-income nations. This supplement seeks to address this significant gap by establishing cancer registries in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burundi, and Cameroon. These registries will provide governments with essential data, crucial for informed decision-making in cancer control. Additionally, they will facilitate the tracking of adverse clinical outcomes in people living with HIV, a challenge with current data limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The principal aim of this administrative supplement is to complete the analysis by SIMOA biofluid markers and compare with lipidome signature in a transversal case-control study of Alzheimer's disease. It will allow to successfully validate and broaden the understanding of early biomarkers in individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD), focusing on those carrying genetic mutations with high penetrance and susceptibility gene variants and the common pattern with sporadic cases, for future clinical research studies about early detection, pronostic, diagnosis, prevention and treatment of AD and other neurodegenerative diseases at the LatinAmerican region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: BRAIN GLUCOSE DEFICIENCY: MECHANISMS AND MODULATION. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE. Pathogenic mutations of the brain glucose transporter type I lead to glucose transporter deficiency syndrome (G1D), which is most often associated with medication-refractory epilepsy and movement dysfunction. At present, G1D is only alleviated by interventions such as the ketogenic diet, which can be poorly tolerated and afford only an incomplete restoration of neural function. A better understanding of G1D fulfills the NIH mission by uncovering new fundamental aspects of brain function while facilitating the development of new therapies aimed to restore brain metabolism and excitability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Administrative Supplement to Genetic Basis of Cannabis Use Disorder and Cannabinoid Response in Humans Cannabis use (CanUD) and major depressive disorder (MDD) frequently co-occur and have negative consequences including lost productivity, functional impairment, and suicide risk. We propose a carefully- designed training plan that incorporates translational research to study the genetic underpinnings of CanUD and MDD and learn how genetic risk for MDD may predict response to laboratory administration of cannabis, cannabis derivatives, and CanUD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: High blood pressure is the most prevalent modifiable risk factor for dementia and cardiovascular disease among older adults in the United States; however, clinic-based blood pressure measurement is inaccessible to many older adults, especially in the COVID-19 era, often delaying hypertension diagnosis and treatment. While home- based blood pressure measures show promise for overcoming access barriers and promoting more timely treatment, there is a dearth of evidence informing the clinical interpretation of these measurements inolder adults in the United States, a population characterized by high blood pressure variability and discordance from clinic- based blood pressure. Our proposal will perform home blood pressure monitoring and 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring assessments in over 2,100 community-dwelling adults, aged 80-100 years, establishing the measurement performance, prognostic utility (for dementia and cardiovascular disease), and clinical interpretation of home-based blood pressure measurements in this vulnerable population in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative NIAMS Diversity Supplement 2024-2026 The Molecular Basis of Altered Natural Kill Cells in Systemic Sclerosis-associated Interstitial Lung Disease Scleroderma is a devastating autoimmune disease with interstitial lung disease, a leading cause of death in patients and for which limited, effective therapies are available. This project will study natural killer (NK) cells, an immune cell that may be contributing to scleroderma associated- interstitial lung disease (SSc-ILD). By studying how genes of interest from NK cells turn on in scleroderma lung tissue compared to healthy control lung, we will gain further understanding about how NK cells cause lung damage and scarring in scleroderma as well as discover potential molecules to target for new treatment in SSc-ILD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The CHAMPS study seeks to address a critical gap in cancer care delivery for people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWH) in Botswana, a country facing significant burdens of both cancer and HIV/AIDS. By investigating barriers and facilitators in the cancer care cascade and assessing the acceptability and feasibility of peer support intervention using expert clients, this research aims to improve access to cancer care for PLWH, ultimately reducing morbidity and mortality in this population. The findings will inform evidence-based interventions and policies, contributing to improved health outcomes and quality of life for PLWH co-diagnosed with cancer in Botswana and similar resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Enhancing Real-World Data with Measures of Social Determinants of Health project will facilitate the use of real-world data (RWD) across NCI Persistent Poverty Initiative Centers, encouraging collaborative initiatives that harness RWD to understand and address structural and social determinants of health that drive cancer inequalities in persistent poverty areas. First, we will create measures of the most commonly used social deprivation indexes, and area-based measures of structural racism, and make these measures publicly available with code and documentation for how they are created. Next, we will use new artificial intelligence approaches to create synthetic versions of SEER-Medicare data, and make this available to researchers at NCI Persistent Poverty Initiative Centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Magnetic Resonance Facility at Madison (NMRFAM) research resource provides access to state- of-the-art solution and solid-state NMR technology to the biomedical research community, enabling facility users to leverage the power and diversity of NMR methods to study the structure, dynamics, function and interactions of large and small biomolecules. NMRFAM will continue to provide reliable and timely access to NMR instrumentation with excellent staff support for all phases of the NMR experience, in order to engage actively in experiment design well aligned with user objectives, to obtain the highest quality data possible and to commit to interpreting results to solve highly significant biomedical research problems that are best addressed by NMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Individuals suffering from substance use disorders are susceptible to relapse when presented with  contextual cues, suggesting that contextual memories associated with drugs of abuse impede abstinence  success. PHR: Contact PD/PI: Jackson, Daniel J. PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma disproportionately affects children in urban communities in the United States and imposes a great personal and health care burden. Despite treatment advances, a significant proportion of patients do not achieve disease control and continue to have high levels of morbidity and currently no intervention has proven to either prevent or cure this disease. By identifying and addressing these unmet needs in this application, we propose to improve current asthma care in urban children, pursue disease modification, and ultimately develop effective strategies to prevent asthma.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: Multiple sclerosis is a devastating disease that inflicts sensory, motor and cognitive deficits on thousands of US veterans. Currently, there is no cure and the available therapies have variable results. MS is classically described as a demyelinating disease; However, more recent work has demonstrated that much of the irre- versible functional loss associated with this disease results from pathology of the nerve cell. Although nerve cell damage is now being investigated, it is being studied strictly as a consequence of chronic demyelination. Our previous work showed that the nerve cell is a primary target of attack and implicated the resident brain immune cells known as microglia as the facilitator of the attack. Here, we will investigate a novel factor that is may be critical for this attack and determine if this factor can be a therapeutic target for disease amelioration.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This study is intended to correct an important systemic deficit in the care of chronic kidney disease (CKD), VHA’s fourth most common healthcare condition with high mortality and healthcare burden. Currently, many Veterans with CKD have poor awareness of their condition. This leads to suboptimal care. We anticipate that our proposed comprehensive pre-end stage renal disease (ESRD) education (CPE) will enhance Veterans’ CKD knowledge and their confidence in making an informed selection of an appropriate dialysis modality, and lead to an increase in the use of home dialysis (HoD) – an evidence-based, yet underutilized dialysis modality. Further, this study will allow us to examine whether such Veteran-informed dialysis choice can improve Veteran and health services outcomes. If successful, this study may deliver a ready to roll-out strategy to meet the CKD care needs of the Veterans and reduce VHA healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The focus of this Collaborative MERIT Application is to better understand how environmental toxins veterans were exposed to during the Gulf War (GW) may have uniquely sensitized the neuroimmune system to subsequent insults, rendering them at risk for eliciting amplified or persistent neuroinflammatory or immune responses when subjected to psychological stressors. Through this project, we plan to execute experiments that will investigate if GW toxins amplify immune responses to psychological stressors, if this process is a function of transcriptional priming of the NLRP3 inflammasome, and if we can selectively target the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome to attenuate neuroinflammatory responses. By investigating these mechanisms, we hope to identify novel therapeutic methods that may provide veterans of the Gulf War both interventional and preventative options to help manage GWVI symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 1 in 5 US children experiences a communication disorder before age 6, causing long-term social, emotional, behavioral, academic, physical health, and mental health risks. Early Intervention improves outcomes; however, children from racial, ethnic, and/or linguistic minority populations, including those living in rural areas and/or poverty, have less access to timely, accurate identification and high-quality communication disorder treatment. Using stakeholder engagement methods and data from over 100,000 children in five states, we will identify key sources of structural racism and discrimination for children with communication disorders in the Early Intervention system and use findings to develop actionable practice and policy recommendations.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks the establishment of the Puerto Rico Racial & Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (PR-REACH) to support the advancement of Hispanic Puerto Ricans health equity, this is a first step in a research agenda to collaborate with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Office of Minority Health and Health Equity (OMHHE) across REACH research projects and activities by first building an administrative research and communication infrastructure; leadership team, three EQUITY research cores (Clinical Trials, Voices and Data), a training and mentoring core, and an advisory team. A pilot study under this consortium will be conducted to advance the understanding of substance use disorder patients’ journey as perspectives, preferences and unmet needs regarding substance use disorder (SUD) treatment with FDA approved medications in PR to be able to improve its outcomes and launch PR-REACH in PR. The PR-REACH will initiate with Hispanics living in Puerto Rico as a model than can inform and guide subsequent extrapolation to Hispanics in the US in collaboration with the FDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and rurality is associated with worse COPD prevalence and outcomes. This application aims to test the uptake, effectiveness, and patient-caregiver-provider experience of a crucial treatment not provided in rural areas: pulmonary rehabilitation. The proposed intervention will provide home-based pulmonary rehabilitation to every patient recruited and will address access to care as SDOH and two aspects of social injustice in COPD: inadequate COPD care and lack of support for rural patients.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Three sentences   With a collaborative approach grounded in Indigenous core cultural values, the Indigenous Innovators Collaborative (IIC) team will engage in community-based participatory research study to address the FDA priorities as outlined in FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award: Racial and Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) funding opportunity. The IIC seeks to engage American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) communities, stakeholders, researchers in an exploration of clinical trials and promote cultural knowledge in understanding clinical trials in Indian Country. One of the fundamental goals of this study is to aid in identifying perceptions of clinical trials and gene therapy within the Native American population.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC), a heterogenous cholestatic condition often leading to multi-focal stricturing due to progressive constriction and blockage of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts, is an autoimmune liver disease characterized by slow but persistent inflammation and fibrosis surrounding the bile ducts which can result in the development of malignancy in up to 20% of cases. Although there are some pharmacotherapies being used to support PSC management, there are no regulatory approved therapies for the disease which has resulted in PSC having the highest rate of liver transplantation amongst all autoimmune liver diseases. In this project, Perspectum seeks to complete the necessary evidence to qualify the MRCP+ biomarker number of strictures as a monitoring biomarker, used in conjunction with clinical risk factors, by evaluating disease progression in a PSC population.

PROJECT_TITLE: DDT-BMQ-000146 Assessing clinically meaningful change in PSC as determined by quantitative MRCP (MRCP+) measured number of strictures

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence (IPV) includes assault to the head, neck, and face, with approximately 90% of survivors reporting symptoms concordant with persistent post-concussion symptoms, wherein pregnancy is associated with increased intensity and frequency of physical assault. Like stress, drugs, and inflammation, traumatic brain injury (TBI) during pregnancy, from IPV, falls, motor vehicle accidents, can increase the environmental risk for neurodevelopmental disorders in the children. The proposal extends strong proof-of-principle results to explore the outcomes of gravida TBI – TBI during pregnancy – in mice on the neurobehavioral, neurocircuitry, and molecular phenotypes of offspring to better inform science, education, and policy making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Up to 60% of African Americans, who are at heightened risk for kidney and cardiovascular disease (CVD), carry at least one Apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) coding change variant allele. These variants associate with adverse renal and CVD outcomes—particularly in chronic inflammatory disease such as SLE. By leveraging SLE monocyte transcriptional profiles validated by primary cell culture models, this study will test the overall hypothesis that immune activation and resultant increased APOL1 expression synergizes with APOL1 genotype to precipitate human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Filaments made of beta and gamma actin are proteins that provide the shape and stability of structures known as stereocilia within the inner ear. Stereocilia detect vibrations and convert them into electrical signals that the brain eventually comprehends as sound or head movement. This project centers around how a specific gamma actin mutation alters the structure and stability of the stereocilia to understand its associated hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myeloid cells promote chronic inflammation during HIV, that is not suppressed by antiviral therapies, and is a major risk factor for the development of comorbid diseases. We propose to evaluate the anti-inflammatory potential of the phytocannabinoid cannabidiol (CBD) in a rhesus macaque animal model of HIV infection. We anticipate our work will increase understanding of the biological mechanisms by which chronic CBD affects persistent inflammation and the endocannabinoid system in the context of antiretroviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human socioeconomic status is one of the strongest predictors of health and mortality, however little is known regarding the neurobiological mechanisms predisposing individuals of low social status to neuropsychiatric disorders such as alcohol use disorder. This proposal will determine if social anxiety underlies social rank and social isolation-associated alcohol drinking and if amygdala or cortical glial activation is predictive of this behavior. The findings will advance our conceptual framework for neuroimmune regulation of circuits and behavioral factors underlying social rank and isolation-associated alcohol drinking.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive disease of increasing cognitive impairment leading to dementia that impacts the ability of people living with AD to function independently and carry out activities of daily living (e.g., household chores and personal care); however, current endpoint measures in AD clinical trials are not sensitive at early stages of the disease and provide inadequate measurement of cognition-dependent day-to-day functioning. The overall objective of this project is to prepare and submit a Qualification Plan to support the qualification of the Virtual Reality Functional Capacity Assessment Tool – Short List for use as a performance outcome measure of day-to-day functioning (based on evaluation of cognition-dependent instrumental activities of daily living) among individuals diagnosed with Stage 2 and Stage 3 AD. The impact of this work will be the advancement of a publicly available, psychometrically sound measure of cognition-dependent day-to-day functioning that can be used in AD treatment trials to better assess and understand the impact of new treatments on performance of tasks that reflect essential aspects of day-to-day functioning in individuals with Stage 2 and Stage 3 biomarker-positive AD.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development of a Qualification Plan for the Virtual Reality Functional Capacity Assessment Tool - Short List (VRFCAT-SLx) (DDT COA #000004)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Although bilingualism is common among children in the U.S., there is little research examining the language development of bilingual children with hearing loss. This Administrative Diversity Supplement will train a Latina, bilingual post-baccalaureate researcher to transcribe the content of preschool children’s English and Spanish language use, assess the reliability of automated methods of transcription, and assist in interpreting project analyses to characterize the content of bilingual language of preschoolers with and without hearing loss. These efforts will pave the way for classroom-based interventions to enhance the language development of bilingual children with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE Heart failure is a major worldwide health problem associated with signs and symptoms such as breathlessness with exertion, shortness of breath, fatigue, tiredness or weakness, difficulty breathing when lying down, sleeping problems, swollen legs or ankles, and weight gain, which can negatively impact health-related quality of life and physical function. The ability to properly assess symptoms in persons with heart failure is important in order to evaluate the effectiveness of therapies, inform clinical decision-making, and improve patient-centered outcomes beyond the more traditional measures of hospitalization and mortality; therefore, the overall objective of this project is to conduct quantitative analyses of an existing cross-sectional dataset and prepare a quantitative study report to support the qualification of the Chronic Heart Failure Symptom Scale (CHF-SS) as a patient-reported outcome (PRO) measure of chronic heart failure (CHF) symptom severity in individuals diagnosed with CHF. Although multiple clinical outcome assessments (COAs), specifically PRO measures, have been developed and tested against the scientific processes of their time and widely used in evaluating heart failure interventions, they each present their own limitations with respect to the recent FDA COA-related guidances; given these limitations, qualifying the CHF-SS will fill a critical gap as a publicly available, psychometrically sound measure of symptom severity in CHF treatment trials according to the most recent, rigorous standards and best practices for developing fit-for-purpose COAs for regulatory decision making.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Psychometric Analyses and Quantitative Study Report for Qualification of the Chronic Heart Failure Symptom Scale (CHF-SS) (DDT COA #000112)

Analysis of social determinants of behavioral and mental health outcomes for young adults able to abstain from alcohol for a month will assist in understanding potential differences across socioeconomic status and race/ ethnic groups.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following guidance from the FDA for biomarker development we aim to qualify the change in bone mineral density (BMD) as a surrogate endpoint for osteoporotic fractures in future drug development, thereby facilitating smaller and shorter trials, greatly decreasing drug development costs. We have compiled individual patient data from >50 clinical trials in osteoporosis, and to date, our analyses reveal a strong relationship between larger increases in BMD and greater fracture reductions. Working with the FDA, we have submitted our Full Qualification Package, the final step in the biomarker qualification process, with the goal to obtain the first-ever formal approval of a surrogate endpoint marker under the new FDA guidelines.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DDT-BMQ-000054: Planning for biomarker qualification, implementation and dissemination for BMD as a surrogate biomarker in future osteoporosis treatment trials: the SABRE project

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive disease caused by functional and structural changes in the pulmonary vasculature, which lead to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and eventually right ventricular failure and death. Despite recent advances, there remains a need for improved understanding of PAH pathophysiology and a need for improved therapeutic options for these patients, as current therapies are severely limited. The cytokine/enzyme, nicotinamide phosphoribosyl-transferase (NAMPT) binds to TLR4 to promote vascular cell resistance to apoptosis, cell proliferation, and smooth muscle cell survival, all processes implicated in pulmonary vascular remodeling; therefore, we hypothesize that eNAMPT is an important therapeutic target in PAH pathobiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This competitive renewal RO1 application aims to further dissect the mechanisms by which hydrogen sulfide, a novel uterine artery dilator we pioneered the last funding cycle, utilizes to mediate estrogen- induced uterine vasodilatation in normal pregnancy and how these mechanisms are impaired in preeclampsia. New data obtained will enhance the cellular and molecular understanding of estrogens, ion channels, uterine artery vascular smooth muscle contractility and tone, and uterine blood flow. The knowledge will in turn inform new pathways to assist the development of therapeutics for combating preeclampsia and other pregnancy failures and will also shed lights on the understanding of the cardiovascular protective effects of estrogens.

PHR: Synucleinopathies, including multiple system atrophy (MSA), are fatal movement disorders caused by the misfolding and self-templating of the protein α-synuclein. Little is known about how the biochemical features of each misfolded shape, or strain, of α-synuclein contributes to disease presentation. The long-term goal of these studies is to determine how strain-specific differences in axonal transport, titer, and trans-synaptic spread impact disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Parent Grant) Germinal matrix intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) occurs in 15-20% of babies born before 32 weeks of pregnancy. Lifelong consequences may include post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus (PHH), developmental delay, and cerebral palsy. We propose to use cutting-edge optical, genetic, molecular, and clinically informed approaches in our mouse model of neonatal IVH to test if two distinct and complementary endogenous responses to intraventricular blood can be harnessed to mitigate IVH sequelae: (1) ChP-NKCC1 gene therapy to remove excess CSF, and (2) macrophage clearance of ventricular blood. Our findings will give insight into the sequence and causality of events following IVH, unveil new therapeutic targets, and test the first potential gene therapy for PHH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human population history is of importance to public health because it determines the genetic variants that individuals and populations inherit, which in turn make some people more or less susceptible to disease. The exponential increase ancient DNA data—from 0 genomes a decade ago to more than 10000 today—creates extraordinary new opportunities, but methods for analysis have not caught up to the data. This grant will support the development of a complete toolkit for using ancient DNA for studying biology and history, and in addition to papers describing these methods and their application, will produce two major resources: publicly available software and a high quality reprocessed version of the world's ancient DNA data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the elderly, tissue regeneration is impaired and repeated injury often precludes the health benefits of exercise. My proposal will determine if the loss of lysine methyltransferase 5a (Kmt5a) and subsequently Kmt5a-mediated methylation of lysine 20 on histone H4 (H4K20me1) during aging disrupts muscle stem cell quiescence, consequently impairing skeletal muscle regeneration. Data generated by this proposal will first (K99) define Kmt5a role in quiescent muscle stem cells at homeostasis and in response to a skeletal muscle injury during aging, and then (R00) define H4K20me1 as an epigenetic modification that can be stimulated by exercise to rejuvenate muscle and hematopoietic stem cell function in the context of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Programmed DNA damage regulates core biological processes, but may also create challenges for genome integrity, especially in long-lived neurons. Both deficiency and overactivity of programmed DNA damage at neuronal enhancers may contribute to neurodegeneration, including in age-related frontotemporal dementia and Alzheimer’s disease. This proposal uses iPSC-derived human neurons and in vivo CRISPR interference mouse models to uncover how programmed DNA damage is regulated and the consequences of dysregulation for epigenetic remodeling and mutational frequency.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PD/PI: Takemaru, Ken-Ichi 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Infertility is a public health issue, affecting approximately 15% of all couples, and in about 50% of cases, a male factor is involved. The sperm flagellum is responsible for sperm motility and fertilization of the egg, but how flagella are properly formed remains poorly understood. Our research focuses on understanding the roles of Chibby (Cby) family members and their binding proteins in the formation and function of sperm flagella, thereby contributing to our better understanding of male germ cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons depend on the transport of mRNA down axons and dendrites so that the mRNA can be translated into proteins locally. We uncovered a mechanism by which mRNA travels on mitochondria by binding to a protein called synaptojanin2. We now ask what species of mRNA use this method of transportation and how important the mechanism is for the health of neurons, synapses, and neuronal mitochondria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender men who have sex with men (trans MSM) are an underserved NIH health disparities population at-risk of HIV acquisition in the US and require gender-affirming culturally responsive public health strategies for biobehavioral HIV prevention. This study will test individualized and group-based peer-delivered population- specific strategies to increase PrEP uptake and prevent HIV acquisition in trans MSM. The proposed research fills critical knowledge gaps in biomedical HIV prevention efforts for trans MSM, advances the science of peer- engaged approaches, and addresses national priorities in the 2021-2025 US National Strategic Plan to End the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project focuses on largely unexplored mechanisms that multicellular eukaryotes have evolved to grow and protect themselves from death and diseases caused by insufficiency and defects in secretory protein synthesis. To achieve our goals, we will harness the power of the genomic resources and molecular tools of the model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana, which allow genetic and advanced analyses that are impossible to perform in humans and whole-body mammalian models. By studying the signaling pathways of conserved sensors that monitor the homeostasis of secretory protein synthesis, this work will reveal new mechanisms that coordinate growth, stress responses and cell fate decisions and thus improve our understanding of human growth and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Disruption of genomic regulation is accompanied by striking functional changes across cell types and species. However, how mobile genetic elements are regulated throughout life, across biological sexes, and how they influence physiology in response to external or internal cues, remains largely unknown. By leveraging big data and state-of-the-art experimental approaches on vertebrate models including mouse and the emerging African turquoise killifish, the proposed research program will advance our understanding of mobile genetic element control in healthy somatic cells, and shed light on how these elements can influence vertebrate health and disease. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative One of the most intriguing questions in science is how developmental pattern formation is executed so robustly despite unavoidable cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. We will investigate the mechanisms buffering this variability during vertebral segmentation. We will also elucidate how the transcriptome-level reorganization (expression levels and variability of thousands of genes) is controlled by cell signaling gradients. These information will be significant for understanding and potentially preventing vertebral malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Controversy exists over the risk to benefit ratio of medical marijuana for adults with chronic non-cancer pain (CNCP) on chronic opioid therapy (COT). The primary goal of this proposal is to assess whether medical marijuana, when added to a behavioral prescription opioid taper support program, improves pain and reduces opioid dose in adults on COT for CNCP more so than the behavioral intervention alone. This information is critical to better inform patients and clinicians about the extent to which medical marijuana use may be beneficial or harmful to this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and alcohol use disorder (AUD) are highly comorbid and individual differences in response to stress suggest resilient and susceptible populations, which may be important for understanding this high comorbidity. The proposed work will examine neural circuitry and mechanisms that drive adaptive vs. maladaptive coping strategies during stress and the relation to subsequent alcohol drinking. Understanding the neurobiological mechanisms that underlie stress coping and maladaptive alcohol drinking may provide more effective-and sex-specific clinical prevention and treatment strategies for individuals with PTSD and comorbid alcohol use.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Monitoring antimicrobial use in dairy cattle is imperative to facilitate data-driven antimicrobial stewardship and better understand the relationships between antimicrobial use in animals and antimicrobial resistance. This project aims to collect multiple years of detailed antimicrobial use data on dairy farms, develop an antimicrobial use monitoring system with features that incentivize farmer participation, and improve the understanding of farmers' perceptions and needs concerning antimicrobial use monitoring. Such a system will incentivize dairy farmer participation and enable One Health to benefit from national-level antimicrobial use monitoring.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A System Approach to Animal-Level Antimicrobial Use Monitoring in Dairy Cattle

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Researchers-in-training in biomedical fields, particularly those from underrepresented groups, contend with a number of barriers to their career success. In the proposed project, we plan to address the Triple Threat to trainees’ career success (impostor phenomenon, fixed mindset, and perceived discrimination) by developing and testing dual interventions—one for trainees and one for their mentors—that directly target and mitigate these threats. These dual interventions, which will not only address trainees’ coping skills but will also foster environmental change via their mentors and training program directors also trained to deliver the interventions, are designed to be scalable and sustainable over time, with the goal of increasing retention of all underrepresented groups in the biomedical research pipeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We hypothesize that mutant p53 enhances inflammatory stress via activating the NLRP1 inflammasome and increasing the secretion of proinflammatory cytokines, thereby generating a chronic inflammatory microenvironment that inhibits wild type (WT) hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell (HSPC) fitness in a paracrine fashion. We further speculate that reducing chronic inflammation will prevent or delay the progression of TP53 mutant clonal hematopoiesis to myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The proposed research is relevant to public health in that it aims to create a software infrastructure that will facilitate evaluation of cognition associated with cognitive interventions and other longitudinal studies assessing cognitive abilities. This research is aligned with the NIH mission of improving health and well-being of older adults who may be at risk to develop Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), in that it seeks to facilitate better measurement and comparisons of measurements of cognition in older adult population. Thus, the proposed research cuts across the bounds of numerous NIH agencies, with our framework contributing to the missions of the NIA, NCI, NEI, NIMH, NIAAA, NINCD, NIDA, NINDS, in that all of these agencies work with populations who can gain direct benefits from successful approaches to mental fitness, and the NIH's greater mission to seek knowledge that will result in enhanced health and a reduced burden of disabilities.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Antimicrobial use (AMU) is the primary selective force behind the emergence of resistant bacteria, and systems must be developed for collecting on-farm AMU data. This project will expand an ongoing, nationally-representative and sustainable system for collecting on-farm quantitative antimicrobial use data in the broiler chicken, turkey, and table egg industries of the U.S. This project will also address key data gaps that we have identified during our 10-year effort of collect data from the majority of annual U.S. poultry production.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Antimicrobial Use Data Collection in the U.S. Poultry Production System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This Project Narrative was originally submitted with R01 NS114430 and is included here unchanged to satisfy submission system requirements. NARRATIVE Skilled movement is believed to emerge from the learned dynamical patterns of neural activity in motor control brain regions. However, movement related activity in the cerebellar neurons is best understood at the cellular level. Therefore, we will test the hypothesis that cerebellar Purkinje cells also employ a population code that synergizes spike rate modulation and synchronous firing to produce robust disinhibition of recipient neurons in the cerebellar nuclei leading to kinematic alterations of learned, dexterous motor behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 does not replicate in macaques, and thus chimeric simian-human immunodeficiency viruses (SHIVs) are used as surrogates to study HIV-1 infection in macaques. However, most SHIVs fail to replicate in macaques unless they are extensively adapted via serial macaque passage, which is an expensive and labor-intensive process. This study will characterize the viral and host determinants of adaptation of SHIVs to macaques, which will facilitate rational design of SHIVs that do not require extensive adaptation.

PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE: This diversity supplement is requested to support the scientific and career training of Ms. Allison Brezinski, a promising PhD candidate whose long-term goal is to become an independent neuroscience investigator. Ms. Brezinski’s independent research project examining the role of Dorsal type-3 interneurons (dI3 INs) in respiratory circuity and recovery in degenerative cervical myelopathy expands on the parent grant’s goal of investigating dI3 INs in neural circuity and recovery of fine motor movement in DCM. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The NIH created the Helping to End Addiction Long-term (HEAL) initiative to speed scientic solutions to the national opioid public health crisis. As part of the HEAL initiative, the HEAL Effectiveness Research Network (ERN) was established to conduct comparative effectiveness trials for prevention and management of pain, while reducing risk of addiction. The University of Utah will provide data coordination support for these trials, leading to more effective management of acute and chronic pain while reducing the risk of opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: Leveraging the extensive database of FARAD and advanced analytics of the 1DATA consortium, this project aims to develop the Long-term Antimicrobial Use with AI web-crawler (LAMU-AI) to revolutionize antimicrobial stewardship in veterinary medicine. By integrating multiple data sources and deploying sophisticated visualization tools, LAMU-AI will provide real-time insights into antimicrobial usage trends across diverse animal populations, enabling informed decision- making for stakeholders. Through collaboration with FARAD scientists and veterinary experts, we seek to address critical data gaps and enhance our understanding of antimicrobial deployment patterns to combat antibiotic resistance effectively.

PROJECT_TITLE: Bridging Critical Data Gaps in Veterinary Medicine Via Artificial Intelligence and Advanced Large Language Models to Procure Real-Time Antibiotic Use Data in Livestock, Poultry and Companion Animals

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative How infants learn to progress from spontaneous and seemingly disorganized movements into goal-directed and refined motor skills is unknown. Until we understand how to promote successful infant learning, we cannot design optimal early intervention for infants with or at risk of neuromotor developmental disabilities. The objectives of this project are to 1) determine the relationship between error rate and the development of reaching skill in infants with typical development, 2) identify individual and environmental factors related to the development of skilled reaching in infants with typical development, 3) identify patterns of concurrent brain activity that differentiate between spontaneous arm movements, early reaching attempts, and skilled reaches in infants with typical development, and 4) identify patterns of concurrent brain activity that differentiate between spontaneous arm movements, early reaching attempts, and skilled reaches in infants at high risk for cerebral palsy.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: RFA-FD-24-030 Application Identifier: 1690535 Project Narrative: Emulate has submitted a Letter of Intent (LOI; DDT-IST-000016-LOI-2) that describes the above-mentioned context of use (pairwise DILI risk comparisons) and argues that the Liver-Chip is suitable as a drug development tool (DDT) for this use-case. The submission uses data derived from Ewart et al., 2022, to illustrate that the Liver-Chip provides sufficient accuracy to facilitate pairwise DILI risk comparisons by examining 12 FDA-approved drugs with known clinical DILI profiles. However, the suitability of the Liver-Chip to the described context of use would also benefit from a demonstration of the (inter-lab) reproducibility and (intra-lab) repeatability of the DDT as well as testing across a broader panel of human hepatocyte donors. 27 Drydock Avenue, 5th Floor Boston, MA 02210

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Children with autism spectrum disorder who receive intervention earlier in life show larger gains in language skills and improved overall development; presymptomatic intervention during infancy may soon be feasible because recent research advances have lowered the age of possible detection to 6-months. The proposed study will inform future presymptomatic interventions by identifying infant-based language and communication risk markers, caregiver-based intervention targets, and brain-based monitoring biomarkers. The objectives of this proposal align with the NIDCD Strategic Plan Priority Areas in Voice, Speech, and Language Research by: 1) understanding diseases and disorders; 2) improving diagnosis, treatment, and prevention; and 3) improving outcomes for human communication.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The brain regulates reproductive function and fertility through the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), and defects in neural mechanisms that govern the normal pulsatile GnRH release pattern are invariably associated with reproductive disorders such as absent, delayed, or precocious puberty, functional hypothalamic amenorrhea, or polycystic ovary syndrome. The proposed studies will utilize innovative new animal models to determine the mechanisms by which a network of neurons producing the neuropeptide kisspeptin synchronously activate GnRH neurons as a functional “kisspeptin-GnRH pulse generator”. By providing fundamental information on the cellular circuitries that produce pulsatile GnRH release, the proposed studies will shed new light on the pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying neuroendocrine-based fertility disorders and point to new potential targets for intervention in these reproductive impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A majority of the women in Kenya, who are not pregnant, breastfeeding, or seeking family planning services are often missed by the current cervical cancer screening initiatives integrated in these special clinics providing such services. Outpatient emergency departments present an opportunity to reach many women at the initial point of contact with the health care system. This project seeks to understand the acceptability, barriers, and facilitators to integrating cervical cancer screening into the existing outpatient emergency departments and will provide important insights into its feasibility allowing the formulation and adaptation of strategies to promote its implementation in many outpatient clinics in Kenya and other LMICs with low cervical cancer screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Children and adolescents who reside in rural regions of the United States experience substantially increased risks of mental and behavioral health conditions, suicide, and firearm-related deaths, and also experience unique barriers to care given geographic isolation and shortages of mental health professionals. This research will develop, implement, and evaluate technology-assisted, culturally sensitive safety planning in rural emergency departments for youth with suicidal ideation or attempt and their caregivers, aiming to improve home safety and connections to community-based resources and ultimately decrease youth suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in 151 women in the United States carry the FMR1 premutation, a genetic abnormality that is associated with substantially increased risk for disease that appears to worsen at older ages. This longitudinal investigation of mother carriers of the FMR1 premutation aims to define age-related stability of symptoms in midlife and early old age, associated functional limitations, and the role of biological and environmental factors. Delineating the trajectory and predictors of age-related decline will inform critical age periods for prevention, risk factors, and the eventual development of strategies to improve age-related outcomes for both carrier mothers and their children with fragile X syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall In the first phase of HuBMAP, we established the Stanford Tissue Mapping Center to map the complexity of cellular architecture and biomolecular profiles of the small bowel and colon ーorgans that play wide-ranging roles in maintaining normal physiologies of metabolism, immunity, and even neural function. We applied the deep expertise of our team to obtain high-quality biospecimens, characterize tissues using cutting-edge omics and multiparametric imaging techniques, and perform integrative analyses to understand the biomolecular profiles in the context of spatial tissue structure. We have scaled these data-generation and analysis pipelines for production-scale interrogation of the intestinal wall. We will continue these efforts to build three-dimensional multi-modal (snRNA, snATAC, CODEX, multiplex FISH) spatial maps that will give the greater scientific community insights into the molecular underpinnings of normal bowel function.

PHR: Project narrative The proposed work is relevant to public health because the discovery of molecular mechanisms of Rhes- mediated tunneling nanotube–like cell-cell communication in cell and animal models is ultimately expected to increase understanding of mechanisms of aging and neurological disorders and provide the framework for developing novel therapeutic strategies based on novel mechanisms-based approaches. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of health care appointments in the United States end with at least one prescription being written for the patient, but doctors may not have the necessary tools to choose the best medication and dose for any given disease or condition. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop improved strategies that better inform clinicians on how to prescribe therapy that maximizes efficacy and minimizes harm based on the unique characteristics (demographics, genes, environment, and lifestyle) of a given patient. To do this, we will study past electronic health records from hundreds of thousands of patients to observe how they responded to drug therapy and look for patterns that link unique characteristics to favorable outcomes after taking a given medication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Peripheral and autonomic neuropathies degrade quality of life and are prevalent in patients receiving chemotherapy and living with diabetes, but few treatments exist to alleviate these conditions. Because our skin and internal organs are in constant motion, so are the sensory neurons embedded in these tissues. The proposed multidisciplinary experiments and integrated theoretical research exploits a simple genetic model to develop a comprehensive understanding of how mechanical force is detected by sensory neurons and how these self-same neurons bend without breaking, focusing on cytoskeletal structures like microtubules and spectrin that are conserved in humans and implicated in sensitivity to traumatic brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Genomic Risk Assessment Coordinating center for eMERGE (GRACE) will create infrastructure to implement and evaluate genomic risk assessments for common, complex diseases such as heart disease, and return these assessments to participants. GRACE will organize collaboration among eMERGE investigators, streamline data collection, and utilize cloud computing to enable large scale analyses of genomic data. GRACE will support the recruitment and genotyping of a 20,000 person cohort to determine the clinical impact of delivering genomic risk assessments, measure the uptake of risk reduction recommendations, and assess changes to clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) are common and costly, and most available therapeutic options do not provide long-term symptom relief. The proposed research will increase understanding of LUTS subtypes, the underlying mechanisms behind different subtypes, and will develop and refine comprehensive, validated, and responsive measurement tools for defining treatment efficacy. This work is relevant to public health as it has the potential to improve diagnosis and treatment of LUTS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A healthy retina relies on the proper function of the blood-retina barrier, i.e., the interface between blood vessels and retina that mediates highly selective transport of nutrients, hormones, and metabolic waste. Multiple retinal diseases are associated with blood-retina barrier dysfunction. Here, we will use cell-based systems and mouse models to determine the mechanism of action and efficacy of a novel drug candidate that promotes blood-retina barrier function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Classic galactosemia (CG) is one of the most common metabolic disorders identified by newborn screening in the United States, yet despite neonatal diagnosis and lifelong dietary restriction of galactose, which is the current standard of care, most children with CG grow to experience a range of developmental and other disabilities. There is currently no approved treatment that prevents or resolves these complications. The proposed research will leverage our existing GALT-null rat model for CG to define key aspects of an AAV9-based gene therapy approach to intervention, establishing a pre-clinical foundation for future translation to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In any given year, over 10% of the adult population in the United States engages in excessive alcohol use, which has myriad negative personal and public health consequences. One reason why certain individuals develop disordered and excessive alcohol use may be that their brains’ reward system is primed to learn about cues that predict rewards and is especially sensitive to alcohol reward, such that these individuals lose the ability to control themselves when confronted with cues that their brain has learned are signals for alcohol. This project will begin develop different ways to measure this between-person difference in the laboratory and test if these laboratory measures can predict changes in problematic alcohol use over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Exposures to the environmental genotoxin aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) factor in etiology of hepatocellular cancer (HCC). Genetic polymorphisms in the hNEIL1 DNA repair glycosylase, and error-prone bypass of AFB1- DNA damage by DNA polymerases may increase risk for HCC; we seek to determine how AFB1 DNA damage is repaired and replicated. Chemistry underlying AFB1 DNA damage is sequence-dependent; we seek to understand how it contributes to the AFB1 mutagenic signature.

PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to Public Health: EnClear Therapies is performing research under a National Institutes of Health Phase ½ FastTrack Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Parent Grant: 1R44NS135792-01 to develop a more effective way of delivering therapeutics to the central nervous system. The EnClear system will improve the outcomes of patients with neurological disease by delivering needed therapeutics, in a precise personalized manner that overcomes the issue of poor CNS penetration. This administrative supplement will increase the diversity at EnClear and in the United States Small Business workforce by enabling EnClear Therapies to hire an MS-level engineer who is of Hispanic male descent (a socially disadvantaged person) to contribute to the parent Phase I/II SBIR award supported research. This new employee will contribute to the development and commercialization of a therapeutic device for drug delivery that will improve the quality of life by enabling better distribution of therapeutics for neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall) The societal impact of Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias is broad. In addition to studies that will lead to prevention and cure, we need to develop new knowledge about how health systems, policy makers and communities can address the needs of people at risk for or with these devastating diseases. The proposed Center to Accelerate Population Research in Alzheimer’s will leverage expertise across disciplines to expand and stimulate multidisciplinary studies that will improve outcomes for the growing population with or at risk for AD/ADRD.

Failure to engage Tribes about these concerns perpetuates barriers to participation in genomic research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative CRAC channels are one of the primary Ca2+ influx pathways in nearly all cell types and generate Ca2+ signals critical for many cellular functions. Gain- and loss-of-function mutations in CRAC channel genes lead to diseases in which various tissues and cell types are affected, suggesting diverse physiological and pathophysiological roles CRAC channels play in human health and disease. Here, I present a basic research program to study the molecular regulation of the CRAC channel signaling pathway, which will help uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying the diverse functions of CRAC channels and facilitate development of therapeutics for treating CRAC channel-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Title: Integrating Responsive Feeding and Nutrition Security to Prevent Early Childhood Obesity in Food Insecure Populations. Project Narrative: Despite an increase in the diversity of the United States (US) population, women from an underrepresented race/ethnic minority group remain underrepresented in higher education, particularly in the biomedical research workforce. Childhood obesity has reached epidemic levels, requiring diversifying the workforce who will be researching culturally sensitive approaches to prevent early childhood obesity (ECO) among diverse racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disadvantaged, such as food insecure populations. This diversity supplement application aims to build upon the parent U01 grant to provide mentored research training in community participatory and mixed-methods research for a pre-doctoral and Filipino woman to promote diversity in the field of health disparities in ECO prevention. Letters of Support (Drs. Buccini, Flatt, Sharma, Moonie, Grigsby, Johansen, and Simangan)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: FDA guidelines stipulate that all new drugs be tested for dangerous side-effects on the heart as part of preclinical research; however, the current tests are poorly predictive of both dangerous and safe drugs leading to unwarranted attrition and dangerous drugs reaching clinic. Human cardiomyocytes derived from donor tissue (iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes) are widely considered to hold great promise for clinical trial in a dish studies of drug cardiotoxicity. This STTR proposal is to commercialize a high throughput platform to accurately identify drug candidates that have cardiac side effects, in particular adding the ability to detect the type of primary heart cell damage common with anti-cancer drugs in a fully automated (high throughput) robotic assay for the first time, to improve the efficiency of preclinical research and the safety of human clinical trials, which will also likely have the added benefit of reducing animal research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease (CKD) and acute kidney injury (AKI) are common, heterogeneous, and morbid diseases. Mechanistic characterization of CKD and AKI in patients may facilitate a precision-medicine approach to prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. The KPMP aims to ethically and safely obtain kidney biopsies from participants with CKD or AKI; create a reference kidney atlas; characterize disease subgroups to stratify patients based on molecular features of disease, clinical characteristics, and associated outcomes; and identify critical cells, pathways, and targets for novel therapies and preventive strategies.

PHR: Relevance Disruptions of mitochondrial structure have been found in many neurodegenerative and mitochondrial diseases. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since 2013, inequities in firearm-related mortality between Black and White children and adolescents ages 1-19 have widened, with the most recent dramatic increases in Black rural youth. This study will apply demographic methods and spatial analysis to examine how area-level structural racism, socioeconomic disadvantage, firearm availability, and population composition contribute to recent spatial and temporal trends in firearm-related mortality among Black youth. The findings will provide critical evidence to guide policymakers in crafting targeted strategies to reduce Black youth firearm-related deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative For the brain to function it is essential that large numbers of neurons are interconnected in a highly precise manner, a process which is controlled by the patterns of genes expressed during brain development. Work of this grant focuses on a circuit of the Drosophila brain controlling navigation. We are analyzing connectivity within this circuit with digital connectomes, and use optogenetic tools to record and manipulate neuronal activity in order to develop concepts which are important to understand, and therapeutically manipulate, circuits formed by nerve cells in the human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is one of the leading causes of irreversible blindness worldwide, and current pharmacologic and surgical treatment methods have low adherence rates and associated complications. The suprachoroidal space can be expanded via a simple microneedle injection of a hydrogel and has been shown to reduce intraocular pressure. In this proposal, I will determine the mechanism of intraocular pressure reduction from suprachoroidal expansion, develop an optimal hydrogel for this application, and evaluate the safety and efficacy of this approach, which will lead to the development of a novel glaucoma treatment method without the use of pharmacologic agents or surgical procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-functioning kidney grafts after deceased-donor kidney transplantation remain a significant problem, with about one thousand grafts failing yearly and only 50% remain functional after ten years. The current tools we have to predict graft failure are limited in providing pathways for future intervention, therefore this project aims to identify if recipient protein markers involved in blood vessel stability are associated with future graft function in an effort to identify pathways amenable to intervention. The mission of this project aligns well with the overall mission of the NIDDK, as we aim to understand pathways that influence recipient graft outcomes to be able to enhance graft quality and improve overall recipient health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is a human neurovascular disorder in which perturbations to vascular cells – including endothelial cells that line the inner lumen of blood vessels – can trigger debilitating blood vessel dysfunction. We previously reported abnormal brain endothelial cell shape, directionality, and movement, using in vitro and in vivo models of endothelial cell dysfunction and brain AVM. We will test the hypothesis that abnormalities to the cytoskeleton underlie brain AVM-related endothelial cell dysfunction and that pharmacological-based normalization of endothelial cell signaling will prevent cytoskeletal anomalies and restore cellular function.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because defects in germline mechanisms are  responsible for various genetic and epigenetic diseases. This study has high potential  to identify novel epigenetic mechanisms that govern distinct sexually dimorphic processes  in spermatogenesis and oogenesis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: This research project aims to support Samantha Mota, a female graduate student of Latin-American descent, in her studies related to the parent grant “Analgesic signaling in Drosophila”. Preliminary data supporting the parent grant found that AstC-R1, a putative Drosophila receptor for the analgesic effects of opiates, is expressed in nociceptive interneurons. Samantha's related project will explore the exact cellular locus of AstC- R1 analgesic function and related roles for the AstC neuropeptide ligand of this receptor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neurobiological basis of socioemotional symptoms, a debilitating feature of many neurological and psychiatric disorders, is not well understood. The brain and autonomic nervous system cohesively interact to support socioemotional well-being, and cutting-edge analytical techniques can now reveal the rich dynamic properties of these systems. By leveraging behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia, a neurodegenerative disease of socioemotional deficits that targets these systems, the goal of the proposed project is to determine how autonomic and functional brain network dynamics shape human emotions and social behavior in healthy and clinical populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of individuals with clinical Alzheimer's disease (AD) is rapidly increasing worldwide due to aging of the population, but current cognitive measures lack sufficient sensitivity and specificity to detect subtle decline within the preclinical phase. There is a critical need for tools that are sensitive to AD neuropathology during the preclinical phase that are low-cost, high-access, and fast to administer that can be used across educationally, linguistically, and culturally diverse older individuals. The goal of this project is to identify metrics for semantic impairment in diverse individuals that correlate with AD neuropathology and predict clinical decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project examines how school-age blind children acquire word meanings, and whether the trajectory of vocabulary development in blind children is altered or delayed relative to that in typically sighted children. Findings from this research have the potential to improve instructional approaches and language and literacy interventions for blind children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Birth defects and skeletal diseases affecting the skull and jaw are a major societal burden. We propose to use zebrafish, a highly regenerative vertebrate amenable to powerful genetic and imaging techniques, to understand how stem cells build and then maintain and repair the head skeleton. The long-term goal is to use foundational knowledge acquired in the zebrafish to develop new regenerative medicine treatments for human craniofacial diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Intrathecal oxytocin is in clinical trials as an opioid alternative for chronic pain treatment. Our work in mice suggests that coupling intrathecal oxytocin with manual therapies (i.e. massage) optimizes the analgesic properties of oxytocin. This project provides the framework to support this combination therapy by concentrating on the spinal cord circuit mechanisms by which oxytocin alleviates pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper cell shape control is essential for the proliferation of cells, normal development and maintenance of a healthy organism. We study how cytokinesis, the physical process in which one cell splits into two, works at a fundamental level in order to understand how cells control cell shape more generally. Ultimately, with a rigorous understanding and a complete molecular handle on these processes, it should be possible to develop better therapies that are tailored to the properties of specific disease types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Parkinson’s disease (PD), late PD dementia (PDD), and PD-related amyloid angiopathy are looming disasters for public health. The combined direct and indirect cost of PD, including treatment, social security payments, and lost income, is estimated to be nearly $52 billion per year in the United States alone. Nearly 1 million Americans are living with PD (2020), and the numbers are growing, as there is no definitive cure. This proposed research is highly relevant, as the control of systemic β-amyloid peptide production and transport, involving platelets and blood, could slow the advance of late-stage dementia and open up a new approach to therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Limited information exists pertaining to the physiological relevance of innate immune regulation across the age spectrum following TBI. Completion of these studies will advance our understanding of the key regulators involved in monocyte/macrophage responses and neurovascular health in TBI pathophysiology. Exploiting the pro-resolving phenotype of juvenile- derived PDMs may provide a novel restorative intervention aimed at improving TBI outcomes and reveal novel targets for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain-related aging and health, including Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (ADRD) have a profound impact on individual physical and mental functioning, and also on families and society. Therefore, investigation of neurocognitive aging and ADRD is crucial to our society and the individuals within it; however, we have too few trained underrepresented scientists to address the challenges of neurocognitive aging and ADRD faced by our increasingly diverse aging population. Our project will develop an exhaustive research training experience in neurocognitive aging ranging from basic neurobiology of neurodegenerative conditions, modifiable risk factors and health disparities related to neurocognitive aging, which will subsequently establish a talented, committed, and sustained pipeline of underrepresented students reflective of community demographics, who have unique perspectives, capable of addressing critical neurocognitive aging challenges in our changing world.

ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease (PD) often results in widespread motor dysfunction. PD is a progressive and degenerative condition, and thus frequent and granular assessment of motor function is critical to effective management of motor symptoms. In this proposal, we will use an innovative pose estimation approach to enable objective quantification of many motor features of PD using only simple digital videos that can be recorded from common household devices (e.g., smartphones, tablets, laptop computers).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed research is focused on understanding the mechanism of Hox function in regulating skeletal differentiation. Loss of Hox function impacts the ability of skeletal stem/progenitors to complete differentiation down the osteogenic and chondrogenic lineages via unknown pathways. The conserved, region-specific, expression of Hox genes in the skeletal stem/progenitors (MSCs) in all vertebrates, including humans, supports the significance and relevance of these studies and fulfills the mission and goal of the NIH to understand the processes of human growth and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This supplement project will develop methods to measure specific protein components in the cerebrospinal fluid of people with Parkinson disease (PD), and determine whether these measurements correlate with the development of cognitive impairment and other symptoms that occur with disease progression. These types of biomarker measurements are needed to guide the development of treatments for PD. The supplement project will also support the career development of an investigator developing expertise in biomarkers for PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Successful completion of the proposed experiments will characterize the role of astrocytic molecular clock in regulating synaptic development and establishment of synaptic rhythmicity and cognitive performance. There is a strong comorbidity between disruptions to the circadian cycle, and cognitive impairments, yet the mechanistic link is not well understood. We will examine how developmental perturbation to astrocytic molecular clock regulates time-of-day-dependent changes in synapse number and activity, and underlying behavior.

PHR: NARRATIVE The project aims to study the interaction between the N-terminus of snake PLA2 and human nAChR β2 subunit, deciphering the role of PLA2 in interacting with β2 subunit. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to development of biomarkers that reflect granular neurobiological principles underlying ASD and related neurodevelopmental conditions. Among these individuals, understanding and addressing challenges related to atypical sensory processing is repeatedly noted as a common goal that would improve quality of life. In the long term, by developing objective brain-based measures of sensory processing (which has historically been a subjective phenomenon), this work has the potential to elevate research for a host of different diseases, alongside a wide variety of neurodevelopmental and sensory conditions.
