IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed research is relevant to public health because the proposed novel biofeedback combined with neural prosthesis control will improve balance control, postural stability, and balance confidence in individuals with lower limb amputation. This, in turn, improves their community participation and quality of life. The project is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission such that demonstrating the effectiveness of biofeedback will help individuals with lower limb amputation to improve the capacity to maintain balance, which reduces risk of fall, encourages prosthesis usage, and improves the health of lower limb amputees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dopaminergic neurons are comprised of diverse subsets, and declines in these critical cells contribute to many mental illnesses and neurological disorders. However, the mechanisms responsible for generating and maintaining dopamine neuron diversity are not well mapped. In this project, we examine how a specific kinase pathway programs the numbers, diversity, and connectivity of dopamine neurons with the long-term goal of preserving these cells to improve outcomes in dopamine-regulated mental illnesses and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Several sight threatening diseases involve excessive cell and synapse removal by an important immune cell type called microglia. The goal of this work is to understand the molecular mechanisms that connect microglia function to their intracellular states. Results from this study will inform the longer- term goal of preventing vision loss by modulating microglia-dependent outcomes in eye diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uterine fibroids (UFs) are the most important benign neoplastic threat to women’s health worldwide, but disproportionately affect women of color, particularly African American (AA) women, who have a threefold higher incidence and relative risk of UFs than European American (EA) women. The underlying cause for this risk disparity is not fully understood, and it is unclear if and how the processes that drive UF formation and determine relative risk are genetically or biochemically linked. This Diversity Supplement to parent grant R01HD087417 is impactful as its suggests a mechanistic basis to couple UF etiology and disease risk through a functional interplay between Vitamin D3 and DNA damage in UFs, and further offers proof-of-concept for clinical treatment of UFs with Vitamin D3 and its FDA-approved nonhormonal analog Doxercalciferol. The studies proposed herein thus address and mechanistically connect three overarching issues in the field: the molecular pathogenesis of UFs, the racial disparity in UF risk, and the development of novel tolerable fertility-saving and cost-effective oral therapies for UFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: GHESKIO is a Haitian organization dedicated to research, service, and training in HIV/AIDS with a 37 year track record of NIH-funded clinical research. The GHESKIO Clinical Trials Unit has two clinical research sites in Port au Prince and will conduct research in two NIAID networks: The adult HIV/AIDS therapeutic clinical trials group and the maternal-adolescent-pediatric HIV/AIDS trials group. The goal is to improve the treatment of HIV, tuberculosis, and HIV complications across the lifespan in pregnant women, adolescents, children, and adults of all ages in Haiti and around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Parent Grant Narrative How the brain determines cerebral ventricular volume, and how that in turn affects brain function or the development of normal pressure hydrocephalus, are poorly understood. This proposal will investigate our discovery of an ependymal chemosensory-mechanotransduction system that uses motile cilia to convert chemical signals into changes in flow which govern ependymal cell junction assembly, ventricular wall stiffness and ependymal permeability. By controlling ventricular compliance and the exchange of CSF between the ventricular and interstitial spaces, this system regulates ventricular volume, the relative distribution and composition of fluid in the ventricular and interstitial compartments, and neuronal activity in brain regions that subserve memory and motor functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative Microsatellite repeat expansions are a growing family of 50+ neurological, neuromuscular, and neurodegenerative diseases that includes the most common cause of adult-onset muscular dystrophy (myotonic dystrophy, DM) and large group of rare neurodegenerative diseases (spinocerebellar ataxias, SCAs). This project, which supports the research and career training of Caroline Pritchard, will focus on bioinformatic approaches to characterize the transcriptomic interface between these repeat expansion disorders. Characterizing shared alternative splicing disease mechanisms in multiple repeat expansion diseases and the synergy in splicing dysregulation at the transcript level will enhance our understanding of the disease biology of SCAs and open new potential avenues for therapeutic development across the entire family of repeat expansion diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though various interventions exist for reducing involvement in the justice system among previously incarcerated people with serious mental illness, no one intervention works for all. This project proposes novel precision medicine methods to understand which justice-involved people with SMI benefit from which interventions. This work will ultimately result in policy recommendations for matching services to the characteristics, needs, and risk factors of those in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this proposal is to conduct a placebo-controlled randomized trial comparing the effects of hemp-derived CBD with and without THC, relative to placebo, on reducing cannabis use and CUD symptoms in adult treatment seeking cannabis concentrate users with CUD. This question has enormous public health importance because the field lacks an effective CUD medication, particularly for high potency concentrate users. In addition, hemp-derived CBD products with and without low levels of THC are already widely available to consumers; thus, a positive finding would have an immediate public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Electronic cigarettes (e-cigs) aerosolize a mixture of chemical solvents, flavor additives and nicotine, and inhalation of the resultant aerosol by e-cigarette users has unknown effects on the heart. In this project, we will examine how specific flavoring chemicals that are inhaled during e-cigarette use impact the function of mouse and human heart cells and tissues. Ultimately, this study will advance knowledge of the toxicity of e-cigarettes, which will direct new regulation of e-liquid constituents based on their potential for adverse effects on the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This research aims to accelerate the implementation of evidence-based interventions to reduce health disparities and promote health for Latinos in the rural United States. In this study, we will adapt, implement, and evaluate the effectiveness of El Valor, a Latino-focused retail food store (tienda) evidence-based intervention to increase the consumption of fruits and vegetables delivered by community health workers for Latinos living in rural communities. We address diet health disparities through our participatory research process, an implementation equity research focus, and innovative application of community health workers delivering the intervention in retail and commercial settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia are well recognized mediators of Alzheimer's disease and related disorders, and endothelial cells are essential players in the vascular pathology due to their role of gatekeepers of the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Micro RNAs are short non-coding RNAs that regulate cell survival and function, but their role as contributors to endothelial cell stress and death mechanisms as well as BBB permeability in AD and cerebral vascular amyloidosis is largely unknown. Here, through the use of human endothelial cells in culture and vessels purified from mouse and human brains with vascular amyloid deposits, we plan to test the hypothesis that the miR-212 downregulation induced by Amyloid β contributes to BBB failure and neurovascular dysfunction in AD and related dementias.

PHR: Project Narrative: Down syndrome (DS) is one of the most common genetic disorders with a prevalence of 1 per 700 liveborn infants in the United States and is associated with an increased risk of developing cerebrovascular disorders (CeVD), which commonly present with stroke as the first evidence of disease. The proposed research will result in the creation of a validated, non-invasive, low-cost, biometric screening tool for young persons with DS in order to address the pressing need of reliable screening of CeVD in at-risk individuals. This proposal presents a five-year research career development program with training that will position me with a unique set of interdisciplinary skills to enable transition to independence as a physician-scientist to study the prediction and prevention of CeVD in persons with DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The reprogramming of differentiated cells to induced pluripotent stem cells represents a remarkable reconfiguration of gene regulatory programs and provides the unprecedented ability to generate any type of human cell in unlimited amounts for therapeutic purposes and drug screening. The goal of this project is to identify the general principle regarding transcription factors remodeling cellular networks that define human cell identities. The results of this project will further reveal how human genetic variation affects the establishment and maintenance of the induced stem cell state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We will determine the role of immune mechanisms in driving HIV persistence, elimination, or expansion of HIV infected clones, and determine whether immune selective pressures shape clone size and composition in young adults in the U.S. living with perinatal HIV-1. In this protocol, we will determine whether the reservoir properties are similar in individuals who acquire HIV with immature immune systems. By identifying and overcoming obstacles to engagement of underrepresented populations, this project advances the overall goal of improving equity and justice in participant selection for clinical studies, which has important impact on relevant strategies for HIV cure research in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a very common and lethal cancer in Africa, and as patients with HIV live longer, the burden of HCC may increase. The proposed Consortium will conduct clinical research projects in Uganda and Senegal to investigate if and how treatment of HCC-causing infections may prevent HCC. In parallel, Consortium resources are applied towards developing human and clinical research capacity in both countries to address the growing problem of HIV and HCC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (of the Parent Award) Spontaneous pregnancy loss is a devastating and serious public health problem affecting 1 in 4 women worldwide. Uterine infection is associated with implantation failure but how infection affects endometrial function remains unknown. The proposed research will determine the mechanisms by which double-stranded RNA that is present in all viruses impact endometrial decidualization and communication with placental trophoblasts, contributing to our current understanding of the pathophysiology of early pregnancy loss in women who have been exposed to infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to development of biomarkers that reflect granular neurobiological principles underlying ASD and related neurodevelopmental conditions. Among these individuals, understanding and addressing challenges related to atypical sensory processing is repeatedly noted as a common goal that would improve quality of life. In the long term, by developing objective brain-based measures of sensory processing (which has historically been a subjective phenomenon), this work has the potential to elevate research for a host of different diseases, alongside a wide variety of neurodevelopmental and sensory conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed research examines the neurocognitive bases of treatment response to a well-established evidence-based treatment program. We use pre and post treatment neuroimaging and, for the first time, frequent neuroimaging during the course of treatment 1) to gain new insights into how evidence-based treatment modulates brain organization for literacy, language learning, and remediation; and 2) why it fails to do so for some children. The proposed research represents a key step towards the development of comprehensive and mechanistic models of the neural underpinnings of typical and atypical reading development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The fundamental question for the field of Down Syndrome (DS) basic research is how an extra copy of human chromosome 21 (HSA21) translates into the organ-specific defects observed in the DS population. Control of when cells differentiate from progenitor to differentiated cell is important for normal organ formation. We will test the overall hypothesis that altered Hh signaling response and cardiac differentiation timing is a mechanism underlying increased CHD risk in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: WEK, RONALD C PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic diseases, including diabetes mellitus and obesity, are major public health concerns in the US and worldwide. The objective of this Training Program is to recruit, mentor, and train a talented and diverse cadre of scientists to carry out cutting-edge basic science and translational research focused on improving the health of individuals with or at risk of type 1 and type 2 diabetes, obesity, and their associated complications. This program will leverage the infrastructure, resources, and rich training environment of the Indiana University School of Medicine and the Indiana Diabetes Research Center to nurture the careers of the next generation of diabetes, obesity, and metabolism investigators. PHR: Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study is designed to help improve the care of SGM with AD/ADRD in LTSS by conducting a rigorous study of the policies of LTSS agencies in Minnesota and by training the state’s LTSS workforce in SGM culturally responsive care. The study of policy will inform whether LTSS agencies need regulation or have already adopted SGM appropriate policies. The randomized controlled trial will rigorously test the effects of an in- person versus an online training program on improving SGM culturally responsive care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This goals of this project are to (1) investigate longitudinal trajectories of cognitive and brain aging in older adults with epilepsy, and (2) identify modifiable risk factors to mitigate or prevent cognitive decline and progression to dementia. This research will be accomplished by combining advanced structural, diffusion, and perfusion imaging with neuropsychological, CSF biomarker and vascular risk factor data to model cognitive and brain changes, as well as moderators of change, over a 5-year period. The information gained from this investigation may help to shift epilepsy care beyond seizure control to include factors to protect and promote brain health in our elderly patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This administrative supplement project examines whether criminal legal system involvement impedes the reach of harm reduction services and exacerbates overdose mortality. This evaluation could help clarify for policymakers and service providers what practices or barriers need to be adapted to improve the health of people who use drugs. These findings are critical for public health and public safety agencies who continue to struggle with solutions that reduce overdose mortality in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Experiences of adversity, including racism and discrimination, among pregnant women is a substantial public health concern that impacts their functioning and outcomes in their offspring. The proposed supplement examines Black/White racial disparities in perinatal experiences and outcomes among women with substance use histories, as well as the interaction of discrimination and perinatal adversity on Black women’s functioning. This work will provide a better understanding of the effects of pre- and postnatal factors that impact maternal functioning and infant health and developmental outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Growing evidence demonstrates that secure attachment in childhood predicts children’s healthy social, biological, and behavioral functioning, whereas insecure attachment predicts behavior problems and physiological dysregulation; thus, efforts to foster secure attachment are crucial for promoting the healthy development of children and families. This proposal describes a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of an innovative intervention program that can be widely implemented designed to foster children’s secure attachment, promote healthy physiological regulation, and reduce the risk for behavior problems: The Circle of Security – Parenting intervention. To this end, we will conduct an RCT with 249 parent-child dyads enrolled in two diverse Early Head Start programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative PACS1 R203W pathogenic substitution is solely responsible for over 200 patients presenting with the ASD- associated disease, PACS1 Syndrome, yet the mechanisms that lead to the neurodevelopmental defects remain largely unknown. Moreover, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) identified the human PACS1 locus as a susceptibility gene in severe early-onset obesity, developmental delay, and bipolar disorder, suggesting a broader role in neural development and function. In this proposal, we will use modern molecular biology and stem cell techniques combined with neuroscience tools to better understand the pathogenic mechanisms by which PACS1 deficits affect the developing nervous system, possibly revealing convergent therapy targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative (of Parent Grant 1-R01 NS131399-01) Developmental and epileptic encephalopathies (DEE) are a devastating group of neuropsychiatric disorders where seizures (that begin early in life) and an underlying genetic mutation or brain lesion result in developmental delay, intellectual disability and a complex spectrum of neurobehavioral disturbances. In this proposal, we apply a mouse model of DEE to clarify the molecular and circuit-level mediators underlying such behavioral syndromes using a novel homecage approach to measuring mouse behavior.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Somatic point mutations are very frequent in the context of several human genetic diseases but their causes are still poorly understood. Within the scope of the funded parent grant, this application aims at performing computational analyses on existing data on mutational signatures to better define the origins of different mutational signatures across mutagens and conditions. The other main goal of this application is to foster scientific and educational training for Dr Paolo Mita to promote his future academic career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure diagnosis and treatment in Uganda faces significant challenges due to limited specialist availability and resources. The candidate, leveraging her background in global health and echocardiography training of non-specialists in Haiti, aims to address these issues through the co-design of an Echocardiography Training Intervention Package tailored for non-specialists in six Regional Referral Hospitals in Uganda. This project, by improving the early detection of heart failure and studying Guideline-Directed Medical Therapy prescribing practices, seeks to enhance patient outcomes and advance heart failure care practices in Uganda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE OF PROJECT TO RESEARCH AND PUBLIC HEALTH Widespread utilization of genomic sequencing in medicine creates an urgent need to educate providers and patients. Currently, providers frequently misinterpret genomic information and patients often don't understand their own test results. In order to address this critical need, we propose to design and test multiple e-Health communication tools that will help providers and patients to better understand genomic data, lead to higher quality patient care, and facilitate genomic information sharing within families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Astrocytes, the most abundant glial cells in the central nervous system, perform a multitude of evolutionary conserved functions including, metabolic support to neurons, regulating blood-brain barrier, and modulating synapse-formation, -function and -plasticity, and are crucial in maintaining normal brain homeostasis. Dynamic crosstalk between astrocytes and neuronal synapses modulates most if not all of these functions, yet the molecular mechanism of neuron-astrocyte cross-communication at the synapse is largely untapped. Based on our preliminary studies, we propose a novel mechanism of neuron-astrocyte crosstalk at the synapse via S1P/S1PR1 signaling that regulates astrocyte function and neuronal synapse formation, function and plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall vision of the “Kaposi Sarcoma in the Era of ART in Africa Program (KEAAP)” is to build a collaborative network between the Cancer Diseases Hospital and the University Teaching Hospitals in Zambia, the Ocean Road Cancer Institute in Tanzania, and the Stanley S Scott Cancer Center at the Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center-New Orleans, to conduct cutting edge research that will lead to a better understanding of Kaposi sarcoma, a common HIV associated cancer in Africa. KEAAP is high impact because it builds on successful ongoing Fogarty and NCI training programs, it will implement a cross-disciplinary tri- lateral research and training program driven by our Tanzanian and Zambian collaborators with broad local support to ensure their sustainability. The lessons learned will also benefit Louisiana HIV-1 and cancer research since the state has the fifth largest population of people living with HIV, mostly among its health disparities population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently developed a new non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) system, kilohertz transcranial magnetic perturbation (kTMP), that opens a new experimental space for safely modulating neural excitability in targeted areas of the human brain. This project will focus on building and testing an instrumented glove designed to capture detailed motor performance during a reach-to-grasp task. In addition, the supplementee will carrying out an engineering gap analysis to create a Formal Design History File for kTMP that is necessary to prepare a Premarket Submission to the FDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Candidate Clinical Condition as Prognostic Outcome for TB Study (C3PO) will find out whether using new tests at the end of tuberculosis treatment can identify which people will relapse with tuberculosis after treatment. The first new test, called the RS ratio®, can detect residual tuberculosis bacteria in sputum that standard culture techniques do not pick up. The second new test detects unresolved inflammation in blood that shows that the immune system of someone treated for tuberculosis is still battling the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Segmental-loss peripheral nerve injuries are currently rather in-effectively treated with cadaveric nerve allografts, stimulating slow regeneration of outgrowing axons with various drugs or other substances. Our proposal seeks to investigate and develop potentially synergistic methods of axon fusion and localized immunosuppression of peripheral nerve allografts to circumvent these problems and lead to a new standard of treatment for segmental-loss peripheral nerve defects.

PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE RNA oxidation precedes motor neuron degeneration in ALS, yet its consequences in the context of disease are not understood. This project seeks to identify the effects of RNA oxidation on several aspects of RNA processing and the cellular mechanisms by which it might lead to neuronal death. This work will help clarify the molecular mechanisms underlying RNA oxidation and identify potential therapeutic intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Physiological transport of fluid, molecules, proteins, and cells throughout the body is critical for homeostasis. While transport processes like cell migration and molecular passage across cellular barriers are well documented, less is known about transport across the interstitial tissue spaces and into lymphatic vessels, the natural conduit from peripheral tissues to draining lymph nodes, where the immune response is shaped. The proposed research program combines mucosal, lymphoid tissue, and lymphatic vessel physiology with engineering approaches, such as building relevant in vitro model systems and designing nanoparticle probes, to increase our understanding of protein, particulate, and other material transport across interstitial tissues and into lymphatic vessels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This works aims to study the role of inflammatory proteins in the development and progression of chronic disease. We will use an injectable fluorescent nanosensor network to quantify inflammatory proteins at the site of disease as well as throughout the body. We expect to understand the role of inflammation in chronic disease and to potentially discover new inflammatory signatures for different stages of each disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease, multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and corticobasal syndrome are devastating neurodegenerative diseases that cause a progressive debilitation and eventually death. Misdiagnosis and confusion of these diseases causes much suffering and hampers conduction of clinical trials. We will test a new biomarker panel for distinguishing among these diseases using a blood test, which will substantially facilitate development of new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Summary and Narrative Many mental health and neurological diseases have significant affective components of their disease and/or significant comorbidities with affective disorders, such that treating the affective component of the disease is beneficial for treating the whole disease process. In the parent award of this proposal, ultrasonic uncaging of ketamine will be applied to the anterior cingulate cortex of patients with chronic pain to treat the affective component of this disorder – to modulate how severe the patient experiences pain, less so modulating whether they experience pain in the first place. This same strategy could in principle be applied to other neuropsychiatric disorders that have a strong affective component. In particular opioid use disorder (OUD) is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide with a strong affective component. Traditional treatments like buprenorphine or methadone often fail to address the mood disturbances associated with OUD, leading to high relapse rates. Specifically, the withdrawal/abstinence period of OUD is associated with a negative affective state, dubbed ‘hyperkatifeia,’ that predisposes to relapse later. Like in the chronic pain application, ketamine uncaging targeted to a critical brain region could treat the affective component of substance use disorders, including OUD, to break the cycle of binge, withdrawal, and relapse that defines the disorder. In this training period, the candidate will explore the use of ultrasonic ketamine uncaging to modulate affective behaviors in rodent models of chronic pain as well as of OUD. This activity will better define the protocols for ultrasonic ketamine uncaging to be used in the clinical trial phase of the parent award, guide interpretation of the clinical and physiologic data in that clinical trial phase, and generate data to suggest further applications of ketamine uncaging, and the use of ultrasonic uncaging more broadly to treat affective disorders and the affective component of neuropsychiatric disease. During the preclinical phase of the parent award, the candidate will gain training in in vivo application of therapeutic ultrasound, neurobehavioral assay development and implementation, quantitative video behavioral analysis, functional ultrasound imaging, and neuroscientific data analysis. For the clinical phase of the parent award it is anticipated that the candidate will stay with the investigatory group, with or without a successful extension of this funding, to gain training in the clinical use of therapeutic ultrasound and neuropsychological trial implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of people experience general anesthesia each year in the United States, yet the mechanisms governing anesthetic actions are unclear. The period of arousal from anesthesia, termed emergence, is a particularly sensitive and dangerous time in clinical anesthesia care, and no therapeutic strategy currently exists for modifying emergence. This equipment supplement will support studies aimed at elucidating the inhibitory cellular, circuit, and behavioral mechanisms of emergence from general anesthesia in order to inform the development of mechanistically targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sub-Saharan Africa carries the highest burden globally of both HIV and cervical cancer (CC). Cervical Cancer is 6-fold more common in women with HIV, and is preventable via vaccination prior to HPV exposure, or through screening and treating women for HPV infection or cervical lesions. Rwanda is a low-income country with high burden of both HIV and cervical cancer and limited research capacity for investigators to conduct high impact research in this area. Building research capacity for investigators to study this population at a dual burden of disease could contribute towards strategies to mitigate that burden

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic liver disease, leading to cirrhosis is epidemic in Veterans. A major complication of cirrhosis is hepatic encephalopathy (HE), that can cause lasting brain damage if it recurs. Current treatments for HE target inflammation produced in the bowels but are often not effective. Our preliminary study showed that feces from a healthy donor, also known as fecal microbial transplant (FMT), was safe using an enema and oral capsule routes. However, it is not clear which route or combination of fecal transplant administration would be helpful in preventing hospitalizations in HE patients. It is also unclear whether it is the microbes in the FMT or their products that are associated with the improvement. Our proposed trial studies the effect of oral and enema routes of FMT in Veterans with HE to prevent hospitalizations, and also aims to find out which FMT components are associated with improvement using animal models.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative/Health Relevance About 5,000 Veterans take their own lives each year. While the VA has currently mandated a multifaceted prevention approach, including suicide risk screening of all Veterans seen for mental health issues, the continued large numbers of Veterans who attempt or die of suicide points to the desperate need for improved prediction of suicide risk. Existing prediction methods are subject to high rates of false alarm, so that only about 10% of Veterans flagged as at-risk actually attempt suicide; this high false alarm rate potentially diffuses critical clinical resources away from those who need them most. The development of more accurate predictive tools has been identified as one of the most important areas in suicide research, and would also improve the evidence base for clinical therapy, by more accurately identifying at-risk clients to participate in research trials and evaluating treatment effectiveness across time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) results in 40% of all deaths and results in serious morbidity in both men and women and it is well known that a key early step in the development of CVD is dysfunction of a thin single-cell layer of cells lining the inner wall of the blood vessels called endothelium. Our goal is to determine the mechanisms responsible for the impairment of endothelial function by hypercholesterolemia, focusing on cholesterol-induced suppression of a specific type of endothelial K+ channel that we showed to play a significant role in endothelial dysfunction. Currently we focus on elucidating the mechanism of how cholesterol binding to the channels impairs their function (a fundamental and still unanswered question), the role of cholesterol-induced suppression of these channels in endothelial dysfunction, and the impact of the loss of function of these channels on atherosclerosis development, which we believe will contribute significantly to the understanding of endothelial dysfunction and provide the basis for new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of cardiomyocytes by necrotic cell death is the direct mechanistic basis for mortality due to myocardial infarction injury, as well as ensuing heart failure associated with an array of cardiomyopathies. This proposal will explore novel mechanisms in regards to the composition and regulation of the mitochondria permeability transition pore and its opening, which is the critical event that is responsible for regulated necrotic cell death. Further definition and molecular composition of the permeability transition pore is critical for designing new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. José Maldonado-Ortiz will evaluate patients with chronic Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection before and after direct-acting antiviral treatment to determine the pathophysiologic changes in the salivary glands (SG) and correlate those changes to xerostomia and clinical features of salivary dysfunction. Additionally, a mouse model expressing HCV antigenic proteins will be used to better understand the HCV/host immune cell interactions and tissue changes that may result in SG dysfunction. HCV infection, which is the most common blood-borne pathogen in the US and has been associated with dry mouth, offers a unique opportunity to study viral induced SG dysfunction and can provide mechanistic data on the role of viruses in driving inflammation, dysfunction, and damage in the SG.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: This proposal is to establish the Northern Pacific Global Health Leadership, Education, And Development for Early-career Researchers (NPGH LEADERs) Consortium – a research training program directed by the University of Washington in partnership with the Universities of Hawaii, Michigan and Minnesota with international partnerships in Cameroon, Ghana, India, Kenya, Liberia, Nepal, Peru, Thailand, and Uganda. The goal of this Consortium is to provide outstanding mentored research training to U.S. and LMIC post-doctoral and U.S. pre-doctoral trainees at international partner institutions in order to create the next generation of independent global health scientists and leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study seeks to provide large-scale, foundational evidence that high-intensity rehabilitation is effective and can be systematically implemented to improve functional outcomes for patients admitted to skilled nursing facilities following hospitalization. Additionally, this study will generate a descriptive overview of factors that predict implementation success while informing effective implementation strategies for future skilled nursing facilities innovation. Overall, this study is a critical step in advancing clinical practice to establish high-intensity rehabilitation as an effective standard of care in skilled nursing facilities to shift current treatment away from low-intensity, conservative interventions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY: The major goal of this administrative supplement application for the Parent P40 Grant of the Caribbean Primate Research Center (CPRC) is to renovate the Behavioral/Environmental Enrichment Unit (BEEU) area at the Sabana Seca Field Station. This in turn is essential to support animal well-being as well as any future expansion of the Center's Indian origin rhesus macaque colony. It is well-known that species-specific plans for housing and management should be developed in any NHP facility. Such plans should also include strategies for environmental enrichment. The CPRC is one of the most important national resources for any research program using indian- origin (IO) rhesus macaques with no history of admixture and with well-defined genetic and virological backgrounds. Since 1938, the Center has supplied the scientific community with Indian origin rhesus macaques with known backgrounds and of the same genetic pool for use in studies of basic biology and diseases. In the last three years (2020-2023), 1,234 animals have been allocated from the CPRC program in support of NIH-high priority HIV/AIDS-research, mainly R01, P01, U01- funded academic investigators and NIAID-DAIDS-SVEU programs in USA. The CPRC has vast experience in the establishment and maintenance of rhesus macaque breeding colonies. The animal care and use program of the CPRC is in compliance with the directives established by the Animal Welfare Act (AWA), PHS and other agencies. The Center is AAALAC fully- accredited. The population management program has been designed to optimize the health and well-being of the monkeys, enhance the value of the colony for research, and provide healthy animals to the scientific community for a variety of studies. The Center is in the urgent need of renovating the behavior /environmental enrichment infrastructure severely affected by Hurricane Maria. This renovation will support the CPRC's plan for future expansion as well as the parent grant's objective of producing and distribute valuable genetically and virologically characterized rhesus monkeys for the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the impact of disclosing genetic risk information on parental behavior and psychological responses in managing childhood obesity. By conducting interviews with parents and caregivers who have received genetic risk assessments for their children, the study aims to understand how this information affects health behavior changes, including a range of psychosocial issues. The findings will guide the developing of effective, ethically informed practices in genetic counseling and healthcare, enhancing interventions to prevent childhood obesity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children from disadvantaged backgrounds, on average exhibit disparities in academic achievement and cognitive development, compared to their peers from higher socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds. The proposed studies will investigate the role of specific aspects of children’s early language input on the development of neural networks supporting the development of language, executive functioning, and social cognition, and how these may ultimately drive SES differences in academic achievement. Findings from this work have the potential to inform maximally impactful interventions to reduce achievement gaps and improve cognitive outcomes for children from all backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to neurovascular coupling, neural activity creates a reliable increase in blood flow and hence local temperature, which can be measured in the operating room with an infrared thermographic camera. While an awake patient performs tasks, this new method of monitoring the patterns of temperature fluctuation can be used to create a map of brain function, that once validated the surgical team can use to avoid damage to key functional areas. This can lead to safer, faster, and more effective surgeries for patients with drug-resistant epilepsy, glioma, or neurovascular malformations.

PHR: NARRATIVE Transcription is the first step in gene expression, is the most highly regulated step in gene expression, and is the target of two classes of current antibacterial drugs. The proposed work will define the structural and mechanistic basis of the principal pathways of bacterial and archaeal transcription termination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER AT EL PASO
PHR: Project narrative  MicroRNAs (miRNAs) enrichment was detected at synapse and synaptosomal components; however, the status of synaptosomal miRNAs and their precise roles in Alzheimer's disease progression are completely unexplored. Present study is designed to determine the status of synaptosomal and cytosolic miRNAs in Alzheimer's disease and to unveil their possible roles in amyloid-β and p-tau induced synaptic damage and cognitive dysfunction. The outcome of our study is expected to provide new insights about synaptosome- specific miRNAs and their therapeutic relevance in synaptic dysfunction in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My lab studies circadian-regulated processes and their contributions to health and disease; circadian regulation refers to daily oscillations in biological functions (e.g., metabolism, sleep) and is a universal, evolutionarily conserved feature from bacteria to humans. Proper circadian regulation is important for human health; despite the profound effects of circadian regulation on human health and physiology, it remains unclear how loss of circadian regulation contributes to the progression of disease (i.e., metabolic disorders, bacterial infection). In this proposal, we focus on circadian-regulated metabolism in Drosophila and its role in sensitivity to oxidative stress due to chronic short sleep (Project 1) and regulation of host tolerance of bacterial infection (Project 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of chronic widespread pain in individuals infected with the human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) is high, ranging from 25% to 85%. Despite the increasing awareness that pain is a significant problem for people with HIV by the International Task Force on Pain and AIDS in 1994, the prevalence rate of pain since the 1980s has not diminished despite antiretroviral therapy. Therefore, in this study, we propose to identify the mechanisms of chronic widespread pain in HIV and identify non-opioid therapeutic interventions to mitigate pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Excessive visceral adiposity, also known as central obesity, predicts development of type 2 diabetes and other metabolic diseases. We have recently identified Clostridium immunis as a commensal bacterium—and a sugar it secretes as the relevant active molecule—that reduces visceral adiposity, and the proposed studies seek to understand the mechanisms by which this happens. These results will highlight new therapeutic opportunities for reducing visceral adiposity and treating metabolic diseases.

PHR: Our recent work has identified a surprising level of parallel molecular responses among different cell types in the pituitary gland, the master controller of the endocrine system. We will now study mechanisms underlying regulation of the follicle stimulated hormone gene, a key gene involved in reproduction and polycystic ovarian disease, as well as the molecular changes in endocrine cell types in the pituitary during the reproductive cycle and during the development of hypothyroidism. The use of techniques for comprehensive study of the molecular state of individual cells will improve understanding of the pituitary endocrine processes contributing to health and disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: For Veterans with spinal cord injury who use a wheelchair, pressure injuries related to sitting are a significant daily threat to well-being. Pressure injuries are costly to treat, negatively impact quality of life and community participation, and can be life threatening. Moving or shifting at regular intervals in the wheelchair redistributes harmful pressure and reduce risk for skin breakdown, yet these movements are a challenge to perform consistently. The challenge exists due to lack of sensation to let the individual know they need to shift their weight. Pressure mapping provides a detailed visual representation of pressure distribution and can compensate for impaired sensation. Pressure mapping feedback delivered on-demand on mobile platforms can potentially increase effectiveness in carrying out behaviors to reduce risk for pressure injury when used during clinician-delivered education to set goals and monitor progress and when used at home as a self- management strategy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Noise exposure during their military careers and over their lifetimes could be an unrecognized but significant factor in vestibular disorders prevalent in aging Veterans. A recent study found that ~69 million US adults over the age of 40 have a balance disorder involving the inner ear and many of these patients also suffer from noise induced or occupational hearing loss. The proposed experiments will characterize noise induced vestibular dysfunction in an animal model, a necessary first step for development of preventative and rehabilitative strategies for this population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Reducing Veteran suicide has been the top clinical priority of the VA for the last few years. However, the total number of suicides among Veterans has continued to increase. There is a critical need for targeted treatments to reduce the risk of suicide in Veterans. Impaired executive function, such as impaired decision making and impulsivity, has been identified as an important contributor to the transition from suicidal ideation to suicide attempt. To address the epidemic of Veteran suicide in the United States, we propose to test the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of a five day transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) augmented executive functioning training intervention. This intervention will be delivered to high suicide risk inpatients who have been hospitalized following a suicide attempt. The ultimate goal is to reduce future suicide events (ideation, attempts, deaths) and improve quality of life (e.g. social relationships, health resource utilization).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Tinnitus is the most common service-connected disability among Veterans. Despite the prevalence of tinnitus, interventions known to improve quality of life with tinnitus are unstandardized and not widely implemented across VA settings. In contrast to the difficulty many Veterans experience with finding care to improve quality of life with tinnitus, products that falsely claim to cure tinnitus are widely available and easy to access. The purpose of this two-year project is to develop a prototype video-based online module of 10-15 Veterans' narratives on their lived-experience with tinnitus and with seeking assistance for tinnitus in clinical settings and elsewhere. Feedback on the protype will then be gathered from Veterans with bothersome tinnitus. The results will be used to inform the development of a VA Merit Award to create a comprehensive tinnitus module (30-50 narratives) and to evaluate the utility of patient narratives with Veterans and the VA clinicians who serve them.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SIERRA NEVADA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Thiamine micronutrient deficiency (TD) can cause a variety of non-specific symptoms and leads to several thiamine deficiency disorders such as heart failure, polyneuropathy, Wernicke’s Encephalopathy and generalized weakness and debility. Symptoms are often vague and non-specific such as fatigue, leg swelling, imbalance, confusion, mood disorders, gastrointestinal upset, and weakness. Hospitalized veterans may be particularly susceptible to TD due to food insecurity and chronic illnesses which cause inflammation and increased metabolic demands. This study aims to determine the prevalence of TD in hospitalized veterans which has never been done before. We also seek to identify risk factors causing TD including acute and chronic forms of inflammation, food insecurity, and dietary habits. Lastly, we hope to clarify the abnormally low levels of blood thiamine that correlate with symptoms of TD that improve with replenishment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Military traumatic brain injury (TBI) is complex, involving both diffuse and focal components and resulting in post- traumatic epilepsy (PTE) in many of our Veterans. While the high incidence of epilepsy following TBI is well known, PTE is often resistant to standard anti-epileptic therapeutics and the mechanisms underlying the transition from trauma to injury are unclear, making new treatment development challenging. Existing rodent models of PTE have reproduced aspects of this progression, including a temporal lobe epilepsy model. However, due to the key role of network localization of hyperexcitability in epileptogenesis, we propose that a large animal model (pig) with a gyrencephalic brain and complex white matter pathways may be the only way to model injury phenotypes and epileptogenesis accurately. We will therefore compare biomarkers and epileptogenic development and mechanisms in two different injury models, cortical contusion and repetitive mTBI. This will allow for treatment target development in order to find and validate new treatment paradigms for PTE.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Parkinson's disease (PD) is an incurable brain illness that afflicts more than one million Americans, including many of our aging veterans. PD places an unbearable burden on the individual due to progressive impairment of movement and mental function. As a result, patients lose critical abilities such as driving and can become isolated. Although drugs and surgery help movement problems, their benefits are temporary and may cause side effects. Drugs provide limited and temporary benefit for cognition and do not prevent dementia. Animal and preliminary human studies on aerobic exercise show promising results in helping a broad spectrum of symptoms. However, due to limited and inconsistent research results, the long term effects of aerobic exercise on brain health and clinical features in PD is unknown. We will conduct a clinical trial to test the long term effects of aerobic exercise on the brain tissue, movement, mental functions, and driving in PD. If effective, aerobic exercise can be implemented immediately as a low cost, easily accessible treatment in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquito-borne diseases are a global concern that impact public health, tourism, and natural disaster recovery efforts. With no preventative vaccines or effective therapeutic option available for most mosquito-borne diseases, vector control efforts are the only combative option; however, these efforts are often limited by financial constraint and insecticide resistance concern. This proposed project aims to integrate cutting-edge mosquito collection traps, and novel remote sensing and machine learning workflows to guide local vector operations and direct abatement efforts in a cost-efficient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  During the last ten years, it has become apparent that deregulation or disruption of proteins residing at the Intercalated Disk (ICD), the unique membrane microdomain that mediates the mechanical and electrical coupling of cardiomyocytes, leads to cardiac defects and development of severe or lethal cardiomyopathies. The proposed studies will provide important and novel information about the modulation of a major component of the ICD, N-cadherin, via the enzymatic activity of the obscurin Ser/Thr kinase domain 1. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms that underlie cell-cell adhesion and communication in cardiac muscle during normalcy will allow us to understand how these are altered or compromised during congenital heart disease, and thus enable us to develop new, effective, and targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Obesity is among the most common and costly disorders affecting Western society, yet underlying pathogenic mechanisms remain unclear. We propose that activation of brain microglial cells by high-fat diet consumption causes loss of key regulatory structures called perineuronal nets (PNNs), leading to disruption of the control system for body weight. Here, we will formally test this model by directly assessing the contributions of microglial activation and PNN loss to the development of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH CAR-T cell therapy reprograms a patient’s own immune cells to identify and destroy tumors with precision, trans- lating to revolutionary new treatment paradigm for certain blood cancers. Unfortunately, CAR-T cell therapy is enormously expensive, (~$500,000) and has a slow manufacturing process and enormous regulatory hurdles for facilities that manufacture CAR-T cells. We will develop a technology to manufacture CAR-T cells within a patient's own body to dramatically cut costs and increase patient access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rural, Latina farmworkers experience significant disparities in both maternal and overall cardiovascular disease (CVD) morbidity and mortality, with greater CVD risk factors than their urban, white, and male counterparts – disparities driven in part by social determinants of health (SDOH). With the rapid growth of Latinas in the U.S. farming workforce, it is imperative to implement and evaluate strategies to reduce CVD risk, premature CVD including in the perinatal period, and overall CVD morbidity and mortality. We will conduct a hybrid type 1 effectiveness-implementation trial to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of an adapted peer support, community health worker/promotora-led intervention for rural, migrant, reproductive- aged Latina farmworker women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The interaction between prefrontal and visual cortical areas is critical for many cognitive functions including attention and working memory. This proposal investigates the role of phase coding in visual cortex, along with its modulation by prefrontal activity during working memory, and the ability of a similar coding mechanism to expand the information capacity of the visual system during eye movements. Understanding the role of phase coding during working memory and eye movements will provide a necessary comparison point for neurological disorders involving impaired prefrontal-sensory interactions, including schizophrenia, Alzheimer’s disease, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and autism spectrum disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Responding to the pressing need to enhance digital literacy as a means to improve access to healthcare resources for rural populations, and in alignment with NINR’s call for Strategies to Improve Health Outcomes and Advance Health Equity in Rural Populations (RFA-NR-24-005), we developed CONNECT, a web-based tool designed to enhance digital literacy and access to cancer-related emotional distress and anxiety resources for rural older cancer survivors (ROCS). Building upon the positive feedback from our usability pilot and the Designing for Dissemination logic model, the proposed study seeks to adapt CONNECT to include functions recommended from our usability pilot and assess its efficacy and implementation in improving levels of cancer- related distress and digital engagement for ROCS compared to an enhanced standard care arm in a 12-month RCT. Successful completion of our aims will yield: 1) multi-level strategies enhancing healthcare delivery and access, fostering health equity in rural populations by improving digital literacy; 2) design strategies supporting the potential sustainability of digital tool development for marginalized populations; and 3) pertinent data to facilitate the scaled implementation of CONNECT in a future implementation-effectiveness hybrid trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PARENT AWARD R35GM148385 PROJECT NARRATIVE Animal-coloning bacteria transition from an environmental lifestyle to the host-associated state, in which individual bacterial cells coordinate functions to act as a group. Using a model system that allows for interrogation of bacteria within the animal host, this project addresses how the host and microbes exchange and interpret molecular signals, leading to group versus solitary behaviors of the colonizing microbes. This project has ramifications for therapeutic interventions to establish beneficial microbes (e.g. probiotics) and to understand and interfere with colonization by pathogenic microbes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The increased expression of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) enhances the immune function of macrophages and neutrophils by altering their metabolism and increasing cell production of ATP. This proposal is to investigate exactly how ACE modifies myeloid cell metabolism to learn how to increase myeloid cell function in treating human infection, malignancy and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mild cognitive impairment is a defining feature of early Alzheimer’s disease, but it is also associated with many other conditions such as HIV-infection, where the prevalence rate is much higher than the general population. Despite this, there is a fundamental lack of scientific knowledge regarding the shared and distinct mechanisms underlying cognitive impairment in people with HIV, early Alzheimer’s disease, and normal aging adults. The current project uses a state-of-the-art dynamic functional mapping approach to identify the specific brain circuits and neural processes that uniquely contribute to cognitive impairment in these different populations.

PHR: Project Narrative As our population ages, the incidence of Alzheimer's disease increases adding economic and social stress. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Prostate cancer is the second most commonly diagnosed cancer in men in the U.S. and is responsible for about 34,000 deaths and an economic toll of $13 billion each year. To treat men whose cancer has advanced to castration-resistant prostate cancer, Arma Bio is developing dual inhibitors of the full-length androgen receptor (AR-fl) and AR-V7, the most prevalent splice variant in men with this cancer. A dual inhibitor that can overcome drug resistance will offer a much-needed therapeutic option for men with castration-resistant prostate cancer, ultimately improving clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission since we want to identify a new therapeutic option for patients with autosomal dominant tubulo-interstitial kidney disease caused by Uromodulin mutations (ADTKD-UMOD). This condition is caused by heterozygous mutations in Uromodulin, which result in a misfolded protein, Uromodulin accumulation in the endoplasmic reticulum, apoptosis, renal fibrosis, and subsequently renal failure. We have been developing a cell cultured-based high throughput assay to identify compounds, which enhance mutant Uromodulin protein secretion in ADTKD-UMOD patients and thereby improve outcome of chronic and end-stage kidney disease in ADTKD-UMOD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Jackson, Daniel J. PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma disproportionately affects children in urban communities in the United States and imposes a great personal and health care burden. Despite treatment advances, a significant proportion of patients do not achieve disease control and continue to have high levels of morbidity and currently no intervention has proven to either prevent or cure this disease. By identifying and addressing these unmet needs in this application, we propose to improve current asthma care in urban children, pursue disease modification, and ultimately develop effective strategies to prevent asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lung transplantation is an established therapy for patients with end stage pulmonary failure, yet survival rates after lung transplantation lag behind those observed after transplantation of other solid organs (SOT). Unlike other SOTs where the initiation of rejection depends on cell trafficking to graft-draining lymphoid organs, in the lung, lymphocyte priming occurs in the lung graft itself. Utilizing this knowledge, we will investigate the efficacy of bi-functional nanoagents capable of preventing immune cell infiltration and priming while concomitantly eliciting immunosuppression, with the overall goal of inducing graft tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to optimize and validate a series of 3D Ultrashort Echo Time (UTE) MRI sequences with TEs ~100 times shorter than those of clinical sequences for comprehensive evaluation of joints with hemophilic arthropathy (HA) through assessment of hemosiderin, cartilage, and the osteochondral junction. We will first optimize a series of UTE MRI techniques in phantoms and human patellar samples, then validate them in ex vivo tissues from hemophilia patients following total knee arthroplasty (n=10) and from normal cadaveric human knee joints (n=10). Finally, we will apply the optimized 3D UTE and clinical MRI techniques in three groups of hemophilia patients with mild (n=20), moderate (n=20), and severe (n=20) HA at two time points (baseline and 12 months) and in one group of age-matched healthy volunteers (n=20) once, to evaluate the outcomes of prophylaxis by correlating cross-sectional and longitudinal UTE and clinical MRI measures with Hemophilia Joint Health Scores (HJHSs), Pettersson radiograph scores, and other self-reported outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Given that a substantial and increasing number of Veterans are using cannabis, it is essential for the VHA to understand how use is related to health, functioning, and service utilization outcomes among patients. Findings from the proposed study will have important implications for VHA patients, providers, and policymakers, including the better understanding of potential negative consequences associated with use among Veterans, the identification of patients for whom additional services may be indicated to address their cannabis use, and informing VHA clinical practice guidelines regarding cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE  Age is the most important risk factor for developing Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, but the mechanisms and development of successful treatments remain elusive. We propose to determine how age- related changes in both neurons and non-neuronal brain cells can drive these pathologies, with the long term goal of using these insights into effective interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People rely on cognitive abilities to function in situations and natural environments experienced in daily life, but research studies assess cognition in “one-shot” in a laboratory or clinical setting, which can yield unreliable results. This study will develop a smartphone app carefully designed to assess cognition with several brief (<3 min) tests per day over the course of a week in people with Down syndrome (DS) at risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). If successful, this study will provide new insights into DS-AD and could lead to faster results from clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will examine adverse and protective factors that modify Black-White disparities in sleep, will elucidate whether sleep disparities relates to Black-White differences in risk for cognitive impairment, and will identify best practices for research engagement with underrepresented populations. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission to reduce and/or eliminate health differences that are commonly observed between Blacks and Whites as well as enhance research engagement with diverse communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Identifying and understanding biological factors that promote opioid abuse and addiction can inform the development of novel therapeutic neuromodulation strategies that help combat the opioid epidemic. The proposed studies will test the hypothesis that fast-spiking interneurons in the nucleus accumbens represent a powerful modulator of motivational behaviors disrupted in addiction. Identifying novel circuits that can be harnessed to prevent and treat opioid use disorders is relevant to the NIH and NIDAs mission to tackle the opioid abuse epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions):  People living with HIV/AIDS remain untreated and more become newly infected each year. Many testing,  treatment, and prevention methods exist, raising critically important questions about which strategies to  employ when, where, and for whom, given varying epidemic features and resource constraints. We will  expand the CEPAC-I Model to address questions related to the impact of novel treatment and prevention  options and to determine which combinations of interventions will optimize HIV health outcomes globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Metalloproteins perform a wide range of chemical transformations whose functions are imperative for maintaining human health. The entire protein scaffold that houses the metallocofactor is responsible for controlling active site geometry, electronic structure of the metal center, reaction pathway, and substrate specificity. The ability to design proteins from scratch that bind metallocofactors and control substrate orientation will establish key structure-function relationships that govern the function and selectivity of efficient metalloenzymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer mortality rates are projected to more than double in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) in the next two decades. In order to address this looming public health crisis, we propose a training program that will maximize the rigor of cancer research in SSA by training researchers to develop strategic and operational capacity that will generate new knowledge about the determinants of cancer risk and outcomes, and improve effectiveness of strategies for reducing risk and improve outcomes. The overarching goals of this training program are to 1) Develop and disseminate best practices to enable the highest quality cancer research in Africa; 2) Teach fundamental skills to those who conduct research in Africa; and 3) Create a cadre of individuals who can lead and support cancer research in SSA.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Residential segregation, one example of structural racism, has long been recognized as a root cause of disparities in the U.S. and imposes inequitable burden on marginalized communities. The proposed project aims to assess the extent to which residential segregation influences oil and gas development and fertility among couples attempting pregnancy, which will be the first to characterize and evaluate residential segregation during the preconception period. This work seeks to identify opportunities for environmental and reproductive intervention, which will inform the development of targeted interventions to improve population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a severe congenital heart defect that can lead to death of newborns within a week in the absence of surgical treatment. This R01 project aims to address how the aberrant intercellular communication between myocardium (cardiac muscle fibers) and endocardium (endothelial cells lining the interior of the heart) leads to HLHS using patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells and CRISPR genome editing. Understanding how HLHS is developed would be pivotal to discover novel therapeutic treatment for this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Chronic pain and hazardous opioid use are major public health problems, particularly in military veterans. The major goal of this supplement project is to finalize recruitment, treatment and follow- ups of a multisite randomized clinical trial to test the efficacy of an innovative behavioral treatment for patients with chronic pain who are prescribed buprenorphine for the treatment of opioid use disorder. This project supports the strategic goals of several NIH institutes by examining a difficult and understudied problem with the ultimate goal of impacting scientific knowledge and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is focused on the identification of novel intracellular inputs to stress-activated signaling pathways. These inputs are critical to elicit the normal cellular responses to a wide variety of chemical and physical stress conditions, including heat shock, environmental toxins, and genotoxic stress. Such cellular responses help to maintain cellular integrity, metabolism, and genomic stability and are important in the treatment and prevention of cancer and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will have a significant impact on the fundamental understanding of bacterial physiology by determining why ribosome rescue pathways are essential for bacteria, providing the first structural and biochemical pictures of ribosomal interactions required for ribosome rescue, and providing biochemical and structural information that will allow rational optimization of the activity of ribosome rescue inhibitors. These studies will enable development of ribosome rescue inhibitors as new antibiotics. Therefore, this work will have a large and direct impact on improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Short tandem repeats (STRs) are repetitive DNA sequences that cause dozens of genetic diseases in humans and are difficult to sequence and interpret, leaving individuals with STR-associated disease undiagnosed. This proposal will establish a genetic diagnosis for hundreds of patients, while searching for new STR disease loci. To accomplish this, we will develop new computational approaches and call STRs across the genome in thousands of individuals to establish a population-scale STR catalog, with an emphasis on diverse and under- served populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) remain a leading cause of death in the United States in part due to abnormal calcium cycling in the heart. This project aims to gain novel insights into the impact of mitochondria on calcium cycling, thereby contributing to our understanding of arrhythmogenesis. Findings from these studies will offer valuable guidance for the development of new therapies targeting heart disorders, particularly calcium- dependent arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons in the brain are precisely orchestrated to provide an internal representation of our environment, a vital yet incompletely understood function. Here, we focus our attention on an overlooked population of inhibitory neurons in the brain to investigate how synapses and neurons cooperate to synchronize neuronal activity across a network. The proposed research will expand our knowledge on the fundamental mechanisms underlying neuronal network coordination, with our findings having potentially far-reaching impact for our understanding of neurological disorders such as autism spectrum disorders, schizophrenia, and epilepsies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant problem for U.S. Hispanic children; rehabilitation after TBI decrease disability, but requires timely initiation, and long treatments in hospitals, community healthcare facilities and schools. While parents play a critical role in their child’s recovery, Hispanic parents face substantial barriers that can result in delayed initiation of treatments and higher disability. Our study evaluates the effect of a culturally and linguistically tailored TBI education and navigation intervention, aimed to improve parental caregiving self-efficacy, optimize access and adherence to rehabilitation and ultimately improve outcomes in an underserved and rapidly growing population.

PHR: NeuroTech Harbor (NTH) led by Johns Hopkins and Howard Universities will gather innovators, expert mentors, and resource providers to accelerate the development of highly promising solutions to improve neurological health for all. To address the lack of women and under-represented minority innovators, it will create the nation's first incubator ecosystem with an Equitech philosophy - the belief that diversity of teams, leadership, and perspectives is a force multiplier to fuel innovation producing solutions accessible to all communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risk for major depressive disorder (MDD) dramatically increases during adolescence, particularly for females, and although interpersonal stress generation is an established risk factor, it is essential to clarify the underlying mechanisms to improve early detection and prevention of depression risk. The current study will utilize a multi- wave prospective design to examine neural and real-world affective reactivity to negative social interactions as prospective predictors of interpersonal stress generation and subsequent increases in depression symptoms in female adolescents at elevated risk for depression. Ultimately, the elucidation of brain and behavioral mechanisms underlying interpersonal stress generation and subsequent depression risk in female adolescents may contribute to greater understanding of the etiology of adolescent depression and aid in identifying novel targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Aging and age-related metabolic dysfunction poses unprecedented challenge to public health, and development of innovative and targetable interventions is highly warranted. Our project will examine the interplay of the microbiome and cellular senescence underlying diet-induced metabolic dysfunction in mice with older age. It will offer an integrative understanding of pathophysiology of age-related diseases, and lay a solid foundation to develop robust interventions targeting senescence, microbiome or both to improve health and increase longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to develop novel, non-invasive, clinically relevant magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technologies to visualize therapeutic cell distribution and homing following systemic administration. If successful, the proposed work will provide scientists and clinicians with powerful and clinically translatable imaging tools to assess cell homing, survival and therapeutic efficacy and the means to accelerate therapy development. If awarded, this diversity supplement will support a meritorious graduate student towards his PhD and career goals.
